Hereditary xanthinuria type I is caused by mutations in the XDH gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis is a condition that causes episodes of extreme muscle weakness or paralysis, usually beginning in infancy or early childhood.
Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis affects an estimated 1 in 200,000 people.
Mutations in the SCN4A gene can cause hyperkalemic periodic paralysis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Arginase deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes the amino acid arginine (a building block of proteins) and ammonia to accumulate gradually in the blood.
Arginase deficiency is a very rare disorder; it has been estimated to occur once in every 300,000 to 1,000,000 individuals.
Mutations in the ARG1 gene cause arginase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neuroblastoma is a type of cancer that most often affects children.
Neuroblastoma is the most common cancer in infants younger than 1 year.

Neuroblastoma and other cancers occur when a buildup of genetic mutations in critical genesthose that control cell growth and division (proliferation) or maturation (differentiation)allow cells to grow and divide uncontrollably to form a tumor.
Most people with neuroblastoma have sporadic neuroblastoma, meaning the condition arose from somatic mutations in the body's cells and was not inherited.
Birt-Hogg-Dub syndrome is a rare disorder that affects the skin and lungs and increases the risk of certain types of tumors.
Birt-Hogg-Dub syndrome is rare; its exact incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the FLCN gene cause Birt-Hogg-Dub syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered FLCN gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.
N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the NAGS gene cause N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Winchester syndrome is a rare inherited disease characterized by a loss of bone tissue (osteolysis), particularly in the hands and feet.
Winchester syndrome is a rare condition whose prevalence is unknown.
Winchester syndrome is caused by mutations in the MMP14 gene (also known as MT1-MMP).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Wolman disease is a rare inherited condition involving the breakdown and use of fats and cholesterol in the body (lipid metabolism).
Wolman disease is estimated to occur in 1 in 350,000 newborns.
Mutations in the LIPA gene cause Wolman disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency is one of several disorders that damage the immune system and cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency is rare; only about 70 affected individuals have been identified.
Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency is caused by mutations in the PNP gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cushing disease is caused by elevated levels of a hormone called cortisol, which leads to a wide variety of signs and symptoms.
Cushing disease is estimated to occur in 10 to 15 per million people worldwide.
The genetic cause of Cushing disease is often unknown.
Most cases of Cushing disease are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE) is a progressive disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of deposits of calcium and other minerals (mineralization) in elastic fibers.
PXE affects approximately 1 in 50,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the ABCC6 gene cause PXE.
PXE is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Beta-mannosidosis is a rare inherited disorder affecting the way certain sugar molecules are processed in the body.
Beta-mannosidosis is believed to be a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the MANBA gene cause beta-mannosidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spondylocostal dysostosis is a group of conditions characterized by abnormal development of bones in the spine and ribs.
Spondylocostal dysostosis is a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.

Mutations in at least four genes are known to cause spondylocostal dysostosis: Mutations in the DLL3 gene cause spondylocostal dysostosis type 1; mutations in the MESP2 gene cause spondylocostal dysostosis type 2; mutations in the LFNG gene cause spondylocostal dysostosis type 3; and mutations in the HES7 gene cause spondylocostal dysostosis type 4.
Spondylocostal dysostosis can have different inheritance patterns.
Biotinidase deficiency is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to recycle the vitamin biotin.
Profound or partial biotinidase deficiency occurs in approximately 1 in 60,000 newborns.
Mutations in the BTD gene cause biotinidase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the BTD gene in each cell have mutations.
Erythrokeratodermia variabilis et progressiva (EKVP) is a skin disorder that is present at birth or becomes apparent in infancy.
EKVP is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
EKVP can be caused by mutations in the GJB3 or GJB4 gene.
EKVP is most often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 (PHA1) is a condition characterized by problems regulating the amount of sodium in the body.
PHA1 is a rare condition that has been estimated to affect 1 in 80,000 newborns.
Mutations in one of four different genes involved in sodium regulation cause autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive PHA1.
PHA1 can have different inheritance patterns.
Trichothiodystrophy, which is commonly called TTD, is a rare inherited condition that affects many parts of the body.
Trichothiodystrophy has an estimated incidence of about 1 in 1 million newborns in the United States and Europe.
Most cases of the photosensitive form of trichothiodystrophy result from mutations in one of three genes: ERCC2, ERCC3, or GTF2H5.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hemophilia is a bleeding disorder that slows the blood clotting process.
The two major forms of hemophilia occur much more commonly in males than in females.
Changes in the F8 gene are responsible for hemophilia A, while mutations in the F9 gene cause hemophilia B.
Hemophilia A and hemophilia B are inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Gnathodiaphyseal dysplasia is a disorder that affects the bones.
The prevalence of gnathodiaphyseal dysplasia is unknown, but it is thought to be a rare disorder.
Gnathodiaphyseal dysplasia is caused by mutations in the ANO5 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called anoctamin-5.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Primary spontaneous pneumothorax is an abnormal accumulation of air in the space between the lungs and the chest cavity (called the pleural space) that can result in the partial or complete collapse of a lung.
Primary spontaneous pneumothorax is more common in men than in women.
Mutations in the FLCN gene can cause primary spontaneous pneumothorax, although these mutations appear to be a very rare cause of this condition.

When this condition is caused by mutations in the FLCN gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hereditary paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma is a condition characterized by the growth of noncancerous (benign) tumors in structures called paraganglia.
Hereditary paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma occurs in approximately 1 in 1 million people.
Mutations in at least four genes increase the risk of developing the different types of hereditary paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma.
Hereditary paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing tumors.
Arterial tortuosity syndrome is a disorder that affects connective tissue.
Arterial tortuosity syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Arterial tortuosity syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC2A10 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Deafness and myopia syndrome is a disorder that causes problems with both hearing and vision.
The prevalence of deafness and myopia syndrome is unknown.
Deafness and myopia syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLITRK6 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a condition that affects the bile ducts.
An estimated 1 in 10,000 people have primary sclerosing cholangitis, and the condition is diagnosed in approximately 1 in 100,000 people per year worldwide.
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is thought to arise from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
The inheritance pattern of primary sclerosing cholangitis is unknown because many genetic and environmental factors are likely to be involved.

Succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase (SCOT) deficiency is an inherited disorder that impairs the body's ability to break down ketones, which are molecules produced in the liver during the breakdown of fats.
The prevalence of SCOT deficiency is unknown.
Mutations in the OXCT1 gene cause SCOT deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans is a rare type of cancer that causes a tumor in the deep layers of skin.
Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans is estimated to occur in 1 in 100,000 to 1 in 1 million people per year.
Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans is associated with a rearrangement (translocation) of genetic material between chromosomes 17 and 22.
Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans results from a new mutation that occurs in the body's cells after conception and is found only in the tumor cells.
Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is a condition that causes profound hearing loss from birth and a disruption of the heart's normal rhythm (arrhythmia).
Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is uncommon; it affects an estimated 1.
Mutations in the KCNE1 and KCNQ1 genes cause Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Pierre Robin sequence is a set of abnormalities affecting the head and face, consisting of a small lower jaw (micrognathia), a tongue that is placed further back than normal (glossoptosis), and an opening in the roof of the mouth (a cleft palate).
Isolated Pierre Robin sequence affects an estimated 1 in 8,500 to 14,000 people.
Changes in the DNA near the SOX9 gene are the most common genetic cause of isolated Pierre Robin sequence.
Isolated Pierre Robin sequence is usually not inherited.
Prolidase deficiency is a disorder that causes a wide variety of symptoms.
Prolidase deficiency is a rare disorder.
Prolidase deficiency is caused by mutations in the PEPD gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Melnick-Needles syndrome is a disorder involving abnormalities in skeletal development and other health problems.
Melnick-Needles syndrome is a rare disorder; fewer than 100 cases have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the FLNA gene cause Melnick-Needles syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Restless legs syndrome is a neurological condition that causes an irresistible urge to move the legs.
Restless legs syndrome is one of the most common sleep and movement disorders.
Restless legs syndrome likely results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors, many of which are unknown.
The inheritance pattern of restless legs syndrome is usually unclear because many genetic and environmental factors can be involved.
Inclusion body myopathy with early-onset Paget disease and frontotemporal dementia (IBMPFD) is a condition that can affect the muscles, bones, and brain.
Although the prevalence of IBMPFD is unknown, this condition is rare.
Mutations in the VCP gene cause IBMPFD.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is a condition characterized by abnormal electrical pathways in the heart that cause a disruption of the heart's normal rhythm (arrhythmia).
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome affects 1 to 3 in 1,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the PRKAG2 gene cause Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.
Most cases of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome occur in people with no apparent family history of the condition.
Alpha thalassemia is a blood disorder that reduces the production of hemoglobin.
Alpha thalassemia is a fairly common blood disorder worldwide.
Alpha thalassemia typically results from deletions involving the HBA1 and HBA2 genes.
The inheritance of alpha thalassemia is complex.
KBG syndrome is a rare disorder that affects several body systems.
KBG syndrome is a rare disorder that has been reported in around 60 individuals.
KBG syndrome is caused by mutations in the ANKRD11 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Greenberg dysplasia is a severe condition characterized by specific bone abnormalities in the developing fetus.
Greenberg dysplasia is a very rare condition.
Mutations in the LBR gene cause Greenberg dysplasia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial porencephaly is part of a group of conditions called the COL4A1-related disorders.
Familial porencephaly is a rare condition, although the exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the COL4A1 gene cause familial porencephaly.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Psoriatic arthritis is a condition involving joint inflammation (arthritis) that usually occurs in combination with a skin disorder called psoriasis.
Psoriatic arthritis affects an estimated 24 in 10,000 people.
The specific cause of psoriatic arthritis is unknown.
This condition has an unknown inheritance pattern.
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood (hyperammonemia).
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency is a rare disorder; its overall incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the CPS1 gene cause carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Rheumatoid arthritis is a disease that causes chronic abnormal inflammation, primarily affecting the joints.
Rheumatoid arthritis affects about 1.
Rheumatoid arthritis probably results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors, many of which are unknown.
The inheritance pattern of rheumatoid arthritis is unclear because many genetic and environmental factors appear to be involved.
Generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) is a disorder affecting the circulatory system that becomes apparent before birth or within the first few months of life.
The prevalence of GACI has been estimated to be about 1 in 391,000.
In about two-thirds of cases, GACI is caused by mutations in the ENPP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

PPM-X syndrome is a condition characterized by psychotic disorders (most commonly bipolar disorder), a pattern of movement abnormalities known as parkinsonism, and mild to severe intellectual disability.
The prevalence of PPM-X syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the MECP2 gene cause PPM-X syndrome.
More than 99 percent of PPM-X syndrome cases occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 36 (SCA36) is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement that typically begin in mid-adulthood.
Approximately 100 individuals with SCA36 have been reported in the scientific literature.
SCA36 is caused by mutations in the NOP56 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Niemann-Pick disease is a condition that affects many body systems.
Niemann-Pick disease types A and B is estimated to affect 1 in 250,000 individuals.
Niemann-Pick disease types A and B is caused by mutations in the SMPD1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
RAPADILINO syndrome is a rare condition that involves many parts of the body.
RAPADILINO syndrome is a rare condition, although its worldwide prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the RECQL4 gene cause RAPADILINO syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Alpha-mannosidosis is a rare inherited disorder that causes problems in many organs and tissues of the body.
Alpha-mannosidosis is estimated to occur in approximately 1 in 500,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the MAN2B1 gene cause alpha-mannosidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Freeman-Sheldon syndrome is a condition that primarily affects the face, hands, and feet.
Freeman-Sheldon syndrome is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Freeman-Sheldon syndrome may be caused by mutations in the MYH3 gene.
Freeman-Sheldon syndrome can have different inheritance patterns.
Severe congenital neutropenia is a condition that causes affected individuals to be prone to recurrent infections.
The incidence of severe congenital neutropenia is estimated to be 1 in 200,000 individuals.
Severe congenital neutropenia can result from mutations in at least five different genes.
Most cases of severe congenital neutropenia are classified as sporadic and occur in people with no apparent history of the disorder in their family.
Vohwinkel syndrome is a disorder with classic and variant forms, both of which affect the skin.
Vohwinkel syndrome is a rare disorder; about 50 cases have been reported in the medical literature.
The classic form of Vohwinkel syndrome is caused by mutations in the GJB2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Thanatophoric dysplasia is a severe skeletal disorder characterized by extremely short limbs and folds of extra (redundant) skin on the arms and legs.
This condition occurs in 1 in 20,000 to 50,000 newborns.
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene cause thanatophoric dysplasia.
Thanatophoric dysplasia is considered an autosomal dominant disorder because one mutated copy of the FGFR3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.
GRACILE syndrome is a severe disorder that begins before birth.
GRACILE syndrome is found almost exclusively in Finland, where it is estimated to affect 1 in 47,000 infants.
GRACILE syndrome is caused by a mutation in the BCS1L gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Coloboma is an eye abnormality that occurs before birth.
Coloboma occurs in approximately 1 in 10,000 people.
Coloboma arises from abnormal development of the eye.
Most often, isolated coloboma is not inherited, and there is only one affected individual in a family.
Brody myopathy is a condition that affects the skeletal muscles, which are the muscles used for movement.
Brody myopathy is a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ATP2A1 gene cause Brody myopathy.
Brody myopathy is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Isolated lissencephaly sequence (ILS) is a condition that affects brain development before birth.
ILS affects approximately 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the PAFAH1B1, DCX, or TUBA1A gene can cause ILS.
The inheritance pattern of ILS depends on the gene involved.
Homocystinuria is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to process certain building blocks of proteins (amino acids) properly.
The most common form of homocystinuria affects at least 1 in 200,000 to 335,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the CBS, MTHFR, MTR, MTRR, and MMADHC genes cause homocystinuria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked congenital stationary night blindness is a disorder of the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color.
The prevalence of this condition is unknown.
Mutations in the NYX and CACNA1F genes cause the complete and incomplete forms of X-linked congenital stationary night blindness, respectively.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (CN-AML) is one form of a cancer of the blood-forming tissue (bone marrow) called acute myeloid leukemia.
Acute myeloid leukemia occurs in approximately 3.
CN-AML is classified as "cytogenetically normal" based on the type of genetic changes involved in its development.
CN-AML is not usually inherited but arises from genetic changes in the body's cells that occur after conception.
Adermatoglyphia is the absence of ridges on the skin on the pads of the fingers and toes, as well as on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.
Adermatoglyphia appears to be a rare condition.
Adermatoglyphia is caused by mutations in the SMARCAD1 gene.
Adermatoglyphia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered SMARCAD1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.
X-linked lissencephaly with abnormal genitalia (XLAG) is a condition that affects the development of the brain and genitalia.
The incidence of XLAG is unknown; approximately 30 affected families have been described in the medical literature.
Mutations in the ARX gene cause XLAG.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Prothrombin thrombophilia is an inherited disorder of blood clotting.
Prothrombin thrombophilia is the second most common inherited form of thrombophilia after factor V Leiden thrombophilia.
Prothrombin thrombophilia is caused by a particular mutation in the F2 gene.
The risk of developing an abnormal clot in a blood vessel depends on whether a person inherits one or two copies of the F2 gene mutation that causes prothrombin thrombophilia.
Catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT) is a condition characterized by an abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia).
The prevalence of CPVT is estimated to be about 1 in 10,000 people.
CPVT can result from mutations in two genes, RYR2 and CASQ2.
When CPVT results from mutations in the RYR2 gene, it has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
Schinzel-Giedion syndrome is a severe condition that is apparent at birth and affects many body systems.
Schinzel-Giedion syndrome is very rare, although the exact prevalence is unknown.
Schinzel-Giedion syndrome is caused by mutations in the SETBP1 gene.
Schinzel-Giedion syndrome results from new mutations in the SETBP1 gene and occurs in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
PRICKLE1-related progressive myoclonus epilepsy with ataxia is a rare inherited condition characterized by recurrent seizures (epilepsy) and problems with movement.
The prevalence of PRICKLE1-related progressive myoclonus epilepsy with ataxia is unknown.
PRICKLE1-related progressive myoclonus epilepsy with ataxia is caused by mutations in the PRICKLE1 gene.
Some cases of PRICKLE1-related progressive myoclonus epilepsy with ataxia are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Autosomal dominant vitreoretinochoroidopathy (ADVIRC) is a disorder that affects several parts of the eyes, including the clear gel that fills the eye (the vitreous), the light-sensitive tissue that lines the back of the eye (the retina), and the network of blood vessels within the retina (the choroid).
ADVIRC is considered a rare disease.
ADVIRC is caused by mutations in the BEST1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pyruvate carboxylase deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes lactic acid and other potentially toxic compounds to accumulate in the blood.
Pyruvate carboxylase deficiency is a rare condition, with an estimated incidence of 1 in 250,000 births worldwide.
Mutations in the PC gene cause pyruvate carboxylase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita is an inherited bone growth disorder that results in short stature (dwarfism), skeletal abnormalities, and problems with vision and hearing.
This condition is rare; the exact incidence is unknown.
Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita is one of a spectrum of skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the COL2A1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Palmoplantar keratoderma with deafness is a disorder characterized by skin abnormalities and hearing loss.
Palmoplantar keratoderma with deafness is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Palmoplantar keratoderma with deafness can be caused by mutations in the GJB2 or MT-TS1 genes.
Palmoplantar keratoderma with deafness can have different inheritance patterns.
47,XYY syndrome is characterized by an extra copy of the Y chromosome in each of a male's cells.
This condition occurs in about 1 in 1,000 newborn boys.
People normally have 46 chromosomes in each cell.
Most cases of 47,XYY syndrome are not inherited.
Leydig cell hypoplasia is a condition that affects male sexual development.
Leydig cell hypoplasia is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the LHCGR gene cause Leydig cell hypoplasia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Permanent neonatal diabetes mellitus is a type of diabetes that first appears within the first 6 months of life and persists throughout the lifespan.
About 1 in 400,000 infants are diagnosed with diabetes mellitus in the first few months of life.
Permanent neonatal diabetes mellitus may be caused by mutations in several genes.
Permanent neonatal diabetes mellitus can have different inheritance patterns.
Camurati-Engelmann disease is a condition that mainly affects the bones.
The prevalence of Camurati-Engelmann disease is unknown.
Mutations in the TGFB1 gene cause Camurati-Engelmann disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Congenital contractural arachnodactyly is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
The prevalence of congenital contractural arachnodactyly is estimated to be less than 1 in 10,000 worldwide.
Mutations in the FBN2 gene cause congenital contractural arachnodactyly.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cole disease is a disorder that affects the skin.
Cole disease is a rare disease; its prevalence is unknown.
Cole disease is caused by mutations in the ENPP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Congenital central hypoventilation syndrome (CCHS) is a disorder that affects breathing.
CCHS is a relatively rare disorder.
Mutations in the PHOX2B gene cause CCHS.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Aicardi syndrome is a disorder that occurs almost exclusively in females.
Aicardi syndrome is a very rare disorder.
The cause of Aicardi syndrome is unknown.
Nearly all known cases of Aicardi syndrome are sporadic, which means that they are not passed down through generations and occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats to energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
In the United States, the estimated incidence of MCAD deficiency is 1 in 17,000 people.
Mutations in the ACADM gene cause MCAD deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary hemochromatosis is a disorder that causes the body to absorb too much iron from the diet.
Type 1 hemochromatosis is one of the most common genetic disorders in the United States, affecting about 1 million people.
Mutations in the HAMP, HFE, HFE2, SLC40A1, and TFR2 genes cause hereditary hemochromatosis.
Types 1, 2, and 3 hemochromatosis are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Incontinentia pigmenti is a condition that can affect many body systems, particularly the skin.
Incontinentia pigmenti is an uncommon disorder.
Mutations in the IKBKG gene cause incontinentia pigmenti.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

Stve-Wiedemann syndrome is a severe condition characterized by bone abnormalities and dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary body processes such as the regulation of breathing rate and body temperature.
Stve-Wiedemann syndrome is a rare condition that has been found worldwide.
Stve-Wiedemann syndrome is usually caused by mutations in the LIFR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) is an inherited disorder in which the body cannot properly regulate the number of immune system cells (lymphocytes).
ALPS is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the FAS gene cause ALPS in approximately 75 percent of affected individuals.

In most people with ALPS, including the majority of those with FAS gene mutations, this condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
SOX2 anophthalmia syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by abnormal development of the eyes and other parts of the body.
SOX2 anophthalmia syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 250,000 individuals.
Mutations in the SOX2 gene cause SOX2 anophthalmia syndrome.
SOX2 anophthalmia syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Spastic paraplegia type 31 is one of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.

Spastic paraplegia type 31 is one of a subgroup of hereditary spastic paraplegias known as autosomal dominant hereditary spastic paraplegia, which has an estimated prevalence of one to 12 per 100,000 individuals.
Spastic paraplegia type 31 is caused by mutations in the REEP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Microphthalmia with linear skin defects syndrome is a disorder that mainly affects females.
The prevalence of microphthalmia with linear skin defects syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the HCCS gene or a deletion of genetic material that includes the HCCS gene cause microphthalmia with linear skin defects syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of genetic conditions that cause the skin to be very fragile and to blister easily.
Considered together, the incidence of all types of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa is estimated to be 6.
Mutations in the COL7A1 gene cause all three major forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa.
The most severe types of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Leber congenital amaurosis is an eye disorder that primarily affects the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color.
Leber congenital amaurosis occurs in 2 to 3 per 100,000 newborns.
Leber congenital amaurosis can result from mutations in at least 14 genes, all of which are necessary for normal vision.
Leber congenital amaurosis usually has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
Aniridia is an eye disorder characterized by a complete or partial absence of the colored part of the eye (the iris).
Aniridia occurs in 1 in 50,000 to 100,000 newborns worldwide.
Aniridia is caused by mutations in the PAX6 gene.
Aniridia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is an inherited condition involving the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system).
The prevalence of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is estimated to be 1 in 200,000 to 500,000 males in the United States.
Mutations in the PLP1 gene cause Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Mucolipidosis type IV is an inherited disorder characterized by delayed development and vision impairment that worsens over time.
Mucolipidosis type IV is estimated to occur in 1 in 40,000 people.
Mutations in the MCOLN1 gene cause mucolipidosis type IV.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Thrombocytopenia-absent radius (TAR) syndrome is characterized by the absence of a bone called the radius in each forearm.
TAR syndrome is a rare disorder, affecting fewer than 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the RBM8A gene cause TAR syndrome.
TAR syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell are altered.
Hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (HDGC) is an inherited disorder that greatly increases the chance of developing a form of stomach (gastric) cancer.
Gastric cancer is the fourth most common form of cancer worldwide, affecting 900,000 people per year.
It is likely that 30 to 40 percent of individuals with HDGC have a mutation in the CDH1 gene.
HDGC is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered CDH1 gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing cancer.
Chronic atrial and intestinal dysrhythmia (CAID) is a disorder affecting the heart and the digestive system.
The prevalence of CAID is unknown.
CAID is caused by mutations in the SGO1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type II (HSAN2) is a condition that primarily affects the sensory nerve cells (sensory neurons), which transmit information about sensations such as pain, temperature, and touch.
HSAN2 is a rare disease; however, the prevalence is unknown.
There are two types of HSAN2, called HSAN2A and HSAN2B, each caused by mutations in a different gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked (IPEX) syndrome is characterized by the development of multiple autoimmune disorders in affected individuals.
IPEX syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the FOXP3 gene cause some cases of IPEX syndrome.
When IPEX syndrome is due to mutations in the FOXP3 gene, it is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
A desmoid tumor is an abnormal growth that arises from connective tissue, which is the tissue that provides strength and flexibility to structures such as bones, ligaments, and muscles.
Desmoid tumors are rare, affecting an estimated 1 to 2 per 500,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the CTNNB1 gene or the APC gene cause desmoid tumors.
Most desmoid tumors are sporadic and are not inherited.
X-linked sideroblastic anemia is an inherited disorder that prevents developing red blood cells (erythroblasts) from making enough hemoglobin, which is the protein that carries oxygen in the blood.
This form of anemia is uncommon.
Mutations in the ALAS2 gene cause X-linked sideroblastic anemia.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
GM2-gangliosidosis, AB variant is a rare inherited disorder that progressively destroys nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and spinal cord.
The AB variant is extremely rare; only a few cases have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the GM2A gene cause GM2-gangliosidosis, AB variant.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
CHST3-related skeletal dysplasia is a genetic condition characterized by bone and joint abnormalities that worsen over time.
The prevalence of CHST3-related skeletal dysplasia is unknown.
As its name suggests, CHST3-related skeletal dysplasia results from mutations in the CHST3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia, Strudwick type is an inherited disorder of bone growth that results in short stature (dwarfism), skeletal abnormalities, and problems with vision.
This condition is rare; only a few affected individuals have been reported worldwide.
Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia, Strudwick type is one of a spectrum of skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the COL2A1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body and occurs primarily in males.
The incidence of Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the GPC3 gene are responsible for some cases of Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Uromodulin-associated kidney disease is an inherited condition that affects the kidneys.
The prevalence of uromodulin-associated kidney disease is unknown.
Mutations in the UMOD gene cause uromodulin-associated kidney disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is a condition that affects the immune system and occurs almost exclusively in males.
XLA occurs in approximately 1 in 200,000 newborns.
Mutations in the BTK gene cause XLA.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Juvenile Batten disease is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
Juvenile Batten disease is the most common type of NCL, but its exact prevalence is unknown.
Most cases of juvenile Batten disease are caused by mutations in the CLN3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Potassium-aggravated myotonia is a disorder that affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
This condition appears to be rare; it has been reported in only a few individuals and families worldwide.
Mutations in the SCN4A gene cause potassium-aggravated myotonia.
Potassium-aggravated myotonia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

DICER1 syndrome is an inherited disorder that increases the risk of a variety of cancerous and noncancerous (benign) tumors, most commonly certain types of tumors that occur in the lungs, kidneys, ovaries, and thyroid (a butterfly-shaped gland in the lower neck).
DICER1 syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
DICER1 syndrome is caused by mutations in the DICER1 gene.
DICER1 syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Graves disease is a condition that affects the function of the thyroid, which is a butterfly-shaped gland in the lower neck.
Graves disease affects about 1 in 200 people.
Graves disease is thought to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
The inheritance pattern of Graves disease is unclear because many genetic and environmental factors appear to be involved.
McCune-Albright syndrome is a disorder that affects the bones, skin, and several hormone-producing (endocrine) tissues.
McCune-Albright syndrome occurs in between 1 in 100,000 and 1 in 1,000,000 people worldwide.
McCune-Albright syndrome is caused by a mutation in the GNAS gene.
McCune-Albright syndrome is not inherited.
SOST-related sclerosing bone dysplasia is a disorder of bone development characterized by excessive bone formation (hyperostosis).
SOST-related sclerosing bone dysplasia is a rare condition; its exact prevalence is unknown.
SOST-related sclerosing bone dysplasia is caused by mutations in or near the SOST gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Rippling muscle disease is a condition in which the muscles are unusually sensitive to movement or pressure (irritable).
The prevalence of rippling muscle disease is unknown.
Rippling muscle disease can be caused by mutations in the CAV3 gene.
Rippling muscle disease is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, but it is occasionally inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is a condition characterized by recurrent seizures (epilepsy).
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy affects an estimated 1 in 1,000 people worldwide.
The genetics of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy are complex and not completely understood.
The inheritance pattern of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is not completely understood.
Prostate cancer is a common disease that affects men, usually in middle age or later.
About 1 in 7 men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer at some time during their life.
Cancers occur when genetic mutations build up in critical genes, specifically those that control cell growth and division or the repair of damaged DNA.
Many cases of prostate cancer are not related to inherited gene changes.
Maternally inherited diabetes and deafness (MIDD) is a form of diabetes that is often accompanied by hearing loss, especially of high tones.
About 1 percent of people with diabetes have MIDD.
Mutations in the MT-TL1, MT-TK, or MT-TE gene cause MIDD.
MIDD is inherited in a mitochondrial pattern, which is also known as maternal inheritance.
Klippel-Feil syndrome is a bone disorder characterized by the abnormal joining (fusion) of two or more spinal bones in the neck (cervical vertebrae).
Klippel-Feil syndrome is estimated to occur in 1 in 40,000 to 42,000 newborns worldwide.
Mutations in the GDF6, GDF3, or MEOX1 gene can cause Klippel-Feil syndrome.

When Klippel-Feil syndrome is caused by mutations in the GDF6 or GDF3 genes, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
An abdominal wall defect is an opening in the abdomen through which various abdominal organs can protrude.
Abdominal wall defects are uncommon.
No genetic mutations are known to cause an abdominal wall defect.
Most cases of abdominal wall defect are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
REN-related kidney disease is an inherited condition that affects kidney function.
REN-related kidney disease is a rare condition.
Mutations in the REN gene cause REN-related kidney disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Familial hyperaldosteronism is a group of inherited conditions in which the adrenal glands, which are small glands located on top of each kidney, produce too much of the hormone aldosterone.
The prevalence of familial hyperaldosteronism is unknown.
The various types of familial hyperaldosteronism have different genetic causes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Acral peeling skin syndrome is a skin disorder characterized by painless peeling of the top layer of skin.
Acral peeling skin syndrome is a rare condition, with several dozen cases reported in the medical literature.
Acral peeling skin syndrome is caused by mutations in the TGM5 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Otospondylomegaepiphyseal dysplasia (OSMED) is a skeletal disorder characterized by skeletal abnormalities, distinctive facial features, and severe hearing loss.
This condition is rare; the prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the COL11A2 gene cause OSMED.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is an inherited disorder of the immune system that occurs almost exclusively in males.
X-linked SCID is the most common form of severe combined immunodeficiency.
Mutations in the IL2RG gene cause X-linked SCID.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Czech dysplasia is an inherited condition that affects joint function and bone development.
The prevalence of Czech dysplasia is unknown; at least 11 families have been affected.
Czech dysplasia is caused by a particular mutation in the COL2A1 gene.
Czech dysplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered COL2A1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Rett syndrome is a brain disorder that occurs almost exclusively in girls.
This condition affects an estimated 1 in 8,500 females.
Classic Rett syndrome and some variant forms of the condition are caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene.
In more than 99 percent of people with Rett syndrome, there is no history of the disorder in their family.
Congenital afibrinogenemia is a bleeding disorder caused by impairment of the blood clotting process.
Congenital afibrinogenemia is a rare condition that occurs in approximately 1 in 1 million newborns.
Congenital afibrinogenemia results from mutations in one of three genes, FGA, FGB, or FGG.
Congenital afibrinogenemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
GM1 gangliosidosis is an inherited disorder that progressively destroys nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and spinal cord.
GM1 gangliosidosis is estimated to occur in 1 in 100,000 to 200,000 newborns.
Mutations in the GLB1 gene cause GM1 gangliosidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Alkaptonuria is an inherited condition that causes urine to turn black when exposed to air.
This condition is rare, affecting 1 in 250,000 to 1 million people worldwide.
Mutations in the HGD gene cause alkaptonuria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Benign chronic pemphigus, often called Hailey-Hailey disease, is a rare skin condition that usually appears in early adulthood.
Benign chronic pemphigus is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Benign chronic pemphigus results from mutations in the ATP2C1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Silver syndrome belongs to a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
Although Silver syndrome appears to be a rare condition, its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the BSCL2 gene cause Silver syndrome.
Silver syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hereditary folate malabsorption is a disorder that interferes with the body's ability to absorb certain B vitamins (called folates) from food.
The prevalence of hereditary folate malabsorption is unknown.
The SLC46A1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called the proton-coupled folate transporter (PCFT).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
MECP2 duplication syndrome is a condition that occurs almost exclusively in males and is characterized by moderate to severe intellectual disability.
The prevalence of MECP2 duplication syndrome is unknown; approximately 120 affected individuals have been reported in the scientific literature.
MECP2 duplication syndrome is caused by a genetic change in which there is an extra copy of the MECP2 gene in each cell.
MECP2 duplication syndrome is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is an acquired disorder that leads to the premature death and impaired production of blood cells.
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a rare disorder, estimated to affect between 1 and 5 per million people.
Mutations in the PIGA gene cause paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
This condition is acquired, rather than inherited.
Glycine encephalopathy, which is also known as nonketotic hyperglycinemia or NKH, is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormally high levels of a molecule called glycine.
The worldwide incidence of glycine encephalopathy is unknown.
Mutations in the AMT and GLDC genes cause glycine encephalopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 6 (SCA6) is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement.
The worldwide prevalence of SCA6 is estimated to be less than 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the CACNA1A gene cause SCA6.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
LAMA2-related muscular dystrophy is a disorder that causes weakness and wasting (atrophy) of muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
The prevalence of early-onset LAMA2-related muscular dystrophy is estimated at 1 in 30,000 individuals.
As its name suggests, LAMA2-related muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the LAMA2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly (MFDM) is a disorder that causes abnormalities of the head and face.
MFDM is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
MFDM is caused by mutations in the EFTUD2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Guillain-Barr syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that affects the nerves.
The prevalence of Guillain-Barr syndrome is estimated to be 6 to 40 cases per 1 million people.

Some studies show that normal variations in certain genes may be associated with an increased risk of developing Guillain-Barr syndrome; however, more research is necessary to identify and confirm associated genes.
Almost all cases of Guillain-Barr syndrome are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disease characterized by the buildup of thick, sticky mucus that can damage many of the body's organs.
Cystic fibrosis is a common genetic disease within the white population in the United States.
Mutations in the CFTR gene cause cystic fibrosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Juvenile polyposis syndrome is a disorder characterized by multiple noncancerous (benign) growths called juvenile polyps.
Juvenile polyposis syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 100,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the BMPR1A and SMAD4 genes cause juvenile polyposis syndrome.
Juvenile polyposis syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
The prevalence of the 22q11.
People with 22q11.
The inheritance of 22q11.

Barth syndrome is a rare condition characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature.
Barth syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 300,000 to 400,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the TAZ gene cause Barth syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Moebius syndrome is a rare neurological condition that primarily affects the muscles that control facial expression and eye movement.
The exact incidence of Moebius syndrome is unknown.
The causes of Moebius syndrome are unknown, although the condition probably results from a combination of environmental and genetic factors.
Most cases of Moebius syndrome are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Adult-onset leukoencephalopathy with axonal spheroids and pigmented glia (ALSP) is a neurological condition characterized by changes to certain areas of the brain.
ALSP is thought to be a rare disorder, although the prevalence is unknown.
ALSP is caused by mutations in the CSF1R gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Y chromosome infertility is a condition that affects the production of sperm, making it difficult or impossible for affected men to father children.
Y chromosome infertility occurs in approximately 1 in 2,000 to 1 in 3,000 males of all ethnic groups.
As its name suggests, this form of infertility is caused by changes in the Y chromosome.

Because Y chromosome infertility impedes the ability to father children, this condition is usually caused by new deletions on the Y chromosome and occurs in men with no history of the disorder in their family.
Larsen syndrome is a disorder that affects the development of bones throughout the body.
Larsen syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the FLNB gene cause Larsen syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hyperprolinemia is an excess of a particular protein building block (amino acid), called proline, in the blood.
It is difficult to determine the prevalence of hyperprolinemia type I because most people with the condition do not have any symptoms.
Mutations in the ALDH4A1 and PRODH genes cause hyperprolinemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Atelosteogenesis type 1 is a disorder that affects the development of bones throughout the body.
Atelosteogenesis type 1 is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the FLNB gene cause atelosteogenesis type 1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body.
The prevalence of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 50,000 births.
Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material near the end of the short (p) arm of chromosome 4.
Between 85 and 90 percent of all cases of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are not inherited.
Sandhoff disease is a rare inherited disorder that progressively destroys nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and spinal cord.
Sandhoff disease is a rare disorder; its frequency varies among populations.
Mutations in the HEXB gene cause Sandhoff disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Alpha-methylacyl-CoA racemase (AMACR) deficiency is a disorder that causes a variety of neurological problems that begin in adulthood and slowly get worse.
AMACR deficiency is a rare disorder.
AMACR deficiency is caused by mutations in the AMACR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary hyperekplexia is a condition in which affected infants have increased muscle tone (hypertonia) and an exaggerated startle reaction to unexpected stimuli, especially loud noises.
The exact prevalence of hereditary hyperekplexia is unknown.
At least five genes are associated with hereditary hyperekplexia.
Hereditary hyperekplexia has different inheritance patterns.
MECP2-related severe neonatal encephalopathy is a neurological disorder that primarily affects males and causes brain dysfunction (encephalopathy).
MECP2-related severe neonatal encephalopathy is likely a rare condition.
Mutations in the MECP2 gene cause MECP2-related severe neonatal encephalopathy.
MECP2-related severe neonatal encephalopathy has an X-linked pattern of inheritance.
Andermann syndrome is a disorder that damages the nerves used for muscle movement and sensation (motor and sensory neuropathy).
Andermann syndrome is most often seen in the French-Canadian population of the Saguenay-Lac-St.
Mutations in the SLC12A6 gene cause Andermann syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Congenital myasthenic syndrome is a group of conditions characterized by muscle weakness (myasthenia) that worsens with physical exertion.
The prevalence of congenital myasthenic syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in many genes can cause congenital myasthenic syndrome.
This condition is most commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cherubism is a disorder characterized by abnormal bone tissue in the lower part of the face.
The incidence of cherubism is unknown.
Mutations in the SH3BP2 gene have been identified in about 80 percent of people with cherubism.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Alport syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities.
Alport syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 50,000 newborns.
Mutations in the COL4A3, COL4A4, and COL4A5 genes cause Alport syndrome.
Alport syndrome can have different inheritance patterns.
Branchiootorenal (BOR) syndrome is a condition that disrupts the development of tissues in the neck and causes malformations of the ears and kidneys.
Researchers estimate that BOR/BO syndrome affects about 1 in 40,000 people.
Mutations in three genes, EYA1, SIX1, and SIX5, have been reported in people with BOR/BO syndrome.
BOR/BO syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Deafness-dystonia-optic neuronopathy (DDON) syndrome, also known as Mohr-Tranebjrg syndrome, is characterized by hearing loss that begins early in life, problems with movement, impaired vision, and behavior problems.
DDON syndrome is a rare disorder; it has been reported in fewer than 70 people worldwide.
Mutations in the TIMM8A gene cause DDON syndrome.
DDON syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Milroy disease is a condition that affects the normal function of the lymphatic system.
Milroy disease is a rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the FLT4 gene cause some cases of Milroy disease.
Milroy disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Frontonasal dysplasia is a condition that results from abnormal development of the head and face before birth.
Frontonasal dysplasia is likely a rare condition; at least 100 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the ALX3 gene cause frontonasal dysplasia type 1, ALX4 gene mutations cause type 2, and ALX1 gene mutations cause type 3.
When frontonasal dysplasia is caused by mutations in the ALX1 or ALX3 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
FOXG1 syndrome is a condition characterized by impaired development and structural brain abnormalities.
FOXG1 syndrome appears to be rare.
As its name suggests, FOXG1 syndrome is caused by changes involving the FOXG1 gene.
FOXG1 syndrome is considered an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor syndrome is a condition characterized by overactivity of the parathyroid glands (hyperparathyroidism).
The exact prevalence of hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the CDC73 gene (also known as the HRPT2 gene) cause hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis refers to a group of conditions involving joint inflammation (arthritis) that first appears before the age of 16.
The incidence of juvenile idiopathic arthritis in North America and Europe is estimated to be 4 to 16 in 10,000 children.
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is thought to arise from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of juvenile idiopathic arthritis are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.

Sudden infant death with dysgenesis of the testes syndrome (SIDDT) is a rare condition that is fatal in the first year of life; its major features include abnormalities of the reproductive system in males, feeding difficulties, and breathing problems.
SIDDT has been diagnosed in more than 20 infants from a single Old Order Amish community in Pennsylvania.
A single mutation in the TSPYL1 gene has caused all identified cases of SIDDT.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cystinuria is a condition characterized by the buildup of the amino acid cystine, a building block of most proteins, in the kidneys and bladder.
Cystinuria affects approximately 1 in 10,000 people.
Mutations in the SLC3A1 or SLC7A9 gene cause cystinuria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hyperferritinemia-cataract syndrome is a disorder characterized by an excess of an iron storage protein called ferritin in the blood (hyperferritinemia) and tissues of the body.
Hyperferritinemia-cataract syndrome has been estimated to occur in 1 in 200,000 individuals.
Hyperferritinemia-cataract syndrome is caused by mutations in the FTL gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy, usually called CADASIL, is an inherited condition that causes stroke and other impairments.
CADASIL is likely a rare condition; however, its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the NOTCH3 gene cause CADASIL.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered NOTCH3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) is one of the major forms of epidermolysis bullosa, a group of genetic conditions that cause the skin to be very fragile and to blister easily.
Both types of junctional epidermolysis bullosa are rare, affecting fewer than 1 per million people in the United States.
Junctional epidermolysis bullosa results from mutations in the LAMA3, LAMB3, LAMC2, and COL17A1 genes.
Both types of junctional epidermolysis bullosa are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a disorder in which excess immune system cells called Langerhans cells build up in the body.
Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare disorder.
Somatic mutations in the BRAF gene have been identified in the Langerhans cells of about half of individuals with Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
Langerhans cell histiocytosis is usually not inherited and typically occurs in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Childhood myocerebrohepatopathy spectrum, commonly called MCHS, is part of a group of conditions called the POLG-related disorders.
The prevalence of childhood myocerebrohepatopathy spectrum is unknown.
MCHS is caused by mutations in the POLG gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Crouzon syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis).
Crouzon syndrome is seen in about 16 per million newborns.
Mutations in the FGFR2 gene cause Crouzon syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase deficiency is a condition characterized by an unusually small head size (microcephaly); impaired development of physical reactions, movements, and speech (psychomotor retardation); and recurrent seizures (epilepsy).
This condition is likely a rare disorder, but its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the PHGDH gene cause phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hajdu-Cheney syndrome is a rare disorder that can affect many parts of the body, particularly the bones.
Hajdu-Cheney syndrome is a rare disease; its prevalence is unknown.
Hajdu-Cheney syndrome is associated with mutations in the NOTCH2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered NOTCH2 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Molybdenum cofactor deficiency is a rare condition characterized by brain dysfunction (encephalopathy) that worsens over time.
Molybdenum cofactor deficiency is a rare condition that is estimated to occur in 1 in 100,000 to 200,000 newborns worldwide.
Molybdenum cofactor deficiency is caused by mutations in the MOCS1, MOCS2, or GPHN gene.
Molybdenum cofactor deficiency has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Focal dermal hypoplasia is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the skin, skeleton, eyes, and face.
Focal dermal hypoplasia appears to be a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the PORCN gene cause focal dermal hypoplasia.
Focal dermal hypoplasia is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy is a term for a group of diseases that cause weakness and wasting of the muscles in the arms and legs.
It is difficult to determine the prevalence of limb-girdle muscular dystrophy because its features vary and overlap with those of other muscle disorders.
The various forms of limb-girdle muscular dystrophy are caused by mutations in many different genes.
Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy can have different inheritance patterns.
Pitt-Hopkins syndrome is a condition characterized by intellectual disability and developmental delay, breathing problems, recurrent seizures (epilepsy), and distinctive facial features.
Pitt-Hopkins syndrome is thought to be a very rare condition.
Mutations in the TCF4 gene cause Pitt-Hopkins syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
CHOPS syndrome is a disorder involving multiple abnormalities that are present from birth (congenital).
CHOPS syndrome is a rare disorder whose prevalence is unknown.
CHOPS syndrome is caused by mutations in the AFF4 gene.
CHOPS syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Netherton syndrome is a disorder that affects the skin, hair, and immune system.
Netherton syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 200,000 newborns.
Netherton syndrome is caused by mutations in the SPINK5 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Kabuki syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Kabuki syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 32,000 newborns.
Kabuki syndrome is caused by mutations in the KMT2D gene (also known as MLL2) or the KDM6A gene.

When Kabuki syndrome is caused by mutations in the KMT2D gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pyruvate kinase deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects red blood cells, which carry oxygen to the body's tissues.
Pyruvate kinase deficiency is the most common inherited cause of nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia.
Pyruvate kinase deficiency is caused by mutations in the PKLR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
PMM2-congenital disorder of glycosylation (PMM2-CDG, also known as congenital disorder of glycosylation type Ia) is an inherited condition that affects many parts of the body.
More than 800 individuals with PMM2-CDG have been identified worldwide.
PMM2-CDG is caused by mutations in the PMM2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Trisomy 13, also called Patau syndrome, is a chromosomal condition associated with severe intellectual disability and physical abnormalities in many parts of the body.
Trisomy 13 occurs in about 1 in 16,000 newborns.
Most cases of trisomy 13 result from having three copies of chromosome 13 in each cell in the body instead of the usual two copies.
Most cases of trisomy 13 are not inherited and result from random events during the formation of eggs and sperm in healthy parents.

Autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxia type 1 (ARCA1) is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement due to a loss (atrophy) of nerve cells in the part of the brain that coordinates movement (the cerebellum).
More than 100 people have been diagnosed with ARCA1.
Mutations in the SYNE1 gene cause ARCA1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body, particularly the immune system.
Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare disorder.
Chediak-Higashi syndrome is caused by mutations in the LYST gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Bartter syndrome is a group of very similar kidney disorders that cause an imbalance of potassium, sodium, chloride, and related molecules in the body.
The exact prevalence of this disorder is unknown, although it likely affects about 1 per million people worldwide.
Bartter syndrome can be caused by mutations in at least five genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Congenital plasminogen deficiency is a disorder that results in inflamed growths on the mucous membranes, which are the moist tissues that line body openings such as the eyelids and the inside of the mouth.
The prevalence of congenital plasminogen deficiency has been estimated at 1.
Congenital plasminogen deficiency is caused by mutations in the PLG gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a liver disorder that occurs in pregnant women.
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is estimated to affect 1 percent of women of Northern European ancestry.
Genetic changes in the ABCB11 or the ABCB4 gene can increase a woman's likelihood of developing intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Susceptibility to intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing the disorder.
Methemoglobinemia, beta-globin type is a condition that affects the function of red blood cells.
The incidence of methemoglobinemia, beta-globin type is unknown.
Methemoglobinemia, beta-globin type is caused by mutations in the HBB gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Glucose-galactose malabsorption is a condition in which the cells lining the intestine cannot take in the sugars glucose and galactose, which prevents proper digestion of these molecules and larger molecules made from them.
Glucose-galactose malabsorption is a rare disorder; only a few hundred cases have been identified worldwide.
Mutations in the SLC5A1 gene cause glucose-galactose malabsorption.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Fibronectin glomerulopathy is a kidney disease that usually develops between early and mid-adulthood but can occur at any age.
Fibronectin glomerulopathy is likely a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Fibronectin glomerulopathy can be caused by mutations in the FN1 gene.

When fibronectin glomerulopathy is caused by mutations in the FN1 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is a condition that affects the development of blood vessels, soft tissues, and bones.
Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is estimated to affect at least 1 in 100,000 people worldwide.
The cause of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is unknown.
Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is almost always sporadic, which means that it occurs in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Aarskog-Scott syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of many parts of the body.
Aarskog-Scott syndrome is believed to be a rare disorder; however, its prevalence is unknown because mildly affected people are often not diagnosed.
Mutations in the FGD1 gene cause some cases of Aarskog-Scott syndrome.
Aarskog-Scott syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Fibrochondrogenesis is a very severe disorder of bone growth.
Fibrochondrogenesis appears to be a rare disorder.
Fibrochondrogenesis can result from mutations in the COL11A1 or COL11A2 gene.
Fibrochondrogenesis is generally inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Congenital hyperinsulinism is a condition that causes individuals to have abnormally high levels of insulin, which is a hormone that helps control blood sugar levels.
Congenital hyperinsulinism affects approximately 1 in 50,000 newborns.
Congenital hyperinsulinism is caused by mutations in genes that regulate the release (secretion) of insulin, which is produced by beta cells in the pancreas.
Congenital hyperinsulinism can have different inheritance patterns, usually depending on the form of the condition.
Floating-Harbor syndrome is a disorder involving short stature, slowing of the mineralization of the bones (delayed bone age), delayed speech development, and characteristic facial features.
Floating-Harbor syndrome is a rare disorder; only about 50 cases have been reported in the medical literature.
Floating-Harbor syndrome is caused by mutations in the SRCAP gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Dilated cardiomyopathy with ataxia (DCMA) syndrome is an inherited condition characterized by heart problems, movement difficulties, and other features affecting multiple body systems.
DCMA syndrome is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the DNAJC19 gene cause DCMA syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Sjgren syndrome is a disorder whose main features are dry eyes and a dry mouth.
Sjgren syndrome is a relatively common disorder; it occurs in 0.
