Sjgren syndrome is thought to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors; however, no associations between specific genetic changes and the development of Sjgren syndrome have been confirmed.
A predisposition to develop autoimmune disorders can be passed through generations in families.
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1 (SCA1) is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement.
SCA1 affects 1 to 2 per 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the ATXN1 gene cause SCA1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
MEGDEL syndrome is an inherited disorder that affects multiple body systems.
MEGDEL syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
MEGDEL syndrome is caused by mutations in the SERAC1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Spinal muscular atrophy with progressive myoclonic epilepsy (SMA-PME) is a neurological condition that causes muscle weakness and wasting (atrophy) and a combination of seizures and uncontrollable muscle jerks (myoclonic epilepsy).
SMA-PME is a rare disorder; approximately a dozen affected families have been described in the scientific literature.
SMA-PME is caused by mutations in the ASAH1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Coats plus syndrome is an inherited condition characterized by an eye disorder called Coats disease plus abnormalities of the brain, bones, gastrointestinal system, and other parts of the body.
Coats plus syndrome appears to be a rare disorder.
Coats plus syndrome results from mutations in the CTC1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Retinoblastoma is a rare type of eye cancer that usually develops in early childhood, typically before the age of 5.
Retinoblastoma is diagnosed in 250 to 350 children per year in the United States.
Mutations in the RB1 gene are responsible for most cases of retinoblastoma.
Researchers estimate that 40 percent of all retinoblastomas are germinal, which means that RB1 mutations occur in all of the body's cells, including reproductive cells (sperm or eggs).
Donohue syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by severe insulin resistance, a condition in which the body's tissues and organs do not respond properly to the hormone insulin.
Donohue syndrome is estimated to affect less than 1 per million people worldwide.
Donohue syndrome results from mutations in the INSR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Amelogenesis imperfecta is a disorder of tooth development.
The exact incidence of amelogenesis imperfecta is uncertain.
Mutations in the AMELX, ENAM, MMP20, and FAM83H genes can cause amelogenesis imperfecta.
Amelogenesis imperfecta can have different inheritance patterns depending on the gene that is altered.
Roberts syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by limb and facial abnormalities.
Roberts syndrome is a rare disorder; approximately 150 affected individuals have been reported.
Mutations in the ESCO2 gene cause Roberts syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial paroxysmal nonkinesigenic dyskinesia is a disorder of the nervous system that causes periods of involuntary movement.
Familial paroxysmal nonkinesigenic dyskinesia is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the PNKD gene cause familial paroxysmal nonkinesigenic dyskinesia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is typically sufficient to cause the disorder.
Wolfram syndrome is a condition that affects many of the body's systems.
The estimated prevalence of Wolfram syndrome type 1 is 1 in 500,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the WFS1 gene cause more than 90 percent of Wolfram syndrome type 1 cases.
When Wolfram syndrome is caused by mutations in the WFS1 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Preeclampsia is a complication of pregnancy in which affected women develop high blood pressure (hypertension) and can also have abnormally high levels of protein in their urine.
Preeclampsia is a common condition in all populations, occurring in 2 to 8 percent of pregnancies.
The specific causes of preeclampsia are not well understood.
Most cases of preeclampsia do not seem to be inherited.
Ollier disease is a disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas, which are noncancerous (benign) growths of cartilage that develop within the bones.
Ollier disease is estimated to occur in 1 in 100,000 people.
In most people with Ollier disease, the disorder is caused by mutations in the IDH1 or IDH2 gene.
Ollier disease is not inherited.
Autosomal recessive hypotrichosis is a condition that affects hair growth.
The worldwide prevalence of autosomal recessive hypotrichosis is unknown.
Autosomal recessive hypotrichosis can be caused by mutations in the LIPH, LPAR6, or DSG4 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Liddle syndrome is an inherited form of high blood pressure (hypertension).
Liddle syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Liddle syndrome is caused by mutations in the SCNN1B or SCNN1G gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Familial male-limited precocious puberty is a condition that causes early sexual development in males; females are not affected.
Familial male-limited precocious puberty is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Familial male-limited precocious puberty can be caused by mutations in the LHCGR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant, male-limited pattern, which means one copy of the altered LHCGR gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder in males.
Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (formerly called Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome) is a disorder of the nervous system.
The precise incidence of this condition is unknown.
Mutations in the PANK2 gene cause pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Xeroderma pigmentosum, which is commonly known as XP, is an inherited condition characterized by an extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight.
Xeroderma pigmentosum is a rare disorder; it is estimated to affect about 1 in 1 million people in the United States and Europe.
Xeroderma pigmentosum is caused by mutations in genes that are involved in repairing damaged DNA.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Transthyretin amyloidosis is a slowly progressive condition characterized by the buildup of abnormal deposits of a protein called amyloid (amyloidosis) in the body's organs and tissues.
The exact incidence of transthyretin amyloidosis is unknown.
Mutations in the TTR gene cause transthyretin amyloidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Enlarged parietal foramina is an inherited condition of impaired skull development.
The prevalence of enlarged parietal foramina is estimated to be 1 in 15,000 to 50,000 individuals.
Mutations in the ALX4 gene account for 60 percent of cases of enlarged parietal foramina and mutations in the MSX2 gene account for 40 percent of cases.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Benign essential blepharospasm is a condition characterized by abnormal blinking or spasms of the eyelids.
Benign essential blepharospasm affects an estimated 20,000 to 50,000 people in the United States.
The causes of benign essential blepharospasm are unknown, although the disorder likely results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of benign essential blepharospasm are sporadic, which means that the condition occurs in people with no history of this disorder or other forms of dystonia in their family.
Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder characterized by disruptions in the multistep process that breaks down the amino acid tyrosine, a building block of most proteins.
Worldwide, tyrosinemia type I affects about 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the FAH, TAT, and HPD genes can cause tyrosinemia types I, II, and III, respectively.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Muckle-Wells syndrome is a disorder characterized by periodic episodes of skin rash, fever, and joint pain.
Muckle-Wells syndrome is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the NLRP3 gene (also known as CIAS1) cause Muckle-Wells syndrome.
This condition is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
3MC syndrome is a disorder characterized by unusual facial features and problems affecting other tissues and organs of the body.
3MC syndrome is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
3MC syndrome is caused by mutations in the COLEC11 or MASP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) deficiency is a disorder that primarily affects movement, with symptoms that may range from mild to severe.
The prevalence of TH deficiency is unknown.
Mutations in the TH gene cause TH deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Treacher Collins syndrome is a condition that affects the development of bones and other tissues of the face.
This condition affects an estimated 1 in 50,000 people.
Mutations in the TCOF1, POLR1C, or POLR1D gene can cause Treacher Collins syndrome.

When Treacher Collins syndrome results from mutations in the TCOF1 or POLR1D gene, it is considered an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Fabry disease is an inherited disorder that results from the buildup of a particular type of fat, called globotriaosylceramide, in the body's cells.
Fabry disease affects an estimated 1 in 40,000 to 60,000 males.
Fabry disease is caused by mutations in the GLA gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Warfarin sensitivity is a condition in which individuals have a low tolerance for the drug warfarin.
The prevalence of warfarin sensitivity is unknown.
Many genes are involved in the metabolism of warfarin and in determining the drug's effects in the body.
The polymorphisms associated with this condition are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to result in warfarin sensitivity.
Apert syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis).
Apert syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 65,000 to 88,000 newborns.
Mutations in the FGFR2 gene cause Apert syndrome.
Apert syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Microphthalmia is an eye abnormality that arises before birth.
Microphthalmia occurs in approximately 1 in 10,000 individuals.
Microphthalmia may be caused by changes in many genes involved in the early development of the eye, most of which have not been identified.
Isolated microphthalmia is sometimes inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
STING-associated vasculopathy with onset in infancy (SAVI) is a disorder involving abnormal inflammation throughout the body, especially in the skin, blood vessels, and lungs.
The prevalence of this condition is unknown.
SAVI is caused by mutations in the TMEM173 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.
Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is believed to occur in approximately 1 in every 80,000 people.
Mutations in the OTC gene cause ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.
Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is an X-linked disorder.
Autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness is a disorder of the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color.
Autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness is likely a rare disease; however, its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in several genes can cause autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Primary ciliary dyskinesia is a disorder characterized by chronic respiratory tract infections, abnormally positioned internal organs, and the inability to have children (infertility).
Primary ciliary dyskinesia occurs in approximately 1 in 16,000 individuals.
Primary ciliary dyskinesia can result from mutations in many different genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Maple syrup urine disease is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to process certain protein building blocks (amino acids) properly.
Maple syrup urine disease affects an estimated 1 in 185,000 infants worldwide.
Mutations in the BCKDHA, BCKDHB, and DBT genes can cause maple syrup urine disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Short stature, hyperextensibility, hernia, ocular depression, Rieger anomaly, and teething delay, commonly known by the acronym SHORT syndrome, is a rare disorder that affects many parts of the body.
SHORT syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
SHORT syndrome results from mutations in the PIK3R1 gene.
SHORT syndrome has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered PIK3R1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Nakajo-Nishimura syndrome is an inherited condition that affects many parts of the body and has been described only in the Japanese population.
Nakajo-Nishimura syndrome appears to be rare and has been described only in the Japanese population.
Nakajo-Nishimura syndrome is caused by mutations in the PSMB8 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Hypermanganesemia with dystonia, polycythemia, and cirrhosis (HMDPC) is an inherited disorder in which excessive amounts of the element manganese accumulate in the body, particularly in the brain, liver, and blood (hypermanganesemia).
The prevalence of HMDPC is unknown.
Mutations in the SLC30A10 gene cause HMDPC.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina, which is often shortened to gyrate atrophy, is an inherited disorder characterized by progressive vision loss.
More than 150 individuals with gyrate atrophy have been identified; approximately one third are from Finland.
Mutations in the OAT gene cause gyrate atrophy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Bladder cancer is a disease in which certain cells in the bladder become abnormal and multiply without control or order.
In the United States, bladder cancer is the fourth most common type of cancer in men and the ninth most common cancer in women.
As with most cancers, the exact causes of bladder cancer are not known; however, many risk factors are associated with this disease.
Bladder cancer is typically not inherited.
Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase (CACT) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from using certain fats for energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
CACT deficiency is very rare; at least 30 cases have been reported.
Mutations in the SLC25A20 gene cause CACT deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Sitosterolemia is a condition in which fatty substances (lipids) from vegetable oils, nuts, and other plant-based foods accumulate in the blood and tissues.
Only 80 to 100 individuals with sitosterolemia have been described in the medical literature.
Sitosterolemia is caused by mutations in the ABCG5 or ABCG8 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Blepharophimosis, ptosis, and epicanthus inversus syndrome (BPES) is a condition that mainly affects development of the eyelids.
The prevalence of BPES is unknown.
Mutations in the FOXL2 gene cause BPES types I and II.
This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (commonly known as TRAPS) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever.
TRAPS has an estimated prevalence of one per million individuals; it is the second most common inherited recurrent fever syndrome, following a similar condition called familial Mediterranean fever.
TRAPS is caused by mutations in the TNFRSF1A gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Kawasaki disease is a sudden and time-limited (acute) illness that affects infants and young children.
In the United States and other Western countries, Kawasaki disease occurs in approximately 1 in 10,000 children under 5 each year.
The causes of Kawasaki disease are not well understood.
A predisposition to Kawasaki disease appears to be passed through generations in families, but the inheritance pattern is unknown.
Familial Mediterranean fever is an inherited condition characterized by recurrent episodes of painful inflammation in the abdomen, chest, or joints.
Familial Mediterranean fever primarily affects populations originating in the Mediterranean region, particularly people of Armenian, Arab, Turkish, or Jewish ancestry.
Mutations in the MEFV gene cause familial Mediterranean fever.
Familial Mediterranean fever is almost always inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the MEFV gene in each cell have mutations.
Ataxia with vitamin E deficiency is a disorder that impairs the body's ability to use vitamin E obtained from the diet.
Ataxia with vitamin E deficiency is a rare condition; however, its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the TTPA gene cause ataxia with vitamin E deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Achromatopsia is a condition characterized by a partial or total absence of color vision.
Achromatopsia affects an estimated 1 in 30,000 people worldwide.
Achromatopsia results from changes in one of several genes: CNGA3, CNGB3, GNAT2, PDE6C, or PDE6H.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Epidermolysis bullosa with pyloric atresia (EB-PA) is a condition that affects the skin and digestive tract.
EB-PA appears to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
EB-PA can be caused by mutations in the ITGA6, ITGB4, and PLEC genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Warsaw breakage syndrome is a condition that can cause multiple abnormalities.
Warsaw breakage syndrome is a rare condition; at least four cases have been described in the medical literature.
Mutations in the DDX11 gene cause Warsaw breakage syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Carpenter syndrome is a condition characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis), abnormalities of the fingers and toes, and other developmental problems.
Carpenter syndrome is thought to be a rare condition; approximately 70 cases have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the RAB23 or MEGF8 gene cause Carpenter syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Potocki-Shaffer syndrome is a disorder that affects development of the bones, nerve cells in the brain, and other tissues.
Potocki-Shaffer syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Potocki-Shaffer syndrome (also known as proximal 11p deletion syndrome) is caused by a deletion of genetic material from the short (p) arm of chromosome 11 at a position designated 11p11.
Potocki-Shaffer syndrome follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, which means a deletion of genetic material from one copy of chromosome 11 is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a group of genetic disorders that mainly affect the bones.
This condition affects an estimated 6 to 7 per 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the COL1A1, COL1A2, CRTAP, and P3H1 genes cause osteogenesis imperfecta.
Most cases of osteogenesis imperfecta have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.
Lung cancer is a disease in which certain cells in the lungs become abnormal and multiply uncontrollably to form a tumor.
In the United States, it is estimated that more than 221,000 people develop lung cancer each year.
Cancers occur when genetic mutations build up in critical genes, specifically those that control cell growth and division or the repair of damaged DNA.
Most cases of lung cancer are not related to inherited gene changes.
Cerebral autosomal recessive arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy, commonly known as CARASIL, is an inherited condition that causes stroke and other impairments.
CARASIL appears to be a rare condition.
CARASIL is caused by mutations in the HTRA1 gene.
As its name suggests, this condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Galactosialidosis is a condition that affects many areas of the body.
The prevalence of galactosialidosis is unknown; more than 100 cases have been reported.
Mutations in the CTSA gene cause all forms of galactosialidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type IE (HSAN IE) is a disorder that affects the nervous system.
HSAN IE is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
HSAN IE is caused by mutations in the DNMT1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

CAV3-related distal myopathy is one form of distal myopathy, a group of disorders characterized by weakness and loss of function affecting the muscles farthest from the center of the body (distal muscles), such as those of the hands and feet.
The prevalence of CAV3-related distal myopathy is unknown.
CAV3-related distal myopathy is part of a group of conditions called caveolinopathies, which are muscle disorders caused by mutations in the CAV3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Galactosemia is a disorder that affects how the body processes a simple sugar called galactose.
Classic galactosemia occurs in 1 in 30,000 to 60,000 newborns.
Mutations in the GALT, GALK1, and GALE genes cause galactosemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Erdheim-Chester disease is a rare disorder characterized by histiocytosis, a condition in which the immune system produces excess quantities of cells called histiocytes.
Erdheim-Chester disease is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
More than half of people with Erdheim-Chester disease have a specific mutation in the BRAF gene.
This condition is not inherited.
The Maat-Kievit-Brunner type of Ohdo syndrome is a rare condition characterized by intellectual disability and distinctive facial features.
The Maat-Kievit-Brunner type of Ohdo syndrome is a very rare condition, with only a few affected individuals reported in the medical literature.
The Maat-Kievit-Brunner type of Ohdo syndrome results from mutations in the MED12 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
As its name suggests, a Huntington disease-like (HDL) syndrome is a condition that resembles Huntington disease.
Overall, HDL syndromes are rare.
In about one percent of people with the characteristic features of Huntington disease, no mutation in the HD gene has been identified.
HDL1, HDL2, and HDL4 are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is a condition that affects the lungs, the kidneys, and the lymphatic system.
Sporadic LAM is estimated to occur in 2 to 5 per million women worldwide.
Mutations in the TSC1 gene or, more commonly, the TSC2 gene, cause LAM.
Sporadic LAM is not inherited.
VACTERL association is a disorder that affects many body systems.
VACTERL association occurs in 1 in 10,000 to 40,000 newborns.
VACTERL association is a complex condition that may have different causes in different people.
Most cases of VACTERL association are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Age-related macular degeneration is an eye disease that is a leading cause of vision loss in older people in developed countries.
Age-related macular degeneration has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 2,000 people in the United States and other developed countries.
Age-related macular degeneration results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Age-related macular degeneration usually does not have a clear-cut pattern of inheritance, although the condition appears to run in families in some cases.
Propionic acidemia is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to process certain parts of proteins and lipids (fats) properly.
Propionic acidemia affects about 1 in 100,000 people in the United States.
Mutations in the PCCA and PCCB genes cause propionic acidemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Early-onset primary dystonia is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement, typically beginning in childhood.
Early-onset primary dystonia is among the most common forms of childhood dystonia.
A particular mutation in the TOR1A gene (also known as DYT1) is responsible for most cases of early-onset primary dystonia.
Mutations in the TOR1A gene are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one of the two copies of the gene is altered in each cell.
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is one of a group of genetic conditions called epidermolysis bullosa that cause the skin to be very fragile and to blister easily.
The exact prevalence of epidermolysis bullosa simplex is unknown, but this condition is estimated to affect 1 in 30,000 to 50,000 people.
The four major types of epidermolysis bullosa simplex can result from mutations in either the KRT5 or KRT14 gene.
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Fatty acid hydroxylase-associated neurodegeneration (FAHN) is a progressive disorder of the nervous system (neurodegeneration) characterized by problems with movement and vision that begin during childhood or adolescence.
FAHN is a rare disorder; only a few dozen cases have been reported.
Mutations in the FA2H gene cause FAHN.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic disorder that affects the digestive system.
Ulcerative colitis is most common in North America and Western Europe; however the prevalence is increasing in other regions.
A variety of genetic and environmental factors are likely involved in the development of ulcerative colitis.
The inheritance pattern of ulcerative colitis is unknown because many genetic and environmental factors are likely to be involved.
Hereditary pancreatitis is a genetic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis).
Hereditary pancreatitis is thought to be a rare condition.
Mutations in the PRSS1 gene cause most cases of hereditary pancreatitis.

When hereditary pancreatitis is caused by mutations in the PRSS1 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an inherited disorder that may cause lung disease and liver disease.
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency occurs worldwide, but its prevalence varies by population.
Mutations in the SERPINA1 gene cause alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal codominant pattern.
Spastic paraplegia type 4 is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
The prevalence of spastic paraplegia type 4 is estimated to be 2 to 6 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the SPAST gene cause spastic paraplegia type 4.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Marinesco-Sjgren syndrome is a condition that has a variety of signs and symptoms affecting many tissues.
Marinesco-Sjgren syndrome appears to be a rare condition.
Mutations in the SIL1 gene cause Marinesco-Sjgren syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked adrenal hypoplasia congenita is a disorder that mainly affects males.
X-linked adrenal hypoplasia congenita is estimated to affect 1 in 12,500 newborns.
Mutations in the NR0B1 gene cause X-linked adrenal hypoplasia congenita.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Prothrombin deficiency is a bleeding disorder that slows the blood clotting process.
Prothrombin deficiency is very rare; it is estimated to affect 1 in 2 million people in the general population.
Mutations in the F2 gene cause prothrombin deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mucopolysaccharidosis type IV (MPS IV), also known as Morquio syndrome, is a progressive condition that mainly affects the skeleton.
The exact prevalence of MPS IV is unknown, although it is estimated to occur in 1 in 200,000 to 300,000 individuals.
Mutations in the GALNS and GLB1 genes cause MPS IV.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Otopalatodigital syndrome type 2 is a disorder involving abnormalities in skeletal development and other health problems.
Otopalatodigital syndrome type 2 is a rare disorder, affecting fewer than 1 in every 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the FLNA gene cause otopalatodigital syndrome type 2.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Sialic acid storage disease is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
Sialic acid storage disease is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the SLC17A5 gene cause all forms of sialic acid storage disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial dilated cardiomyopathy is a genetic form of heart disease.
It is estimated that 750,000 people in the United States have dilated cardiomyopathy; roughly half of these cases are familial.
Mutations in more than 30 genes have been found to cause familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Familial dilated cardiomyopathy has different inheritance patterns depending on the gene involved.
Retinal arterial macroaneurysm with supravalvular pulmonic stenosis (RAMSVPS) is a disorder that affects blood vessels in the eyes and heart.
RAMSVPS is a rare disorder.
RAMSVPS is caused by a mutation in the IGFBP7 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Oral-facial-digital syndrome is actually a group of related conditions that affect the development of the oral cavity (the mouth and teeth), facial features, and digits (fingers and toes).
Oral-facial-digital syndrome has an estimated incidence of 1 in 50,000 to 250,000 newborns.
Only one gene, OFD1, has been associated with oral-facial-digital syndrome.
Oral-facial-digital syndrome type I is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Congenital hemidysplasia with ichthyosiform erythroderma and limb defects, more commonly known by the acronym CHILD syndrome, is a condition that affects the development of several parts of the body.
CHILD syndrome is a rare disorder; it has been reported in about 60 people worldwide.
Mutations in the NSDHL gene cause CHILD syndrome.
This condition has an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is a disorder that results in the development of multiple abnormalities in the blood vessels.

The incidence of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is difficult to determine because the severity of symptoms can vary widely and some symptoms, such as frequent nosebleeds, are common in the general population.
Mutations in the ACVRL1, ENG, and SMAD4 genes cause hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Mitochondrial membrane protein-associated neurodegeneration (MPAN) is a disorder of the nervous system.
MPAN is a rare condition that is estimated to affect less than 1 in 1 million people.
Mutations in the C19orf12 gene cause MPAN.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

T-cell immunodeficiency, congenital alopecia, and nail dystrophy is a type of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which is a group of disorders characterized by an almost total lack of immune protection from foreign invaders such as bacteria and viruses.
T-cell immunodeficiency, congenital alopecia, and nail dystrophy is a rare disorder.
T-cell immunodeficiency, congenital alopecia, and nail dystrophy results from mutations in the FOXN1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome is one of the most severe of a group of conditions called the POLG-related disorders.
The prevalence of Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome is approximately 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome is caused by mutations in the POLG gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked sideroblastic anemia and ataxia is a rare condition characterized by a blood disorder called sideroblastic anemia and movement problems known as ataxia.
X-linked sideroblastic anemia and ataxia is a rare disorder; only a few affected families have been reported.
Mutations in the ABCB7 gene cause X-linked sideroblastic anemia and ataxia.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.

Pulmonary arterial hypertension is a progressive disorder characterized by abnormally high blood pressure (hypertension) in the pulmonary artery, the blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to the lungs.
In the United States, about 1,000 new cases of pulmonary arterial hypertension are diagnosed each year.
Mutations in the BMPR2 gene are the most common genetic cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
Pulmonary arterial hypertension is usually sporadic, which means it occurs in individuals with no known family history of the disorder.
Systemic scleroderma is an autoimmune disorder that affects the skin and internal organs.
The prevalence of systemic scleroderma is estimated to range from 50 to 300 cases per 1 million people.
Researchers have identified variations in several genes that may influence the risk of developing systemic scleroderma.
Most cases of systemic scleroderma are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Denys-Drash syndrome is a condition that affects the kidneys and genitalia.
The prevalence of Denys-Drash syndrome is unknown; at least 150 affected individuals have been reported in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the WT1 gene cause Denys-Drash syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Congenital insensitivity to pain is a condition that inhibits the ability to perceive physical pain.
Congenital insensitivity to pain is a rare condition; about 20 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the SCN9A gene cause congenital insensitivity to pain.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) is a condition that affects many of the body's systems, particularly the brain and nervous system (encephalo-) and muscles (myopathy).
The exact incidence of MELAS is unknown.
MELAS can result from mutations in one of several genes, including MT-ND1, MT-ND5, MT-TH, MT-TL1, and MT-TV.
This condition is inherited in a mitochondrial pattern, which is also known as maternal inheritance.
TK2-related mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, myopathic form (TK2-MDS) is an inherited condition that causes progressive muscle weakness (myopathy).
The prevalence of TK2-MDS is unknown.
As the condition name suggests, mutations in the TK2 gene cause TK2-MDS.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Brooke-Spiegler syndrome is a condition involving multiple skin tumors that develop from structures associated with the skin (skin appendages), such as sweat glands and hair follicles.
Brooke-Spiegler syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Brooke-Spiegler syndrome is caused by mutations in the CYLD gene.
Susceptibility to Brooke-Spiegler syndrome has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell increases the risk of developing this condition.
Late-infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (NCL) is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
The prevalence of late-infantile NCL is unknown.
Mutations in the TPP1 gene cause most cases of late-infantile NCL.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ataxia neuropathy spectrum is part of a group of conditions called the POLG-related disorders.
The prevalence of ataxia neuropathy spectrum is unknown.
Ataxia neuropathy spectrum is caused by mutations in the POLG gene or, rarely, the C10orf2 gene.
Ataxia neuropathy spectrum can have different inheritance patterns depending on the associated gene.
Pilomatricoma, also known as pilomatrixoma, is a type of noncancerous (benign) skin tumor associated with hair follicles.
Pilomatricoma is an uncommon tumor.
Mutations in the CTNNB1 gene are found in almost all cases of isolated pilomatricoma.
Most people with isolated pilomatricoma do not have any other affected family members.
Tietz syndrome is a disorder characterized by profound hearing loss from birth, fair skin, and light-colored hair.
Tietz syndrome is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Tietz syndrome is caused by mutations in the MITF gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Alexander disease is a rare disorder of the nervous system.
The prevalence of Alexander disease is unknown.
Mutations in the GFAP gene cause Alexander disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Turner syndrome is a chromosomal condition that affects development in females.
This condition occurs in about 1 in 2,500 newborn girls worldwide, but it is much more common among pregnancies that do not survive to term (miscarriages and stillbirths).
Turner syndrome is related to the X chromosome, which is one of the two sex chromosomes.
Most cases of Turner syndrome are not inherited.
Auriculo-condylar syndrome is a condition that affects facial development, particularly development of the ears and lower jaw (mandible).
Auriculo-condylar syndrome appears to be a rare disorder.
Auriculo-condylar syndrome can be caused by mutations in either the GNAI3 or PLCB4 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is typically sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cold-induced sweating syndrome is characterized by problems with regulating body temperature and other abnormalities affecting many parts of the body.
Cold-induced sweating syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
About 90 percent of cases of cold-induced sweating syndrome and Crisponi syndrome result from mutations in the CRLF1 gene.
Cold-induced sweating syndrome is inherited in anautosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the CRLF1 or CLCF1 gene in each cell have mutations.
Chanarin-Dorfman syndrome is a condition in which fats (lipids) are stored abnormally in the body.
Chanarin-Dorfman syndrome is a rare condition; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the ABHD5 gene cause Chanarin-Dorfman syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Mitochondrial complex III deficiency is a genetic condition that can affect several parts of the body, including the brain, kidneys, liver, heart, and the muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
The prevalence of mitochondrial complex III deficiency is unknown, although the condition is thought to be rare.
Mitochondrial complex III deficiency can be caused by mutations in one of several genes.
Mitochondrial complex III deficiency is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Malignant migrating partial seizures of infancy (MMPSI) is a severe form of epilepsy that begins very early in life.
MMPSI is a rare condition.
The genetic cause of MMPSI is not fully known.
MMPSI is not inherited from a parent and does not run in families.
Lujan syndrome is a condition characterized by intellectual disability, behavioral problems, and certain physical features.
Lujan syndrome appears to be an uncommon condition, but its prevalence is unknown.
Lujan syndrome is caused by at least one mutation in the MED12 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic disease that causes inflammation in connective tissues, such as cartilage and the lining of blood vessels, which provide strength and flexibility to structures throughout the body.
For unknown reasons, in industrialized Western countries SLE has become 10 times more common over the past 50 years.
Normal variations (polymorphisms) in many genes can affect the risk of developing SLE, and in most cases multiple genetic factors are thought to be involved.
SLE and other autoimmune disorders tend to run in families, but the inheritance pattern is usually unknown.
SADDAN (severe achondroplasia with developmental delay and acanthosis nigricans) is a rare disorder of bone growth characterized by skeletal, brain, and skin abnormalities.
This disorder is very rare; it has been described in only a small number of individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene cause SADDAN.
SADDAN is considered an autosomal dominant disorder because one mutated copy of the FGFR3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.
Familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome is a condition that causes episodes of fever, skin rash, and joint pain after exposure to cold temperatures.
Familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome is a very rare condition, believed to have a prevalence of less than 1 per million people.
Mutations in the NLRP3 and NLRP12 genes cause familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern from an affected parent; one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Congenital hypothyroidism is a partial or complete loss of function of the thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) that affects infants from birth (congenital).
Congenital hypothyroidism affects an estimated 1 in 2,000 to 4,000 newborns.
Congenital hypothyroidism can be caused by a variety of factors, only some of which are genetic.
Most cases of congenital hypothyroidism are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome is a condition characterized by short stature, moderate to severe intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and broad thumbs and first toes.
This condition is uncommon; it occurs in an estimated 1 in 100,000 to 125,000 newborns.
Mutations in the CREBBP gene are responsible for some cases of Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome.
This condition is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Surfactant dysfunction is a lung disorder that causes breathing problems.
One type of surfactant dysfunction, SP-B deficiency, is estimated to occur in 1 in 1 million newborns worldwide.
Surfactant dysfunction is caused by mutations in one of several genes, including SFTPB, SFTPC, and ABCA3.
Surfactant dysfunction can have different inheritance patterns depending on its genetic cause.
Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate-dependent epilepsy is a condition that involves seizures beginning soon after birth or, in some cases, before birth.
Pyridoxal 5'-phosphate-dependent epilepsy is a rare condition; approximately 14 cases have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the PNPO gene cause pyridoxal 5'-phosphate-dependent epilepsy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Anderson-Tawil syndrome is a disorder that causes episodes of muscle weakness (periodic paralysis), changes in heart rhythm (arrhythmia), and developmental abnormalities.
Andersen-Tawil syndrome is a rare genetic disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the KCNJ2 gene cause Andersen-Tawil syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Manitoba oculotrichoanal syndrome is a condition involving several characteristic physical features, particularly affecting the eyes (oculo-), hair (tricho-), and anus (-anal).
Manitoba oculotrichoanal syndrome is estimated to occur in 2 to 6 in 1,000 people in a small isolated Ojibway-Cree community in northern Manitoba, Canada.
Manitoba oculotrichoanal syndrome is caused by mutations in the FREM1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Isolated ectopia lentis is a condition that affects the eyes, specifically the positioning of the lens.
The prevalence of isolated ectopia lentis is unknown.
Mutations in the FBN1 or ADAMTSL4 gene cause isolated ectopia lentis.

When isolated ectopia lentis is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Tuberous sclerosis complex is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous noncancerous (benign) tumors in many parts of the body.
Tuberous sclerosis complex affects about 1 in 6,000 people.
Mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 gene can cause tuberous sclerosis complex.

Tuberous sclerosis complex has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing tumors and other problems with development.
Factor V Leiden thrombophilia is an inherited disorder of blood clotting.
Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited form of thrombophilia.
A particular mutation in the F5 gene causes factor V Leiden thrombophilia.
The chance of developing an abnormal blood clot depends on whether a person has one or two copies of the factor V Leiden mutation in each cell.
Chronic granulomatous disease is a disorder that causes the immune system to malfunction, resulting in a form of immunodeficiency.
Chronic granulomatous disease is estimated to occur in 1 in 200,000 to 250,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the CYBA, CYBB, NCF1, NCF2, or NCF4 gene can cause chronic granulomatous disease.
When chronic granulomatous disease is caused by mutations in the CYBB gene, the condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Osteoporosis-pseudoglioma syndrome is a rare condition characterized by severe thinning of the bones (osteoporosis) and eye abnormalities that lead to vision loss.
Osteoporosis-pseudoglioma syndrome is a rare disorder that occurs in approximately 1 in 2 million people.
Osteoporosis-pseudoglioma syndrome is caused by mutations in the LRP5 gene.
Osteoporosis-pseudoglioma syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the LRP5 gene in each cell have mutations.
15q24 microdeletion is a chromosomal change in which a small piece of chromosome 15 is deleted in each cell.
This condition is very rare; only a few dozen affected individuals have been identified.
People with a 15q24 microdeletion are missing between 1.
The identified cases of 15q24 microdeletion have occurred in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Branchio-oculo-facial syndrome is a condition that affects development before birth, particularly of structures in the face and neck.
Branchio-oculo-facial syndrome is a rare condition, although the prevalence is unknown.
Branchio-oculo-facial syndrome is caused by mutations in the TFAP2A gene.
Branchio-oculo-facial syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pallister-Hall syndrome is a disorder that affects the development of many parts of the body.
This condition is very rare; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the GLI3 gene cause Pallister-Hall syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles is a disorder that affects the muscles that surround the eyes.
CFEOM1 is the most common form of congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles, affecting at least 1 in 230,000 people.
CFEOM1 and rare cases of CFEOM3 result from mutations in the KIF21A gene.
The different types of congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles have different patterns of inheritance.
X-linked dystonia-parkinsonism is a movement disorder that has been found only in people of Filipino descent.
X-linked dystonia-parkinsonism has been reported in more than 500 people of Filipino descent, although it is likely that many more Filipinos are affected.
Mutations in and near the TAF1 gene can cause X-linked dystonia-parkinsonism.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Osteopetrosis is a bone disease that makes bones abnormally dense and prone to breakage (fracture).
Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is the most common form of the disorder, affecting about 1 in 20,000 people.
Mutations in at least nine genes cause the various types of osteopetrosis.
Osteopetrosis can have several different patterns of inheritance.
21-hydroxylase deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects the adrenal glands.
The classic forms of 21-hydroxylase deficiency occur in 1 in 15,000 newborns.
Mutations in the CYP21A2 gene cause 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Complement component 2 deficiency is a disorder that causes the immune system to malfunction, resulting in a form of immunodeficiency.
In Western countries, complement component 2 deficiency is estimated to affect 1 in 20,000 individuals; its prevalence in other areas of the world is unknown.
Complement component 2 deficiency is caused by mutations in the C2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Darier disease is a skin condition characterized by wart-like blemishes on the body.
The worldwide prevalence of Darier disease is unknown.
Mutations in the ATP2A2 gene cause Darier disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Hereditary myopathy with early respiratory failure (HMERF) is an inherited muscle disease that predominantly affects muscles close to the center of the body (proximal muscles) and muscles that are needed for breathing.
HMERF is a rare condition.
HMERF can be caused by a mutation in the TTN gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cyclic vomiting syndrome is a disorder that causes recurrent episodes of nausea, vomiting, and tiredness (lethargy).
The exact prevalence of cyclic vomiting syndrome is unknown; estimates range from 4 to 2,000 per 100,000 children.
Although the causes of cyclic vomiting syndrome have yet to be determined, researchers have proposed several factors that may contribute to the disorder.
In most cases of cyclic vomiting syndrome, affected people have no known history of the disorder in their family.
Congenital dyserythropoietic anemia (CDA) is an inherited blood disorder that affects the development of red blood cells.
Several hundred cases of CDA have been reported worldwide.
CDA type I usually results from mutations in the CDAN1 gene.
The inheritance pattern of CDA depends on the type of the disorder.
MyD88 deficiency is an inherited disorder of the immune system (primary immunodeficiency).
The prevalence of MyD88 deficiency is unknown.

MyD88 deficiency is caused by mutations in the MYD88 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein that plays an important role in stimulating the immune system to respond to bacterial infection.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an inherited disorder characterized by the accumulation of fats called sulfatides in cells.
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is reported to occur in 1 in 40,000 to 160,000 individuals worldwide.
Most individuals with metachromatic leukodystrophy have mutations in the ARSA gene, which provides instructions for making the enzyme arylsulfatase A.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Kleefstra syndrome is a disorder that involves many parts of the body.
The prevalence of Kleefstra syndrome is unknown.
Kleefstra syndrome is caused by the loss of the EHMT1 gene or by mutations that disable its function.

The inheritance of Kleefstra syndrome is considered to be autosomal dominant because a deletion in one copy of chromosome 9 in each cell or a mutation in one copy of the EHMT1 gene is sufficient to cause the condition.
Weill-Marchesani syndrome is a disorder of connective tissue.
Weill-Marchesani syndrome appears to be rare; it has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 100,000 people.
Mutations in the ADAMTS10 and FBN1 genes can cause Weill-Marchesani syndrome.
Weill-Marchesani syndrome can be inherited in either an autosomal recessive or an autosomal dominant pattern.
Hypochondroplasia is a form of short-limbed dwarfism.
The incidence of hypochondroplasia is unknown.
About 70 percent of all cases of hypochondroplasia are caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene.
Hypochondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Noonan syndrome is a condition that affects many areas of the body.
Noonan syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 1,000 to 2,500 people.
Mutations in the PTPN11, SOS1, RAF1, KRAS, NRAS and BRAF genes cause Noonan syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cleidocranial dysplasia is a condition that primarily affects the development of the bones and teeth.
Cleidocranial dysplasia occurs in approximately 1 per million individuals worldwide.
The RUNX2 gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in bone and cartilage development and maintenance.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Fragile X-associated primary ovarian insufficiency (FXPOI) is a condition that affects women and is characterized by reduced function of the ovaries.
An estimated 1 in 200 females has the genetic change that leads to FXPOI, although only about a quarter of them develop the condition.
Mutations in the FMR1 gene increase a woman's risk of developing FXPOI.
An increased risk of developing FXPOI is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Critical congenital heart disease (CCHD) is a term that refers to a group of serious heart defects that are present from birth.
Heart defects are the most common type of birth defect, accounting for more than 30 percent of all infant deaths due to birth defects.
In most cases, the cause of CCHD is unknown.
Most cases of CCHD are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Glycogen storage disease type VII (GSDVII) is an inherited disorder caused by an inability to break down a complex sugar called glycogen in muscle cells.
GSDVII is thought to be a rare condition; more than 100 cases have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the PFKM gene cause GSDVII.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mucopolysaccharidosis type VII (MPS VII), also known as Sly syndrome, is a progressive condition that affects most tissues and organs.
The exact incidence of MPS VII is unknown, although it is estimated to occur in 1 in 250,000 newborns.
Mutations in the GUSB gene cause MPS VII.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Task-specific focal dystonia is a movement disorder that interferes with the performance of particular tasks, such as writing, playing a musical instrument, or participating in a sport.
Task-specific focal dystonia affects an estimated 7 to 69 per million people in the general population.
The causes of task-specific focal dystonia are unknown, although the disorder likely results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of task-specific focal dystonia are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT I) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from using certain fats for energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
CPT I deficiency is a rare disorder; fewer than 50 affected individuals have been identified.
Mutations in the CPT1A gene cause CPT I deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Protein C deficiency is a disorder that increases the risk of developing abnormal blood clots; the condition can be mild or severe.
Mild protein C deficiency affects approximately 1 in 500 individuals.
Protein C deficiency is caused by mutations in the PROC gene.
Protein C deficiency is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one altered copy of the PROC gene in each cell is sufficient to cause mild protein C deficiency.
X-linked chondrodysplasia punctata 1 is a disorder of cartilage and bone development that occurs almost exclusively in males.
The prevalence of X-linked chondrodysplasia punctata 1 is unknown.
X-linked chondrodysplasia punctata 1 is caused by genetic changes involving the ARSE gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Warfarin resistance is a condition in which individuals have a high tolerance for the drug warfarin.
Warfarin resistance is thought to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Many genes are involved in the metabolism of warfarin and in determining the drug's effects in the body.
The polymorphisms associated with this condition are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to result in warfarin resistance.
Feingold syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Feingold syndrome appears to be a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the MYCN gene cause Feingold syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hypercholesterolemia is a condition characterized by very high levels of cholesterol in the blood.
More than 34 million American adults have elevated blood cholesterol levels (higher than 240 mg/dL).
Mutations in the APOB, LDLR, LDLRAP1, and PCSK9 genes cause hypercholesterolemia.
Most cases of high cholesterol are not caused by a single inherited condition, but result from a combination of lifestyle choices and the effects of variations in many genes.
Mucopolysaccharidosis type III (MPS III), also known as Sanfilippo syndrome, is a progressive disorder that mainly affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system).
MPS III is the most common type of mucopolysaccharidosis; the estimated incidence of all four types combined is 1 in 70,000 newborns.
Mutations in the GNS, HGSNAT, NAGLU, and SGSH genes cause MPS III.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
GLUT1 deficiency syndrome is a disorder affecting the nervous system that can have a variety of neurological signs and symptoms.
GLUT1 deficiency syndrome is a rare disorder.
GLUT1 deficiency syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC2A1 gene.
This condition is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Opitz G/BBB syndrome is a genetic condition that causes several abnormalities along the midline of the body.
X-linked Opitz G/BBB syndrome is thought to affect 1 in 10,000 to 50,000 males, although it is likely that this condition is underdiagnosed.
X-linked Opitz G/BBB syndrome is caused by mutations in the MID1 gene.
When caused by mutations in the MID1 gene, Opitz G/BBB syndrome has an X-linked pattern of inheritance.
Stickler syndrome is a group of hereditary conditions characterized by a distinctive facial appearance, eye abnormalities, hearing loss, and joint problems.
Stickler syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 7,500 to 9,000 newborns.
Mutations in several genes cause the different types of Stickler syndrome.
Stickler syndrome types I, II, and III are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Mucolipidosis III alpha/beta is a slowly progressive disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Mucolipidosis III alpha/beta is a rare disorder, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the GNPTAB gene cause mucolipidosis III alpha/beta.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hashimoto thyroiditis is a condition that affects the function of the thyroid, which is a butterfly-shaped gland in the lower neck.
Hashimoto thyroiditis affects 1 to 2 percent of people in the United States.
Hashimoto thyroiditis is thought to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
The inheritance pattern of Hashimoto thyroiditis is unclear because many genetic and environmental factors appear to be involved.
Cornelia de Lange syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Although the exact incidence is unknown, Cornelia de Lange syndrome likely affects 1 in 10,000 to 30,000 newborns.
Cornelia de Lange syndrome can result from mutations in at least five genes: NIPBL, SMC1A, HDAC8, RAD21, and SMC3.
When Cornelia de Lange syndrome is caused by mutations in the NIPBL, RAD21, or SMC3 gene, the condition is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is a type of organic acid disorder in which the body is unable to process proteins properly.
2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is a rare disorder; its actual incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the ACADSB gene cause 2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body, especially the eyes.
The prevalence of Kearns-Sayre syndrome is approximately 1 to 3 per 100,000 individuals.
Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a condition caused by defects in mitochondria, which are structures within cells that use oxygen to convert the energy from food into a form cells can use.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from mutations in the body's cells that occur after conception.
Megalencephaly-capillary malformation syndrome (MCAP) is a disorder characterized by overgrowth of several tissues in the body.
The prevalence of MCAP is unknown.
MCAP is caused by mutations in the PIK3CA gene, which provides instructions for making the p110 alpha (p110) protein.
MCAP is not inherited from a parent and does not run in families.
Lissencephaly with cerebellar hypoplasia (LCH) affects brain development, resulting in the brain having a smooth appearance (lissencephaly) instead of its normal folds and grooves.
LCH is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
LCH can be caused by mutations in the RELN or TUBA1A gene.
When LCH is caused by mutations in the RELN gene, the condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 20,000 to 60,000 newborns.
Mutations in the DHCR7 gene cause Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Monilethrix is a condition that affects hair growth.
The prevalence of monilethrix is unknown.
Monilethrix is caused by mutations in one of several genes.
Monilethrix can have multiple patterns of inheritance.
Bloom syndrome is an inherited disorder characterized by short stature, a skin rash that develops after exposure to the sun, and a greatly increased risk of cancer.
Bloom syndrome is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the BLM gene cause Bloom syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myostatin-related muscle hypertrophy is a rare condition characterized by reduced body fat and increased muscle size.
The prevalence of this condition is unknown.
Mutations in the MSTN gene cause myostatin-related muscle hypertrophy.
Myostatin-related muscle hypertrophy has a pattern of inheritance known as incomplete autosomal dominance.
Autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome (AD-HIES), also known as Job syndrome, is a condition that affects several body systems, particularly the immune system.
This condition is rare, affecting fewer than 1 per million people.
Mutations in the STAT3 gene cause most cases of AD-HIES.
AD-HIES has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Cohen syndrome is an inherited disorder that affects many parts of the body and is characterized by developmental delay, intellectual disability, small head size (microcephaly), and weak muscle tone (hypotonia).
The exact incidence of Cohen syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the VPS13B gene (frequently called the COH1 gene) cause Cohen syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is an inherited form of vision loss.
The prevalence of LHON in most populations is unknown.
Mutations in the MT-ND1, MT-ND4, MT-ND4L, or MT-ND6 gene can cause LHON.
LHON has a mitochondrial pattern of inheritance, which is also known as maternal inheritance.
Nemaline myopathy is a disorder that primarily affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
Nemaline myopathy has an estimated incidence of 1 in 50,000 individuals.
Mutations in one of many genes can cause nemaline myopathy.
Nemaline myopathy is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a condition characterized by jaundice, which is a yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes.
Although Dubin-Johnson syndrome occurs in people of all ethnic backgrounds, it is more common among Iranian and Moroccan Jews living in Israel.
Dubin-Johnson syndrome is caused by mutations in the ABCC2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
46,XX testicular disorder of sex development is a condition in which individuals with two X chromosomes in each cell, the pattern normally found in females, have a male appearance.
Approximately 1 in 20,000 individuals with a male appearance have 46,XX testicular disorder.
People normally have 46 chromosomes in each cell.
SRY-positive 46,XX testicular disorder of sex development is almost never inherited.
Moyamoya disease is a disorder of blood vessels in the brain, specifically the internal carotid arteries and the arteries that branch from them.
Moyamoya disease was first identified in Japan, where it is most prevalent, affecting about 5 in 100,000 individuals.
The genetics of moyamoya disease are not well understood.

Up to 15 percent of Japanese people with moyamoya disease have one or more family members with the condition, indicating that the condition can be passed through generations in families; however, the inheritance pattern is unknown.
Vitelliform macular dystrophy is a genetic eye disorder that can cause progressive vision loss.
Vitelliform macular dystrophy is a rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the BEST1 and PRPH2 genes cause vitelliform macular dystrophy.
Best disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Methylmalonic acidemia with homocystinuria is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to properly process protein building blocks (amino acids), certain fats (lipids), and a waxy fat-like substance called cholesterol.
The most common form of the condition, called methylmalonic acidemia with homocystinuria, cblC type, is estimated to affect 1 in 200,000 newborns worldwide.
Methylmalonic acidemia with homocystinuria can be caused by mutations in one of several genes: MMACHC, MMADHC, LMBRD1, ABCD4, or HCFC1.
Methylmalonic acidemia with homocystinuria is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
2q37 deletion syndrome is a condition that can affect many parts of the body.
2q37 deletion syndrome appears to be a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
2q37 deletion syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material from a specific region in the long (q) arm of chromosome 2.
Most cases of 2q37 deletion syndrome are not inherited.
Congenital mirror movement disorder is a condition in which intentional movements of one side of the body are mirrored by involuntary movements of the other side.
Congenital mirror movement disorder is a very rare disorder.
Congenital mirror movement disorder can be caused by mutations in the DCC or RAD51 gene; mutations in these genes account for a total of about 35 percent of cases.

In most cases, including those caused by mutations in the DCC or RAD51 gene, this condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Duane-radial ray syndrome is a disorder that affects the eyes and causes abnormalities of bones in the arms and hands.
Duane-radial ray syndrome is a rare condition whose prevalence is unknown.
Duane-radial ray syndrome results from mutations in the SALL4 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered SALL4 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Prion disease represents a group of conditions that affect the nervous system in humans and animals.
These disorders are very rare.
Between 10 and 15 percent of all cases of prion disease are caused by mutations in the PRNP gene.
Familial forms of prion disease are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered PRNP gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
X-linked myotubular myopathy is a condition that primarily affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles) and occurs almost exclusively in males.
The incidence of X-linked myotubular myopathy is estimated to be 1 in 50,000 newborn males worldwide.
Mutations in the MTM1 gene cause X-linked myotubular myopathy.
X-linked myotubular myopathy is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.

Hyperphosphatemic familial tumoral calcinosis (HFTC) is a condition characterized by an increase in the levels of phosphate in the blood (hyperphosphatemia) and abnormal deposits of phosphate and calcium (calcinosis) in the body's tissues.
The prevalence of HFTC is unknown, but it is thought to be a rare condition.
Mutations in the FGF23, GALNT3, or KL gene cause HFTC.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Frontometaphyseal dysplasia is a disorder involving abnormalities in skeletal development and other health problems.
Frontometaphyseal dysplasia is a rare disorder; only a few dozen cases have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the FLNA gene cause frontometaphyseal dysplasia.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

Mabry syndrome is a condition characterized by intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, increased levels of an enzyme called alkaline phosphatase in the blood (hyperphosphatasia), and other signs and symptoms.
Mabry syndrome is likely a rare condition, but its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the PIGV, PIGO, or PGAP2 gene cause Mabry syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Harlequin ichthyosis is a severe genetic disorder that mainly affects the skin.
Harlequin ichthyosis is very rare; its exact incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the ABCA12 gene cause harlequin ichthyosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Boomerang dysplasia is a disorder that affects the development of bones throughout the body.
Boomerang dysplasia is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the FLNB gene cause boomerang dysplasia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase deficiency is a severe condition that can affect several body systems.
Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase deficiency occurs in an estimated 1 in 35,000 to 48,000 individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent.
Mutations in the DLD gene cause dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disorder that affects the control of muscle movement.
Spinal muscular atrophy affects 1 in 6,000 to 1 in 10,000 people.
Mutations in the SMN1, UBA1, DYNC1H1, and VAPB genes cause spinal muscular atrophy.
Types I, II, III, and IV spinal muscular atrophy are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the SMN1 gene in each cell have mutations.
