Ankyloblepharon-ectodermal defects-cleft lip/palate (AEC) syndrome is a form of ectodermal dysplasia, a group of about 150 conditions characterized by abnormal development of ectodermal tissues including the skin, hair, nails, teeth, and sweat glands.
AEC syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
AEC syndrome is caused by mutations in the TP63 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy is a condition that involves seizures beginning in infancy or, in some cases, before birth.
Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy occurs in 1 in 100,000 to 700,000 individuals.
Mutations in the ALDH7A1 gene cause pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by abnormal immune system function (immune deficiency) and a reduced ability to form blood clots.
The estimated incidence of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is between 1 and 10 cases per million males worldwide; this condition is rarer in females.
Mutations in the WAS gene cause Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Short QT syndrome is a condition that can cause a disruption of the heart's normal rhythm (arrhythmia).
Short QT syndrome appears to be rare.
Mutations in the KCNH2, KCNJ2, and KCNQ1 genes can cause short QT syndrome.
Short QT syndrome appears to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Spinal muscular atrophy with respiratory distress type 1 (SMARD1) is an inherited condition that causes muscle weakness and respiratory failure typically beginning in infancy.
SMARD1 appears to be a rare condition, but its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the IGHMBP2 gene cause SMARD1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency is a condition that results in increased sensitivity to certain muscle relaxant drugs used during general anesthesia, called choline esters.
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency occurs in 1 in 3,200 to 1 in 5,000 people.
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency can be caused by mutations in the BCHE gene.
When due to genetic causes, this condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tourette syndrome is a complex disorder characterized by repetitive, sudden, and involuntary movements or noises called tics.
Although the exact incidence of Tourette syndrome is uncertain, it is estimated to affect 1 to 10 in 1,000 children.
A variety of genetic and environmental factors likely play a role in causing Tourette syndrome.
The inheritance pattern of Tourette syndrome is unclear.

Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOP) is a disorder in which muscle tissue and connective tissue such as tendons and ligaments are gradually replaced by bone (ossified), forming bone outside the skeleton (extra-skeletal or heterotopic bone) that constrains movement.
Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva is a very rare disorder, believed to occur in approximately 1 in 2 million people worldwide.
Mutations in the ACVR1 gene cause fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) deaminase deficiency is a condition that can affect the muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
AMP deaminase deficiency is one of the most common inherited muscle disorders in white populations, affecting 1 in 50 to 100 people.
Mutations in the AMPD1 gene cause AMP deaminase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Snyder-Robinson syndrome is a condition characterized by intellectual disability, muscle and bone abnormalities, and other problems with development.
Snyder-Robinson syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Snyder-Robinson syndrome results from mutations in the SMS gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is a rare disorder that causes blood clots (thrombi) to form in small blood vessels throughout the body.
The precise incidence of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is unknown.
Mutations in the ADAMTS13 gene cause the familial form of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
The familial form of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Autosomal dominant hypocalcemia is characterized by low levels of calcium in the blood (hypocalcemia).
The prevalence of autosomal dominant hypocalcemia is unknown.
Autosomal dominant hypocalcemia is primarily caused by mutations in the CASR gene; these cases are known as type 1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Progressive supranuclear palsy is a brain disorder that affects movement, vision, speech, and thinking ability (cognition).
The exact prevalence of progressive supranuclear palsy is unknown.
In most cases, the genetic cause of progressive supranuclear palsy is unknown.
Most cases of progressive supranuclear palsy are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
X-linked infantile nystagmus is a condition characterized by abnormal eye movements.
The incidence of all forms of infantile nystagmus is estimated to be 1 in 5,000 newborns; however, the precise incidence of X-linked infantile nystagmus is unknown.
Mutations in the FRMD7 gene cause X-linked infantile nystagmus.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Combined malonic and methylmalonic aciduria (CMAMMA) is a condition characterized by high levels of certain chemicals, known as malonic acid and methylmalonic acid, in the body.
CMAMMA appears to be a rare disease.
Mutations in the ACSF3 gene cause CMAMMA.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary fructose intolerance is a condition that affects a person's ability to digest the sugar fructose.
The incidence of hereditary fructose intolerance is estimated to be 1 in 20,000 to 30,000 individuals each year worldwide.
Mutations in the ALDOB gene cause hereditary fructose intolerance.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Greig cephalopolysyndactyly syndrome is a disorder that affects development of the limbs, head, and face.
This condition is very rare; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the GLI3 gene cause Greig cephalopolysyndactyly syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one altered or missing copy of the GLI3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
D-bifunctional protein deficiency is a disorder that causes deterioration of nervous system functions (neurodegeneration) beginning in infancy.
D-bifunctional protein deficiency is estimated to affect 1 in 100,000 newborns.
D-bifunctional protein deficiency is caused by mutations in the HSD17B4 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ornithine translocase deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.
Ornithine translocase deficiency is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the SLC25A15 gene cause ornithine translocase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked lymphoproliferative disease (XLP) is a disorder of the immune system and blood-forming cells that is found almost exclusively in males.
XLP1 is estimated to occur in about 1 per million males worldwide.
Mutations in the SH2D1A and XIAP genes cause XLP.
This condition is generally inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Metatropic dysplasia is a skeletal disorder characterized by short stature (dwarfism) with other skeletal abnormalities.
Metatropic dysplasia is a rare disease; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Metatropic dysplasia is caused by mutations in the TRPV4 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein that acts as a calcium channel.
Metatropic dysplasia is considered an autosomal dominant disorder because one mutated copy of the TRPV4 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.

DOLK-congenital disorder of glycosylation (DOLK-CDG, formerly known as congenital disorder of glycosylation type Im) is an inherited condition that often affects the heart but can also involve other body systems.
DOLK-CDG is likely a rare condition; at least 18 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
DOLK-CDG is caused by mutations in the DOLK gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a rare disorder that greatly increases the risk of developing several types of cancer, particularly in children and young adults.
The exact prevalence of Li-Fraumeni is unknown.
The CHEK2 and TP53 genes are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
Li-Fraumeni syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing cancer.

CASK-related intellectual disability is a disorder of brain development that has two main forms: microcephaly with pontine and cerebellar hypoplasia (MICPCH), and X-linked intellectual disability (XL-ID) with or without nystagmus.
The prevalence of CASK-related intellectual disability is unknown.
CASK-related intellectual disability, as its name suggests, is caused by mutations in the CASK gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy is a disorder characterized by muscle weakness and wasting (atrophy).
Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 20,000 people.
Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy is caused by genetic changes involving the long (q) arm of chromosome 4.
FSHD1 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the shortened D4Z4 region on a "permissive" chromosome 4 is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Paramyotonia congenita is a disorder that affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
Paramyotonia congenita is an uncommon disorder; it is estimated to affect fewer than 1 in 100,000 people.
Mutations in the SCN4A gene cause paramyotonia congenita.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Bowen-Conradi syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body and is usually fatal in infancy.
Bowen-Conradi syndrome is common in the Hutterite population in Canada and the United States; it occurs in approximately 1 per 355 newborns in all three Hutterite sects (leuts).
Bowen-Conradi syndrome is caused by a mutation in the EMG1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Paget disease of bone is a disorder that causes bones to grow larger and weaker than normal.
Classic Paget disease of bone occurs in approximately 1 percent of people older than 40 in the United States.
A combination of genetic and environmental factors likely play a role in causing Paget disease of bone.
In 15 to 40 percent of all cases of classic Paget disease of bone, the disorder has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
Mycosis fungoides is the most common form of a type of blood cancer called cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
Mycosis fungoides occurs in about 1 in 100,000 to 350,000 individuals.
The cause of mycosis fungoides is unknown.
The inheritance pattern of mycosis fungoides has not been determined.
Distal hereditary motor neuropathy, type V is a progressive disorder that affects nerve cells in the spinal cord.
The incidence of distal hereditary motor neuropathy, type V is unknown.
Mutations in the BSCL2 and GARS genes cause distal hereditary motor neuropathy, type V.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Muenke syndrome is a condition characterized by the premature closure of certain bones of the skull (craniosynostosis) during development, which affects the shape of the head and face.
Muenke syndrome occurs in about 1 in 30,000 newborns.
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene cause Muenke syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Gitelman syndrome is a kidney disorder that causes an imbalance of charged atoms (ions) in the body, including ions of potassium, magnesium, and calcium.
Gitelman syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 40,000 people worldwide.
Gitelman syndrome is usually caused by mutations in the SLC12A3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy, commonly known as DRPLA, is a progressive brain disorder that causes involuntary movements, mental and emotional problems, and a decline in thinking ability.
DRPLA is most common in the Japanese population, where it has an estimated incidence of 2 to 7 per million people.
DRPLA is caused by a mutation in the ATN1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Periventricular heterotopia is a condition in which nerve cells (neurons) do not migrate properly during the early development of the fetal brain, from about the 6th week to the 24th week of pregnancy.
Periventricular heterotopia is a rare condition.
Periventricular heterotopia is related to chromosome 5.
Periventricular heterotopia can have different inheritance patterns.
Spastic paraplegia type 3A is one of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.

Spastic paraplegia type 3A belongs to a subgroup of hereditary spastic paraplegias known as autosomal dominant hereditary spastic paraplegia, which has an estimated prevalence of 2 to 9 per 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the ATL1 gene cause spastic paraplegia type 3A.
Spastic paraplegia type 3A is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Sickle cell disease is a group of disorders that affects hemoglobin, the molecule in red blood cells that delivers oxygen to cells throughout the body.
Sickle cell disease affects millions of people worldwide.
Mutations in the HBB gene cause sickle cell disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Histiocytosis-lymphadenopathy plus syndrome (also known as SLC29A3 spectrum disorder) is a group of conditions with overlapping signs and symptoms that affect many parts of the body.
Histiocytosis-lymphadenopathy plus syndrome is a rare disorder, affecting approximately 100 individuals worldwide.
Histiocytosis-lymphadenopathy plus syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC29A3 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called equilibrative nucleoside transporter 3 (ENT3).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Distal myopathy 2 is a condition characterized by weakness of specific muscles that begins in adulthood.
The prevalence of distal myopathy 2 is unknown.
A mutation in the MATR3 gene has been identified in people with distal myopathy 2.
Distal myopathy 2 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered MATR3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Adenylosuccinate lyase deficiency is a neurological disorder that causes brain dysfunction (encephalopathy) leading to delayed development of mental and movement abilities (psychomotor delay), autistic behaviors that affect communication and social interaction, and seizures.
Adenylosuccinate lyase deficiency is a rare disorder; fewer than 100 cases have been reported.
All forms of adenylosuccinate lyase deficiency are caused by mutations in the ADSL gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis is a disorder in which many tiny fragments (microliths) of a compound called calcium phosphate gradually accumulate in the small air sacs (alveoli) located throughout the lungs.
Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis is caused by mutations in the SLC34A2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Wagner syndrome is a hereditary disorder that causes progressive vision loss.
Wagner syndrome is a rare disorder, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the VCAN gene cause Wagner syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by severe insulin resistance, a condition in which the body's tissues and organs do not respond properly to the hormone insulin.
Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome is estimated to affect less than 1 per million people worldwide.
Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome results from mutations in the INSR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Aspartylglucosaminuria is a condition that causes a progressive decline in mental functioning.
Aspartylglucosaminuria is estimated to affect 1 in 18,500 people in Finland.
Mutations in the AGA gene cause aspartylglucosaminuria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) deficiency is an inherited condition that affects the kidneys and urinary tract.
APRT deficiency is estimated to affect 1 in 27,000 people in Japan.
Mutations in the APRT gene cause APRT deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
FG syndrome is a genetic condition that affects many parts of the body and occurs almost exclusively in males.
The prevalence of FG syndrome is unknown, although several hundred cases have been reported worldwide.
Researchers have identified changes in five regions of the X chromosome that are linked to FG syndrome in affected families.
FG syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 is a disorder that causes the immune system to malfunction, resulting in a form of immunodeficiency.
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 is estimated to occur in 1 per million people worldwide.
Mutations in the ITGB2 gene cause leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Menkes syndrome is a disorder that affects copper levels in the body.
The incidence of Menkes syndrome and occipital horn syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the ATP7A gene cause Menkes syndrome.
Menkes syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Pseudoachondroplasia is an inherited disorder of bone growth.
The exact prevalence of pseudoachondroplasia is unknown; it is estimated to occur in 1 in 30,000 individuals.
Mutations in the COMP gene cause pseudoachondroplasia.
Pseudoachondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Lacrimo-auriculo-dento-digital (LADD) syndrome is a genetic disorder that mainly affects the eyes, ears, mouth, and hands.
LADD syndrome appears to be a rare condition; at least 60 cases have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the FGFR2, FGFR3, or FGF10 gene can cause LADD syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means a mutation in one copy of the FGFR2, FGFR3, or FGF10 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Alternating hemiplegia of childhood is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent episodes of temporary paralysis, often affecting one side of the body (hemiplegia).
Alternating hemiplegia of childhood is a rare condition that affects approximately 1 in 1 million people.
Alternating hemiplegia of childhood is primarily caused by mutations in the ATP1A3 gene.
Alternating hemiplegia of childhood is considered an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (PFIC) is a disorder that causes progressive liver disease, which typically leads to liver failure.
PFIC is estimated to affect 1 in 50,000 to 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the ATP8B1, ABCB11, and ABCB4 genes can cause PFIC.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts is a progressive condition that affects brain development and function.
Megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts is a rare condition; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the MLC1 gene cause megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts type 1; this type accounts for 75 percent of all cases.

All cases of megalencephalic leukoencephalopathy with subcortical cysts caused by mutations in the MLC1 gene (type 1) and some cases caused by mutations in the HEPACAM gene (type 2A) are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Trimethylaminuria is a disorder in which the body is unable to break down trimethylamine, a chemical compound that has a pungent odor.
Trimethylaminuria is an uncommon genetic disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the FMO3 gene cause trimethylaminuria.
Most cases of trimethylaminuria appear to be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Horizontal gaze palsy with progressive scoliosis (HGPPS) is a disorder that affects vision and also causes an abnormal curvature of the spine (scoliosis).
HGPPS has been reported in several dozen families worldwide.
HGPPS is caused by mutations in the ROBO3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Primary macronodular adrenal hyperplasia (PMAH) is a disorder characterized by multiple lumps (nodules) in the adrenal glands, which are small hormone-producing glands located on top of each kidney.
PMAH is a rare disorder.
In about half of individuals with PMAH, the condition is caused by mutations in the ARMC5 gene.
People with PMAH caused by ARMC5 gene mutations inherit one copy of the mutated gene in each cell.
Baller-Gerold syndrome is a rare condition characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis) and abnormalities of bones in the arms and hands.
The prevalence of Baller-Gerold syndrome is unknown, but this rare condition probably affects fewer than 1 per million people.
Mutations in the RECQL4 gene cause some cases of Baller-Gerold syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Usher syndrome is a condition characterized by hearing loss or deafness and progressive vision loss.
Usher syndrome is thought to be responsible for 3 percent to 6 percent of all childhood deafness and about 50 percent of deaf-blindness in adults.
Mutations in the ADGRV1, CDH23, CLRN1, MYO7A, PCDH15, USH1C, USH1G, and USH2A genes can cause Usher syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary angioedema is a disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema).
Hereditary angioedema is estimated to affect 1 in 50,000 people.
Mutations in the SERPING1 gene cause hereditary angioedema type I and type II.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Proteus syndrome is a rare condition characterized by overgrowth of the bones, skin, and other tissues.
Proteus syndrome is a rare condition with an incidence of less than 1 in 1 million people worldwide.
Proteus syndrome results from a mutation in the AKT1 gene.
Because Proteus syndrome is caused by AKT1 gene mutations that occur during early development, the disorder is not inherited and does not run in families.
Cytochrome c oxidase deficiency is a genetic condition that can affect several parts of the body, including the muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles), the heart, the brain, or the liver.
In Eastern Europe, cytochrome c oxidase deficiency is estimated to occur in 1 in 35,000 individuals.
Cytochrome c oxidase deficiency is caused by mutations in one of at least 14 genes.
Cytochrome c oxidase deficiency can have different inheritance patterns depending on the gene involved.
X-linked hyper IgM syndrome is a condition that affects the immune system and occurs almost exclusively in males.
X-linked hyper IgM syndrome is estimated to occur in 2 per million newborn boys.
Mutations in the CD40LG gene cause X-linked hyper IgM syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.

Autosomal recessive primary microcephaly (often shortened to MCPH, which stands for "microcephaly primary hereditary") is a condition in which infants are born with a very small head and a small brain.
The prevalence of all forms of microcephaly that are present from birth (primary microcephaly) ranges from 1 in 30,000 to 1 in 250,000 newborns worldwide.
MCPH can result from mutations in at least seven genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy is a genetic condition characterized by muscle weakness that begins in adulthood, typically after age 40.
In Europe, the prevalence of oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy is estimated to be 1 in 100,000 people.
Mutations in the PABPN1 gene cause oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy.
Most cases of oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder that slows the blood clotting process, causing prolonged bleeding after an injury.
Von Willebrand disease is estimated to affect 1 in 100 to 10,000 individuals.
Mutations in the VWF gene cause von Willebrand disease.
Von Willebrand disease can have different inheritance patterns.
Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome is often caused by mutations in the SKI gene.
Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome is described as autosomal dominant, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glutamate formiminotransferase deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects physical and mental development.
Glutamate formiminotransferase deficiency is a rare disorder; approximately 20 affected individuals have been identified.
Mutations in the FTCD gene cause glutamate formiminotransferase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Northern epilepsy is a genetic condition that causes recurrent seizures (epilepsy) beginning in childhood, usually between ages 5 and 10.
Northern epilepsy appears to affect only individuals of Finnish ancestry, particularly those from the Kainuu region of northern Finland.
Mutations in the CLN8 gene cause Northern epilepsy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Miller syndrome is a rare condition that mainly affects the development of the face and limbs.
Miller syndrome is a rare disorder; it is estimated to affect fewer than 1 in 1 million newborns.
Mutations in the DHODH gene cause Miller syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of disorders that affect the connective tissues that support the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues.
Although it is difficult to estimate the overall frequency of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the combined prevalence of all types of this condition may be about 1 in 5,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in more than a dozen genes have been found to cause Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
The inheritance pattern of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome varies by type.
Werner syndrome is characterized by the dramatic, rapid appearance of features associated with normal aging.
Werner syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 200,000 individuals in the United States.
Mutations in the WRN gene cause Werner syndrome.
Werner syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the WRN gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked infantile spasm syndrome is a seizure disorder characterized by a type of seizure known as infantile spasms.
Infantile spasms are estimated to affect 1 to 1.
X-linked infantile spasm syndrome is caused by mutations in either the ARX gene or the CDKL5 gene.
X-linked infantile spasm syndrome can have different inheritance patterns depending on the genetic cause.
Knobloch syndrome is a rare condition characterized by severe vision problems and a skull defect.
Knobloch syndrome is a rare condition.
Mutations in the COL18A1 gene can cause Knobloch syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) is a severe skin reaction most often triggered by particular medications.
SJS/TEN is a rare disease, affecting 1 to 2 per million people each year.
Several genetic changes have been found to increase the risk of SJS/TEN in response to triggering factors such as medications.
SJS/TEN is not an inherited condition.
Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis (BRIC) is characterized by episodes of liver dysfunction called cholestasis.
BRIC is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the ATP8B1 gene cause benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis type 1 (BRIC1), and mutations in the ABCB11 gene cause benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis type 2 (BRIC2).
Both types of BRIC are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Wilson disease is an inherited disorder in which excessive amounts of copper accumulate in the body, particularly in the liver, brain, and eyes.
Wilson disease is a rare disorder that affects approximately 1 in 30,000 individuals.
Wilson disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Beta thalassemia is a blood disorder that reduces the production of hemoglobin.
Beta thalassemia is a fairly common blood disorder worldwide.
Mutations in the HBB gene cause beta thalassemia.
Thalassemia major and thalassemia intermedia are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the HBB gene in each cell have mutations.
Esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula (EA/TEF) is a condition resulting from abnormal development before birth of the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach (the esophagus).
EA/TEF occurs in 1 in 3,000 to 5,000 newborns.
Isolated EA/TEF is considered to be a multifactorial condition, which means that multiple gene variations and environmental factors likely contribute to its occurrence.
When EA/TEF occurs as a feature of a genetic syndrome or chromosomal abnormality, it may cluster in families according to the inheritance pattern for that condition.
PDGFRB-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is a type of cancer of blood-forming cells.
The exact prevalence of PDGFRB-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is unknown.
PDGFRB-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is caused by genetic rearrangements that join part of the PDGFRB gene with part of another gene.
PDGFRB-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is not inherited and occurs in people with no history of the condition in their families.
Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a condition that affects sexual development before birth and during puberty.
Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome affects 2 to 5 per 100,000 people who are genetically male.
Mutations in the AR gene cause androgen insensitivity syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Spondyloenchondrodysplasia with immune dysregulation (SPENCDI) is an inherited condition that primarily affects bone growth and immune system function.
SPENCDI appears to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ACP5 gene cause SPENCDI.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Oculodentodigital dysplasia is a condition that affects many parts of the body, particularly the eyes (oculo-), teeth (dento-), and fingers (digital).
The exact incidence of oculodentodigital dysplasia is unknown.
Mutations in the GJA1 gene cause oculodentodigital dysplasia.
Most cases of oculodentodigital dysplasia are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cone-rod dystrophy is a group of related eye disorders that causes vision loss, which becomes more severe over time.
Cone-rod dystrophy is estimated to affect 1 in 30,000 to 40,000 individuals.
Mutations in approximately 30 genes are known to cause cone-rod dystrophy.
Cone-rod dystrophy is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Isovaleric acidemia is a rare disorder in which the body is unable to process certain proteins properly.
Isovaleric acidemia is estimated to affect at least 1 in 250,000 people in the United States.
Mutations in the IVD gene cause isovaleric acidemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Activated PI3K-delta syndrome is a disorder that impairs the immune system.
The prevalence of activated PI3K-delta syndrome is unknown.
Activated PI3K-delta syndrome is caused by mutations in the PIK3CD gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called p110 delta (p110).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Mucopolysaccharidosis type II (MPS II), also known as Hunter syndrome, is a condition that affects many different parts of the body and occurs almost exclusively in males.
MPS II occurs in approximately 1 in 100,000 to 1 in 170,000 males.
Mutations in the IDS gene cause MPS II.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Fish-eye disease, also called partial LCAT deficiency, is a disorder that causes the clear front surface of the eyes (the corneas) to gradually become cloudy.
Fish-eye disease is a rare disorder.
Fish-eye disease is caused by mutations in the LCAT gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Factor V deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder.
Factor V deficiency affects an estimated 1 in 1 million people.
Factor V deficiency is usually caused by mutations in the F5 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called coagulation factor V.
Factor V deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the F5 gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked chondrodysplasia punctata 2 is a disorder characterized by bone, skin, and eye abnormalities.
X-linked chondrodysplasia punctata 2 has been estimated to affect fewer than 1 in 400,000 newborns.
X-linked chondrodysplasia punctata 2 is caused by mutations in the EBP gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Familial idiopathic basal ganglia calcification (FIBGC, formerly known as Fahr disease) is a condition characterized by abnormal deposits of calcium (calcification) in the brain.
FIBGC is thought to be a rare disorder; about 60 affected families have been described in the medical literature.
Mutations in the SLC20A2 gene cause nearly half of all cases of FIBGC.
FIBGC is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Familial atrial fibrillation is an inherited condition that disrupts the heart's normal rhythm.
Atrial fibrillation is the most common type of sustained abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia), affecting more than 3 million people in the United States.
A small percentage of all cases of familial atrial fibrillation are associated with changes in the KCNE2, KCNJ2, and KCNQ1 genes.
Familial atrial fibrillation appears to be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Isolated growth hormone deficiency is a condition caused by a severe shortage or absence of growth hormone.
The incidence of isolated growth hormone deficiency is estimated to be 1 in 4,000 to 10,000 individuals worldwide.
Isolated growth hormone deficiency is caused by mutations in one of at least three genes.
Isolated growth hormone deficiency can have different inheritance patterns depending on the type of the condition.
Alstrm syndrome is a rare condition that affects many body systems.
More than 900 people with Alstrm syndrome have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the ALMS1 gene cause Alstrm syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Meige disease is a condition that affects the normal function of the lymphatic system.
The prevalence of Meige disease is unknown.
The cause of Meige disease is unknown.
Meige disease appears to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
Hand-foot-genital syndrome is a rare condition that affects the development of the hands and feet, the urinary tract, and the reproductive system.
Hand-foot-genital syndrome is very rare; only a few families with the condition have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the HOXA13 gene cause hand-foot-genital syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Baraitser-Winter syndrome is a condition that affects the development of many parts of the body, particularly the face and the brain.
Baraitser-Winter syndrome is a rare condition.
Baraitser-Winter syndrome can result from mutations in either the ACTB or ACTG1 gene.
This condition is described as autosomal dominant, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Methylmalonic acidemia is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to process certain proteins and fats (lipids) properly.
This condition occurs in an estimated 1 in 50,000 to 100,000 people.
Mutations in the MUT, MMAA, MMAB, MMADHC, and MCEE genes cause methylmalonic acidemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the MUT, MMAA, MMAB, MMADHC, or MCEE gene in each cell have mutations.
Congenital hepatic fibrosis is a disease of the liver that is present from birth.
Isolated congenital hepatic fibrosis is rare.
Syndromes of which congenital hepatic fibrosis is a feature may be caused by changes in many different genes.
The various syndromes of which congenital hepatic fibrosis is often a feature can have different inheritance patterns.
Most people with 22q11.
The inheritance of 22q11.
Peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency is a disorder that causes deterioration of nervous system functions (neurodegeneration) beginning in infancy.
Peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency is a rare disorder.
Peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency is caused by mutations in the ACOX1 gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called peroxisomal straight-chain acyl-CoA oxidase.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
3-M syndrome is a disorder that causes short stature (dwarfism), unusual facial features, and skeletal abnormalities.
3-M syndrome is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the CUL7 gene cause 3-M syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
People with a 9q22.

Collagen VI-related myopathy is a group of disorders that affect skeletal muscles (which are the muscles used for movement) and connective tissue (which provides strength and flexibility to the skin, joints, and other structures throughout the body).
Collagen VI-related myopathy is rare.
Mutations in the COL6A1, COL6A2, and COL6A3 genes can cause the various forms of collagen VI-related myopathy.
Collagen VI-related myopathy can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies is a disorder that affects peripheral nerves.
Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies is estimated to occur in 2 to 5 per 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the PMP22 gene cause hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Familial paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia is a disorder characterized by episodes of abnormal movement that range from mild to severe.
Familial paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia is estimated to occur in 1 in 150,000 individuals.
Familial paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia can be caused by mutations in the PRRT2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Atelosteogenesis type 3 is a disorder that affects the development of bones throughout the body.
Atelosteogenesis type 3 is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the FLNB gene cause atelosteogenesis type 3.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Walker-Warburg syndrome is an inherited disorder that affects development of the muscles, brain, and eyes.
Walker-Warburg syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 60,500 newborns worldwide.
Walker-Warburg syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of several genes, including POMT1, POMT2, ISPD, FKTN, FKRP, and LARGE.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Smith-Magenis syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Smith-Magenis syndrome affects at least 1 in 25,000 individuals worldwide.
Most people with Smith-Magenis syndrome have a deletion of genetic material from a specific region of chromosome 17.
Smith-Magenis syndrome is typically not inherited.
Glycogen storage disease type VI (also known as GSDVI or Hers disease) is an inherited disorder caused by an inability to break down a complex sugar called glycogen in liver cells.
The exact prevalence of GSDVI is unknown.
Mutations in the PYGL gene cause GSDVI.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ring chromosome 14 syndrome is a condition characterized by seizures and intellectual disability.
Ring chromosome 14 syndrome appears to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Ring chromosome 14 syndrome is caused by a chromosomal abnormality known as a ring chromosome 14, sometimes written as r(14).
Ring chromosome 14 syndrome is almost never inherited.
Griscelli syndrome is an inherited condition characterized by unusually light (hypopigmented) skin and light silvery-gray hair starting in infancy.
Griscelli syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.

The three types of Griscelli syndrome are caused by mutations in different genes: Type 1 results from mutations in the MYO5A gene, type 2 is caused by mutations in the RAB27A gene, and type 3 results from mutations in the MLPH gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is a disorder characterized by a condition called oculocutaneous albinism, which causes abnormally light coloring (pigmentation) of the skin, hair, and eyes.
Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is a rare disorder in most populations and is estimated to affect 1 in 500,000 to 1,000,000 individuals worldwide.
At least nine genes are associated with Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Asphyxiating thoracic dystrophy, also known as Jeune syndrome, is an inherited disorder of bone growth characterized by a narrow chest, short ribs, shortened bones in the arms and legs, short stature, and extra fingers and toes (polydactyly).
Asphyxiating thoracic dystrophy affects an estimated 1 in 100,000 to 130,000 people.
Mutations in at least 11 genes have been found to cause asphyxiating thoracic dystrophy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Joubert syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Joubert syndrome is estimated to affect between 1 in 80,000 and 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Joubert syndrome and related disorders can be caused by mutations in at least 10 genes.
Joubert syndrome typically has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of a gene in each cell have mutations.
Neurofibromatosis type 1 is a condition characterized by changes in skin coloring (pigmentation) and the growth of tumors along nerves in the skin, brain, and other parts of the body.
Neurofibromatosis type 1 occurs in 1 in 3,000 to 4,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the NF1 gene cause neurofibromatosis type 1.
Neurofibromatosis type 1 is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is an inherited disorder that damages the immune system and causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is very rare and is estimated to occur in approximately 1 in 200,000 to 1,000,000 newborns worldwide.
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is caused by mutations in the ADA gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myotonic dystrophy is part of a group of inherited disorders called muscular dystrophies.
Myotonic dystrophy affects at least 1 in 8,000 people worldwide.
Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is caused by mutations in the DMPK gene, while type 2 results from mutations in the CNBP gene.
Both types of myotonic dystrophy are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pol III-related leukodystrophy is a disorder that affects the nervous system and other parts of the body.
Pol III-related leukodystrophy is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Pol III-related leukodystrophy is caused by mutations in the POLR3A or POLR3B gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Legius syndrome is a condition characterized by changes in skin coloring (pigmentation).
The prevalence of Legius syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the SPRED1 gene cause Legius syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Perrault syndrome is a rare condition that causes different patterns of signs and symptoms in affected males and females.
Perrault syndrome is a rare disorder; fewer than 100 affected individuals have been described in the medical literature.
Perrault syndrome has several genetic causes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hepatic veno-occlusive disease with immunodeficiency (also called VODI) is a hereditary disorder of the liver and immune system.
VODI appears to be a rare disorder; approximately 20 affected families have been reported worldwide.
VODI results from mutations in the SP110 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is a form of heart disease that usually appears in adulthood.
ARVC occurs in an estimated 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 1,250 people.
ARVC can result from mutations in at least eight genes.
Up to half of all cases of ARVC appear to run in families.
Dihydropyrimidinase deficiency is a disorder that can cause neurological and gastrointestinal problems in some affected individuals.
Dihydropyrimidinase deficiency is thought to be a rare disorder.
Dihydropyrimidinase deficiency is caused by mutations in the DPYS gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called dihydropyrimidinase.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
MYH9-related disorder is a condition that can have many signs and symptoms, including bleeding problems, hearing loss, kidney (renal) disease, and clouding of the lens of the eyes (cataracts).
The incidence of MYH9-related disorder is unknown.
MYH9-related disorder is caused by mutations in the MYH9 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Ellis-van Creveld syndrome is an inherited disorder of bone growth that results in very short stature (dwarfism).
In most parts of the world, Ellis-van Creveld syndrome occurs in 1 in 60,000 to 200,000 newborns.
Ellis-van Creveld syndrome can be caused by mutations in the EVC or EVC2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a form of severe epilepsy that begins in childhood.
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 50,000 to 1 in 100,000 children.
Researchers have not identified any genes specific to Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, although the disorder likely has a genetic component.
Most cases of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Nonsyndromic aplasia cutis congenita is a condition in which babies are born with localized areas of missing skin (lesions).
Aplasia cutis congenita affects approximately 1 in 10,000 newborns.
Nonsyndromic aplasia cutis congenita can have different causes, and often the cause is unknown.
Most cases of nonsyndromic aplasia cutis congenita are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
DOORS syndrome is a disorder involving multiple abnormalities that are present from birth (congenital).
DOORS syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
DOORS syndrome can be caused by mutations in the TBC1D24 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Arts syndrome is a disorder that causes serious neurological problems in males.
Arts syndrome appears to be extremely rare.
Mutations in the PRPS1 gene cause Arts syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Triple A syndrome is an inherited condition characterized by three specific features: achalasia, Addison disease, and alacrima.
Triple A syndrome is a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the AAAS gene cause triple A syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ichthyosis with confetti is a disorder of the skin.
Ichthyosis with confetti is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the KRT10 gene cause ichthyosis with confetti.
Ichthyosis with confetti is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Congenital leptin deficiency is a condition that causes severe obesity beginning in the first few months of life.
Congenital leptin deficiency is a rare disorder.
Congenital leptin deficiency is caused by mutations in the LEP gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Erythromelalgia is a condition characterized by episodes of pain, redness, and swelling in various parts of the body, particularly the hands and feet.
The prevalence of erythromelalgia is unknown.
Mutations in the SCN9A gene can cause erythromelalgia.
Some cases of erythromelalgia occur in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glucose phosphate isomerase (GPI) deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects red blood cells, which carry oxygen to the body's tissues.
GPI deficiency is a rare cause of hemolytic anemia; its prevalence is unknown.
GPI deficiency is caused by mutations in the GPI gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called glucose phosphate isomerase (GPI).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is a genetic disorder that occurs most often in males.
An estimated 400 million people worldwide have glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.
Mutations in the G6PD gene cause glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
North American Indian childhood cirrhosis is a rare liver disorder that occurs in children.
North American Indian childhood cirrhosis has been found only in children of Ojibway-Cree descent in the Abitibi region of northwestern Quebec, Canada.
North American Indian childhood cirrhosis results from at least one known mutation in the UTP4 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Factor XIII deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder.
Inherited factor XIII deficiency affects 1 to 3 per million people worldwide.
Inherited factor XIII deficiency results from mutations in the F13A1 gene or, less commonly, the F13B gene.

Inherited factor XIII deficiency is considered to have an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means that it results when both copies of either the F13A1 gene or the F13B gene in each cell have mutations.
Cryptogenic cirrhosis is a condition that impairs liver function.
Cirrhosis affects more than 600,000 people in the United States; cryptogenic cirrhosis likely accounts for 5 to 30 percent of these cases.
Unlike most cases of cirrhosis, cryptogenic cirrhosis is not caused by the hepatitis C or B virus or chronic alcohol use.
Most cases of cryptogenic cirrhosis are not inherited.
Medullary cystic kidney disease type 1 (MCKD1) is an inherited condition that affects the kidneys.
MCKD1 is a rare disorder, although its prevalence is unknown.
MCKD1 is caused by mutations in the MUC1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Gilbert syndrome is a relatively mild condition characterized by periods of elevated levels of a toxic substance called bilirubin in the blood (hyperbilirubinemia).
Gilbert syndrome is a common condition that is estimated to affect 3 to 7 percent of Americans.
Changes in the UGT1A1 gene cause Gilbert syndrome.
Gilbert syndrome can have different inheritance patterns.
Glycogen storage disease type IX (also known as GSD IX) is a condition caused by the inability to break down a complex sugar called glycogen.
GSD IX that affects the liver is estimated to occur in 1 in 100,000 people.
Mutations in the PHKA1, PHKA2, PHKB, or PHKG2 genes are known to cause GSD IX.
GSD IX can have different inheritance patterns depending on the genetic cause of the condition.
Nonsyndromic holoprosencephaly is an abnormality of brain development that also affects the head and face.
Nonsyndromic holoprosencephaly accounts for approximately 25 to 50 percent of all cases of holoprosencephaly, which affects an estimated 1 in 10,000 newborns.
Mutations in 11 genes have been found to cause nonsyndromic holoprosencephaly.
Nonsyndromic holoprosencephaly is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means an alteration in one copy of a gene in each cell is usually sufficient to cause the disorder.
Succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency is a disorder that can cause a variety of neurological problems.
Approximately 350 people with succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the ALDH5A1 gene cause succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial erythrocytosis is an inherited condition characterized by an increased number of red blood cells (erythrocytes).
Familial erythrocytosis is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Familial erythrocytosis can result from mutations in the EPOR, VHL, EGLN1, or EPAS1 gene.
Familial erythrocytosis can have different inheritance patterns depending on the gene involved.
Autosomal dominant congenital stationary night blindness is a disorder of the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color.
Autosomal dominant congenital stationary night blindness is likely a rare disease; however, its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the RHO, GNAT1, or PDE6B gene cause autosomal dominant congenital stationary night blindness.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Romano-Ward syndrome is a condition that causes a disruption of the heart's normal rhythm (arrhythmia).
Romano-Ward syndrome is the most common form of inherited long QT syndrome, affecting an estimated 1 in 7,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the KCNE1, KCNE2, KCNH2, KCNQ1, and SCN5A genes cause Romano-Ward syndrome.
This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Timothy syndrome is a rare disorder that affects many parts of the body including the heart, digits (fingers and toes), and the nervous system.
Timothy syndrome is a rare condition; fewer than 20 people with this disorder have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the CACNA1C gene are responsible for all reported cases of Timothy syndrome.
This condition is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered CACNA1C gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Phosphoglycerate kinase deficiency is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down the simple sugar glucose, which is the primary energy source for most cells.
Phosphoglycerate kinase deficiency appears to be a rare disorder.
Phosphoglycerate kinase deficiency is caused by mutations in the PGK1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Fumarase deficiency is a condition that primarily affects the nervous system, especially the brain.
Fumarase deficiency is a very rare disorder.
The FH gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called fumarase (also known as fumarate hydratase).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
3-methylglutaconyl-CoA hydratase deficiency is an inherited condition that causes neurological problems.
3-methylglutaconyl-CoA hydratase deficiency is a rare disorder; at least 20 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the AUH gene cause 3-methylglutaconyl-CoA hydratase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is characterized by problems with movement and thinking ability (cognition).
Studies show that approximately 1 in 450 males has the genetic change that leads to FXTAS, although the condition occurs in only about 40 percent of them.
Mutations in the FMR1 gene increase the risk of developing FXTAS.
An increased risk of developing FXTAS is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

Perry syndrome is a progressive brain disease that is characterized by four major features: a pattern of movement abnormalities known as parkinsonism, psychiatric changes, weight loss, and abnormally slow breathing (hypoventilation).
Perry syndrome is very rare; about 50 affected individuals have been reported worldwide.
Perry syndrome results from mutations in the DCTN1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is an inherited disorder characterized by the formation of tumors and fluid-filled sacs (cysts) in many different parts of the body.
The incidence of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 36,000 individuals.
Mutations in the VHL gene cause von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.
Mutations in the VHL gene are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means that one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing tumors and cysts.
Cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis is a fat (lipid) storage disorder that affects many areas of the body.
The incidence of cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis is estimated to be 3 to 5 per 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the CYP27A1 gene cause cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Lymphedema-distichiasis syndrome is a condition that affects the normal function of the lymphatic system, which is a part of the circulatory and immune systems.
The prevalence of lymphedema-distichiasis syndrome is unknown.
Lymphedema-distichiasis syndrome is caused by mutations in the FOXC2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Jacobsen syndrome is a condition caused by a loss of genetic material from chromosome 11.
The estimated incidence of Jacobsen syndrome is 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Jacobsen syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material at the end of the long (q) arm of chromosome 11.
Most cases of Jacobsen syndrome are not inherited.
Mainzer-Saldino syndrome is a disorder characterized by kidney disease, eye problems, and skeletal abnormalities.
Mainzer-Saldino syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mainzer-Saldino syndrome is usually caused by mutations in the IFT140 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Angelman syndrome is a complex genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
Angelman syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 12,000 to 20,000 people.
Many of the characteristic features of Angelman syndrome result from the loss of function of a gene called UBE3A.
Most cases of Angelman syndrome are not inherited, particularly those caused by a deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy.
Mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I) is a condition that affects many parts of the body.
Severe MPS I occurs in approximately 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the IDUA gene cause MPS I.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy (ADNFLE) is an uncommon form of epilepsy that runs in families.
ADNFLE appears to be an uncommon form of epilepsy; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the CHRNA2, CHRNA4, and CHRNB2 genes can cause ADNFLE.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to raise the risk of developing epilepsy.
Ocular albinism is a genetic condition that primarily affects the eyes.
The most common form of this disorder, ocular albinism type 1, affects at least 1 in 60,000 males.
Ocular albinism type 1 results from mutations in the GPR143 gene.
Ocular albinism type 1 is inherited in an X-linked pattern.

Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC) is a disorder in which affected individuals tend to develop benign tumors containing smooth muscle tissue (leiomyomas) in the skin and, in females, the uterus.
HLRCC has been reported in approximately 100 families worldwide.
Mutations in the FH gene cause hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Gray platelet syndrome is a bleeding disorder associated with abnormal platelets, which are blood cell fragments involved in blood clotting.
Gray platelet syndrome appears to be a rare disorder.
Gray platelet syndrome can be caused by mutations in the NBEAL2 gene.
When gray platelet syndrome is caused by NBEAL2 gene mutations, it has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Rothmund-Thomson syndrome is a rare condition that affects many parts of the body, especially the skin.
Rothmund-Thomson syndrome is a rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the RECQL4 gene cause about two-thirds of all cases of Rothmund-Thomson syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy is a hereditary disorder that can cause progressive vision loss.
The prevalence of familial exudative vitreoretinopathy is unknown.
Mutations in the FZD4, LRP5, and NDP genes can cause familial exudative vitreoretinopathy.
Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy has different inheritance patterns depending on the gene involved.
Spondyloperipheral dysplasia is a disorder that impairs bone growth.
This condition is rare; only a few affected individuals have been reported worldwide.
Spondyloperipheral dysplasia is one of a spectrum of skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the COL2A1 gene.
This condition is probably inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Platyspondylic lethal skeletal dysplasia, Torrance type is a severe disorder of bone growth.
This condition is very rare; only a few affected individuals have been reported worldwide.
Platyspondylic lethal skeletal dysplasia, Torrance type is one of a spectrum of skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the COL2A1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome is a rare disorder of brain development that causes moderate to severe intellectual disability and problems with movement.
Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome appears to be a rare disorder.
Mutations in the SLC16A2 gene cause Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.

Triosephosphate isomerase deficiency is a disorder characterized by a shortage of red blood cells (anemia), movement problems, increased susceptibility to infection, and muscle weakness that can affect breathing and heart function.
Triosephosphate isomerase deficiency is likely a rare condition; approximately 40 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the TPI1 gene cause triosephosphate isomerase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Clouston syndrome is a form of ectodermal dysplasia, a group of about 150 conditions characterized by abnormal development of some or all of the ectodermal structures, which include the skin, hair, nails, teeth, and sweat glands.
The prevalence of Clouston syndrome is unknown.
Clouston syndrome is caused by mutations in the GJB6 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a heart condition characterized by thickening (hypertrophy) of the heart (cardiac) muscle.
Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy affects an estimated 1 in 500 people worldwide.
Mutations in one of several genes can cause familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; the most commonly involved genes are MYH7, MYBPC3, TNNT2, and TNNI3.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Keratitis-ichthyosis-deafness (KID) syndrome is characterized by eye problems, skin abnormalities, and hearing loss.
KID syndrome is a rare disorder.
KID syndrome is caused by mutations in the GJB2 gene.
KID syndrome is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
The prevalence of this disorder is estimated to be 1 in 7,500 to 20,000 people.
At least 500 cases of 22q13.
Most cases of 22q13.
ALG6-congenital disorder of glycosylation (ALG6-CDG, also known as congenital disorder of glycosylation type Ic) is an inherited condition that affects many parts of the body.
The prevalence of ALG6-CDG is unknown, but it is thought to be the second most common type of congenital disorder of glycosylation.
ALG6-CDG is caused by mutations in the ALG6 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Sialuria is a rare disorder that has variable effects on development.
Fewer than 10 people worldwide have been diagnosed with sialuria.
Mutations in the GNE gene cause sialuria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Schindler disease is an inherited disorder that primarily causes neurological problems.
Schindler disease is very rare.
Mutations in the NAGA gene cause Schindler disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Lynch syndrome, often called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an inherited disorder that increases the risk of many types of cancer, particularly cancers of the colon (large intestine) and rectum, which are collectively referred to as colorectal cancer.
In the United States, about 140,000 new cases of colorectal cancer are diagnosed each year.
Variations in the MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, or EPCAM gene increase the risk of developing Lynch syndrome.
Lynch syndrome cancer risk is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one inherited copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase cancer risk.
Gaucher disease is an inherited disorder that affects many of the body's organs and tissues.
Gaucher disease occurs in 1 in 50,000 to 100,000 people in the general population.
Mutations in the GBA gene cause Gaucher disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cockayne syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by short stature and an appearance of premature aging.
Cockayne syndrome occurs in about 2 per million newborns in the United States and Europe.
Cockayne syndrome can result from mutations in either the ERCC6 gene (also known as the CSB gene) or the ERCC8 gene (also known as the CSA gene).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Actin-accumulation myopathy is a disorder that primarily affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
Actin-accumulation myopathy is a rare disorder that has been identified in only a small number of individuals.
Actin-accumulation myopathy is caused by a mutation in the ACTA1 gene.
Actin-accumulation myopathy is an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hirschsprung disease is an intestinal disorder characterized by the absence of nerves in parts of the intestine.
Hirschsprung disease occurs in approximately 1 in 5,000 newborns.
Isolated Hirschsprung disease can result from mutations in one of several genes, including the RET, EDNRB, and EDN3 genes.
Approximately 20 percent of cases of Hirschsprung disease occur in multiple members of the same family.
Fragile X syndrome is a genetic condition that causes a range of developmental problems including learning disabilities and cognitive impairment.
Fragile X syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 4,000 males and 1 in 8,000 females.
Mutations in the FMR1 gene cause fragile X syndrome.
Fragile X syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
ZAP70-related severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is an inherited disorder that damages the immune system.
ZAP70-related SCID is a rare disorder.
As the name indicates, this condition is caused by mutations in the ZAP70 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cant syndrome is a rare condition characterized by excess hair growth (hypertrichosis), a distinctive facial appearance, heart defects, and several other abnormalities.
Cant syndrome is a rare condition.
Cant syndrome results from mutations in the ABCC9 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered ABCC9 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Russell-Silver syndrome is a growth disorder characterized by slow growth before and after birth.
The exact incidence of Russell-Silver syndrome is unknown, but the condition is estimated to affect 1 in 75,000 to 100,000 people.
The genetic causes of Russell-Silver syndrome are complex.
Most cases of Russell-Silver syndrome are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Hennekam syndrome is an inherited disorder resulting from malformation of the lymphatic system, which is part of both the circulatory system and immune system.
At least 50 cases of Hennekam syndrome have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the CCBE1 or FAT4 gene can cause Hennekam syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Eosinophil peroxidase deficiency is a condition that affects certain white blood cells called eosinophils but causes no health problems in affected individuals.
Approximately 100 individuals with eosinophil peroxidase deficiency have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the EPX gene cause eosinophil peroxidase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Friedreich ataxia is a genetic condition that affects the nervous system and causes movement problems.
Friedreich ataxia is estimated to affect 1 in 40,000 people.
Mutations in the FXN gene cause Friedreich ataxia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Meesmann corneal dystrophy is an eye disease that affects the cornea, which is the clear front covering of the eye.
Meesmann corneal dystrophy is a rare disorder whose prevalence is unknown.
Meesmann corneal dystrophy can result from mutations in either the KRT12 gene or the KRT3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered KRT12 or KRT3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Factor X deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder that varies in severity among affected individuals.
Factor X deficiency occurs in approximately 1 per million individuals worldwide.

The inherited form of factor X deficiency, known as congenital factor X deficiency, is caused by mutations in the F10 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called coagulation factor X.
When this condition is caused by mutations in the F10 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Senior-Lken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by the combination of two specific features: a kidney condition called nephronophthisis and an eye condition known as Leber congenital amaurosis.
Senior-Lken syndrome is a rare disorder, with an estimated prevalence of about 1 in 1 million people worldwide.
Senior-Lken syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of at least five genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
