Primary myelofibrosis is a condition characterized by the buildup of scar tissue (fibrosis) in the bone marrow, the tissue that produces blood cells.
Primary myelofibrosis is a rare condition that affects approximately 1 in 500,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the JAK2, MPL, CALR, and TET2 genes are associated with most cases of primary myelofibrosis.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from gene mutations that occur in early blood-forming cells after conception.
Piebaldism is a condition characterized by the absence of cells called melanocytes in certain areas of the skin and hair.
The prevalence of piebaldism is unknown.
Piebaldism can be caused by mutations in the KIT and SNAI2 genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Laron syndrome is a rare form of short stature that results from the body's inability to use growth hormone, a substance produced by the brain's pituitary gland that helps promote growth.
Laron syndrome is a rare disorder.
Laron syndrome is caused by mutations in the GHR gene.
Most cases of Laron syndrome are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the GHR gene in each cell have mutations.
Spastic paraplegia type 15 is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
Spastic paraplegia type 15 is a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ZFYVE26 gene cause spastic paraplegia type 15.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Vitamin D-dependent rickets is a disorder of bone development that leads to softening and weakening of the bones (rickets).
Rickets affects an estimated 1 in 200,000 children.
The two types of vitamin D-dependent rickets have different genetic causes: CYP27B1 gene mutations cause VDDR1, and VDR gene mutations cause VDDR2.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Most people with a 1q21.
Autosomal recessive hyper-IgE syndrome (AR-HIES) is a disorder of the immune system.
AR-HIES is a rare disorder whose prevalence is unknown.
AR-HIES is usually caused by mutations in the DOCK8 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (NCL) is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
The incidence of infantile NCL is unknown.
Mutations in the PPT1 gene cause most cases of infantile NCL.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a severe condition characterized by high levels of a toxic substance called bilirubin in the blood (hyperbilirubinemia).
Crigler-Najjar syndrome is estimated to affect fewer than 1 in 1 million newborns worldwide.
Mutations in the UGT1A1 gene cause Crigler-Najjar syndrome.
Crigler-Najjar syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the UGT1A1 gene in each cell have mutations.
Idiopathic inflammatory myopathy is a group of disorders characterized by inflammation of the muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
The incidence of idiopathic inflammatory myopathy is approximately 2 to 8 cases per million people each year.
Idiopathic inflammatory myopathy is thought to arise from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of idiopathic inflammatory myopathy are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Isobutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase (IBD) deficiency is a condition that disrupts the breakdown of certain proteins.
IBD deficiency is a rare disorder; approximately 22 cases have been reported in the medical literature.
Mutations in the ACAD8 gene cause IBD deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spastic paraplegia type 8 is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
The prevalence of all hereditary spastic paraplegias combined is estimated to be 1 to 18 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the KIAA0196 gene cause spastic paraplegia type 8.
Spastic paraplegia type 8 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Lamellar ichthyosis is a condition that mainly affects the skin.
Lamellar ichthyosis is estimated to affect 1 in 100,000 individuals in the United States.
Mutations in one of many genes can cause lamellar ichthyosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Huntington disease is a progressive brain disorder that causes uncontrolled movements, emotional problems, and loss of thinking ability (cognition).
Huntington disease affects an estimated 3 to 7 per 100,000 people of European ancestry.
Mutations in the HTT gene cause Huntington disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Dyserythropoietic anemia and thrombocytopenia is a condition that affects blood cells and primarily occurs in males.
Dyserythropoietic anemia and thrombocytopenia is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the GATA1 gene cause dyserythropoietic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Progressive pseudorheumatoid dysplasia (PPRD) is a joint disease that worsens over time.
PPRD has been estimated to occur in approximately 1 per million people in the United Kingdom.
PPRD is caused by mutations in the WISP3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Rapid-onset dystonia parkinsonism is a rare movement disorder.
Rapid-onset dystonia parkinsonism appears to be a rare disorder, although its prevalence is unknown.
Rapid-onset dystonia parkinsonism is caused by mutations in the ATP1A3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered ATP1A3 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Breast cancer is a disease in which certain cells in the breast become abnormal and multiply uncontrollably to form a tumor.
Breast cancer is the second most commonly diagnosed cancer in women.
Cancers occur when a buildup of mutations in critical genesthose that control cell growth and division or repair damaged DNAallow cells to grow and divide uncontrollably to form a tumor.
Most cases of breast cancer are not caused by inherited genetic factors.
Kniest dysplasia is a disorder of bone growth characterized by short stature (dwarfism) with other skeletal abnormalities and problems with vision and hearing.
Kniest dysplasia is a rare condition; the exact incidence is unknown.
Kniest dysplasia is one of a spectrum of skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the COL2A1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Ethylmalonic encephalopathy is an inherited disorder that affects several body systems, particularly the nervous system.
About 30 individuals with this condition have been identified worldwide, mostly in Mediterranean and Arab populations.
Mutations in the ETHE1 gene cause ethylmalonic encephalopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cystinosis is a condition characterized by accumulation of the amino acid cystine (a building block of proteins) within cells.
Cystinosis affects approximately 1 in 100,000 to 200,000 newborns worldwide.
All three types of cystinosis are caused by mutations in the CTNS gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mal de Meleda is a rare skin disorder that begins in early infancy.
Mal de Meleda is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mal de Meleda is caused by mutations in the SLURP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial hypobetalipoproteinemia (FHBL) is a disorder that impairs the body's ability to absorb and transport fats.
FHBL is estimated to occur in 1 in 1,000 to 3,000 individuals.
Most cases of FHBL are caused by mutations in the APOB gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal codominant pattern.
Guanidinoacetate methyltransferase deficiency is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the brain and muscles.
Guanidinoacetate methyltransferase deficiency is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the GAMT gene cause guanidinoacetate methyltransferase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency (also known as 3-MCC deficiency) is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to process certain proteins properly.
This condition is detected in an estimated 1 in 36,000 newborns worldwide.
Mutations in the MCCC1 or MCCC2 gene can cause 3-MCC deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Autosomal dominant partial epilepsy with auditory features (ADPEAF) is an uncommon form of epilepsy that runs in families.
This condition appears to be uncommon, although its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the LGI1 gene cause ADPEAF.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered LGI1 gene in each cell is sufficient to raise the risk of developing epilepsy.
Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets is a disorder related to low levels of phosphate in the blood (hypophosphatemia).
X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common form of rickets that runs in families.
Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets can result from mutations in several genes.
Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets can have several patterns of inheritance.
Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a bleeding disorder that is characterized by prolonged or spontaneous bleeding starting from birth.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is estimated to affect 1 in one million individuals worldwide, but may be more common in certain groups, including those of Romani ethnicity, particularly people within the French Manouche community.
Mutations in the ITGA2B or ITGB3 gene cause Glanzmann thrombasthenia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neuroferritinopathy is a disorder in which iron gradually accumulates in the brain.
The prevalence of neuroferritinopathy is unknown.
Mutations in the FTL gene cause neuroferritinopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Diamond-Blackfan anemia is a disorder of the bone marrow.
Diamond-Blackfan anemia affects approximately 5 to 7 per million liveborn infants worldwide.
Diamond-Blackfan anemia can be caused by mutations in the RPL5, RPL11, RPL35A, RPS7, RPS10, RPS17, RPS19, RPS24, and RPS26 genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
1p36 deletion syndrome is a disorder that typically causes severe intellectual disability.
1p36 deletion syndrome is believed to affect between 1 in 5,000 and 1 in 10,000 newborns.
1p36 deletion syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material from a specific region in the short (p) arm of chromosome 1.
Most cases of 1p36 deletion syndrome are not inherited.

Crouzonodermoskeletal syndrome is a disorder characterized by the premature joining of certain bones of the skull (craniosynostosis) during development and a skin condition called acanthosis nigricans.
Crouzonodermoskeletal syndrome is rare; this condition is seen in about 1 person per million.
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene cause Crouzonodermoskeletal syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Osteoglophonic dysplasia is a condition characterized by abnormal bone growth that leads to severe head and face (craniofacial) abnormalities, dwarfism, and other features.
Osteoglophonic dysplasia is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Osteoglophonic dysplasia is caused by mutations in the FGFR1 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called fibroblast growth factor receptor 1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Schimke immuno-osseous dysplasia is a condition characterized by short stature, kidney disease, and a weakened immune system.
Schimke immuno-osseous dysplasia is a very rare condition.
Mutations in the SMARCAL1 gene increase the risk of Schimke immuno-osseous dysplasia.

Mutations in the SMARCAL1 gene are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that an increased risk of Schimke immuno-osseous dysplasia results from mutations in both copies of the SMARCAL1 gene in each cell.
Oculocutaneous albinism is a group of conditions that affect coloring (pigmentation) of the skin, hair, and eyes.
Overall, an estimated 1 in 20,000 people worldwide are born with oculocutaneous albinism.
Oculocutaneous albinism can result from mutations in several genes, including TYR, OCA2, TYRP1, and SLC45A2.
Oculocutaneous albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of a gene in each cell have mutations.
Asthma is a breathing disorder characterized by inflammation of the airways and recurrent episodes of breathing difficulty.
Approximately 235 million people worldwide have asthma.
The cause of allergic asthma is complex.
Allergic asthma can be passed through generations in families, but the inheritance pattern is unknown.
Ovarian cancer is a disease that affects women.
Ovarian cancer affects about 12 in 100,000 women per year.
Cancers occur when a buildup of mutations in critical genesthose that control cell growth and division or repair damaged DNAallow cells to grow and divide uncontrollably to form a tumor.
Most cases of ovarian cancer are not caused by inherited genetic factors.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is one of a group of disorders (collectively called congenital adrenal hyperplasia) that affect the adrenal glands.
CAH due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency accounts for 5 to 8 percent of all cases of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
Mutations in the CYP11B1 gene cause CAH due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Adult polyglucosan body disease is a condition that affects the nervous system.
Adult polyglucosan body disease is a rare condition; although its exact prevalence is unknown, at least 50 affected individuals have been described in the medical literature.
Mutations in the GBE1 gene cause adult polyglucosan body disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cerebral cavernous malformations are collections of small blood vessels (capillaries) in the brain that are enlarged and irregular in structure.
Cerebral cavernous malformations affect about 0.
Mutations in at least three genes, KRIT1 (also known as CCM1), CCM2, and PDCD10 (also known as CCM3), cause familial cerebral cavernous malformations.
This condition has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Succinate-CoA ligase deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects the early development of the brain and other body systems.
Although the exact prevalence of succinate-CoA ligase deficiency is unknown, it appears to be very rare.
Succinate-CoA ligase deficiency results from mutations in the SUCLA2 or SUCLG1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cowden syndrome is a disorder characterized by multiple noncancerous, tumor-like growths called hamartomas and an increased risk of developing certain cancers.
Although the exact prevalence of Cowden syndrome is unknown, researchers estimate that it affects about 1 in 200,000 people.
Changes involving at least four genes, PTEN, SDHB, SDHD, and KLLN, have been identified in people with Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome.

Cowden syndrome and Cowden-like syndrome are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition and increase the risk of developing cancer.

Familial glucocorticoid deficiency is a condition that occurs when the adrenal glands, which are hormone-producing glands located on top of each kidney, do not produce certain hormones called glucocorticoids.
The prevalence of familial glucocorticoid deficiency is unknown.

Mutations in the MC2R, MRAP, and NNT genes account for the majority of cases of familial glucocorticoid deficiency; mutations in other genes, some known and some unidentified, can also cause this condition.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Caudal regression syndrome is a disorder that impairs the development of the lower (caudal) half of the body.
Caudal regression syndrome is estimated to occur in 1 to 2.
Caudal regression syndrome is a complex condition that may have different causes in different people.
Caudal regression syndrome occurs sporadically, which means it occurs in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Mowat-Wilson syndrome is a genetic condition that affects many parts of the body.
The prevalence of Mowat-Wilson syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the ZEB2 gene cause Mowat-Wilson syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Intranuclear rod myopathy is a disorder that primarily affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
Intranuclear rod myopathy is a rare disorder that has been identified in only a small number of individuals.
Intranuclear rod myopathy is caused by a mutation in the ACTA1 gene.
Intranuclear rod myopathy is an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Craniofacial microsomia is a term used to describe a spectrum of abnormalities that primarily affect the development of the skull (cranium) and face before birth.
Craniofacial microsomia has been estimated to occur in between 1 in 5,600 and 1 in 26,550 newborns.
It is unclear what genes are involved in craniofacial microsomia.
Craniofacial microsomia most often occurs in a single individual in a family and is not inherited.
Aromatase deficiency is a condition characterized by reduced levels of the female sex hormone estrogen and increased levels of the male sex hormone testosterone.
The prevalence of aromatase deficiency is unknown; approximately 20 cases have been described in the medical literature.
Mutations in the CYP19A1 gene cause aromatase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cri-du-chat (cat's cry) syndrome, also known as 5p- (5p minus) syndrome, is a chromosomal condition that results when a piece of chromosome 5 is missing.
Cri-du-chat syndrome occurs in an estimated 1 in 20,000 to 50,000 newborns.
Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a deletion of the end of the short (p) arm of chromosome 5.
Most cases of cri-du-chat syndrome are not inherited.
Schwartz-Jampel syndrome is a rare condition characterized by permanent muscle stiffness (myotonia) and bone abnormalities known as chondrodysplasia.
Schwartz-Jampel syndrome appears to be a rare condition.
Schwartz-Jampel syndrome is caused by mutations in the HSPG2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Meckel syndrome is a disorder with severe signs and symptoms that affect many parts of the body.
Meckel syndrome affects 1 in 13,250 to 1 in 140,000 people worldwide.
Meckel syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of at least eight genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Celiac disease is a condition in which the immune system is abnormally sensitive to gluten, a protein found in wheat, rye, and barley.
Celiac disease is a common disorder.
The risk of developing celiac disease is increased by certain variants of the HLA-DQA1 and HLA-DQB1 genes.
Celiac disease tends to cluster in families.
Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a condition that occurs almost exclusively in males.
The prevalence of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is approximately 1 in 380,000 individuals.
Mutations in the HPRT1 gene cause Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Dopa-responsive dystonia is a disorder that involves involuntary muscle contractions, tremors, and other uncontrolled movements (dystonia).
Dopa-responsive dystonia is estimated to affect 1 per million people worldwide.
Mutations in the GCH1 gene are the most common cause of dopa-responsive dystonia.

When dopa-responsive dystonia is caused by mutations in the GCH1 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cutis laxa is a disorder of connective tissue, which is the tissue that forms the body's supportive framework.
Cutis laxa is a rare disorder.
Cutis laxa can be caused by mutations in the ATP6V0A2, ATP7A, EFEMP2, ELN, or FBLN5 gene.
Cutis laxa can have an autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.
Bjrnstad syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by abnormal hair and hearing problems.
Bjrnstad syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Bjrnstad syndrome is caused by mutations in the BCS1L gene.
Bjrnstad syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
A chordoma is a rare type of cancerous tumor that can occur anywhere along the spine, from the base of the skull to the tailbone.
Chordomas are rare, occurring in approximately 1 per million individuals each year.
Changes in the T gene have been associated with chordoma.

When development of a chordoma is associated with a duplication of the T gene inherited from a parent, one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of the disorder, which is an inheritance pattern called autosomal dominant.
Juvenile Paget disease is a disorder that affects bone growth.
Juvenile Paget disease is rare; about 50 affected individuals have been identified worldwide.
Juvenile Paget disease is caused by mutations in the TNFRSF11B gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Anencephaly is a condition that prevents the normal development of the brain and the bones of the skull.
Anencephaly is one of the most common types of neural tube defect, affecting about 1 in 1,000 pregnancies.
Anencephaly is a complex condition that is likely caused by the interaction of multiple genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of anencephaly are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Adams-Oliver syndrome is a rare condition that is present at birth.
Adams-Oliver syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ARHGAP31, DLL4, DOCK6, EOGT, NOTCH1, or RBPJ gene can cause Adams-Oliver syndrome.
Adams-Oliver syndrome can have different inheritance patterns.
Jackson-Weiss syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by foot abnormalities and the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis).
Jackson-Weiss syndrome is a rare genetic disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the FGFR2 gene cause Jackson-Weiss syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Mucolipidosis II alpha/beta (also known as I-cell disease) is a progressively debilitating disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Mucolipidosis II alpha/beta is a rare disorder, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the GNPTAB gene cause mucolipidosis II alpha/beta.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myoclonus-dystonia is a movement disorder that typically affects the upper half of the body.
The prevalence of myoclonus-dystonia is unknown.
Mutations in the SGCE gene cause myoclonus-dystonia.
Myoclonus-dystonia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Complete LCAT deficiency is a disorder that primarily affects the eyes and kidneys.
Complete LCAT deficiency is a rare disorder.
Complete LCAT deficiency is caused by mutations in the LCAT gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Peters plus syndrome is an inherited condition that is characterized by eye abnormalities, short stature, an opening in the lip (cleft lip) with or without an opening in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate), distinctive facial features, and intellectual disability.
Peters plus syndrome is a rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the B3GLCT gene cause Peters plus syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Holt-Oram syndrome is characterized by skeletal abnormalities of the hands and arms (upper limbs) and heart problems.
Holt-Oram syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the TBX5 gene cause Holt-Oram syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Essential thrombocythemia is a condition characterized by an increased number of platelets (thrombocythemia).
Essential thrombocythemia affects an estimated 1 to 24 per 1 million people worldwide.
The JAK2 and CALR genes are the most commonly mutated genes in essential thrombocythemia.
Most cases of essential thrombocythemia are not inherited.
Familial isolated hyperparathyroidism is an inherited condition characterized by overactivity of the parathyroid glands (hyperparathyroidism).
The prevalence of familial isolated hyperparathyroidism is unknown.
Familial isolated hyperparathyroidism can be caused by mutations in the MEN1, CDC73, or CASR gene.
This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Polycystic kidney disease is a disorder that affects the kidneys and other organs.
Polycystic kidney disease is a fairly common genetic disorder.
Mutations in the PKD1, PKD2, and PKHD1 genes cause polycystic kidney disease.
Most cases of polycystic kidney disease have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
Familial cylindromatosis is a condition involving multiple skin tumors that develop from structures associated with the skin (skin appendages), such as hair follicles and sweat glands.
Familial cylindromatosis is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Familial cylindromatosis is caused by mutations in the CYLD gene.
Susceptibility to familial cylindromatosis has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell increases the risk of developing this condition.
Acute promyelocytic leukemia is a form of acute myeloid leukemia, a cancer of the blood-forming tissue (bone marrow).
Acute promyelocytic leukemia accounts for about 10 percent of acute myeloid leukemia cases.
The mutation that causes acute promyelocytic leukemia involves two genes, the PML gene on chromosome 15 and the RARA gene on chromosome 17.
Acute promyelocytic leukemia is not inherited but arises from a translocation in the body's cells that occurs after conception.
Horner syndrome is a disorder that affects the eye and surrounding tissues on one side of the face and results from paralysis of certain nerves.
About 1 in 6,250 babies are born with Horner syndrome.
Although congenital Horner syndrome can be passed down in families, no associated genes have been identified.
Horner syndrome is usually not inherited and occurs in individuals with no history of the disorder in their family.
Giant axonal neuropathy is an inherited condition involving dysfunction of a specific type of protein in nerve cells (neurons).
Giant axonal neuropathy is a very rare disorder; the incidence is unknown.
Giant axonal neuropathy is caused by mutations in the GAN gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called gigaxonin.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is a disorder in which the immune system produces too many activated immune cells (lymphocytes) called T cells, natural killer cells, B cells, and macrophages (histiocytes).
Familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis occurs in approximately 1 in 50,000 individuals worldwide.
Familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis may be caused by mutations in any of several genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dopamine transporter deficiency syndrome is a rare movement disorder.
Dopamine transporter deficiency syndrome appears to be a rare disease; only about 20 affected individuals have been described in the medical literature.
Dopamine transporter deficiency syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC6A3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Globozoospermia is a condition that affects only males.
Globozoospermia is a rare condition that is estimated to affect 1 in 65,000 men.
Globozoospermia is most commonly caused by mutations in the DPY19L2 gene, which are found in about 70 percent of men with this condition.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Recurrent hydatidiform mole occurs when women have at least two abnormal pregnancies described as hydatidiform moles.
Hydatidiform moles occur in 1 in 600 to 1,000 pregnancies in western countries and are more common in developing countries.
Mutations in the NLRP7 or KHDC3L gene can cause recurrent hydatidiform mole, with NLRP7 gene mutations being the most common cause.

This condition is often inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means a woman has to have mutations in both copies of the gene in each of her cells to have recurrent hydatidiform mole pregnancies.
Core binding factor acute myeloid leukemia (CBF-AML) is one form of a cancer of the blood-forming tissue (bone marrow) called acute myeloid leukemia.
Acute myeloid leukemia occurs in approximately 3.
CBF-AML is associated with chromosomal rearrangements between chromosomes 8 and 21 and within chromosome 16.
CBF-AML is not inherited but arises from genetic rearrangements in the body's cells that occur after conception.
Gillespie syndrome is a disorder that involves eye abnormalities, problems with balance and coordinating movements (ataxia), and mild to moderate intellectual disability.
The prevalence of Gillespie syndrome is unknown.
Gillespie syndrome can be caused by mutations in the PAX6 gene.

In some cases, including those in which Gillespie syndrome is caused by PAX6 gene mutations, the condition occurs in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pachyonychia congenita is a condition that primarily affects the nails and skin.
Although the prevalence of pachyonychia congenita is unknown, it appears to be rare.
Mutations in several genes, including KRT6A, KRT6B, KRT6C, KRT16, and KRT17, can cause pachyonychia congenita.
Pachyonychia congenita is considered an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Lattice corneal dystrophy type II is characterized by an accumulation of protein clumps called amyloid deposits in tissues throughout the body.
Lattice corneal dystrophy type II is a rare condition; however, the prevalence is unknown.
Lattice corneal dystrophy type II is caused by mutations in the GSN gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Nager syndrome is a rare condition that mainly affects the development of the face, hands, and arms.
Nager syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
The cause of Nager syndrome is unknown.
Most cases of Nager syndrome are sporadic, which means that they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Meier-Gorlin syndrome is a condition primarily characterized by short stature.
Meier-Gorlin syndrome is a rare condition; however, its prevalence is unknown.
Meier-Gorlin syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of several genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Proopiomelanocortin (POMC) deficiency causes severe obesity that begins at an early age.
POMC deficiency is a rare condition; approximately 50 cases have been reported in the medical literature.
POMC deficiency is caused by mutations in the POMC gene, which provides instructions for making the proopiomelanocortin protein.
POMC deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Leukoencephalopathy with vanishing white matter is a progressive disorder that mainly affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system).
The prevalence of leukoencephalopathy with vanishing white matter is unknown.
Mutations in the EIF2B1, EIF2B2, EIF2B3, EIF2B4, and EIF2B5 genes cause leukoencephalopathy with vanishing white matter.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Capillary malformation-arteriovenous malformation syndrome (CM-AVM) is a disorder of the vascular system, which is the body's complex network of blood vessels.
CM-AVM is thought to occur in at least 1 in 100,000 people of northern European origin.
CM-AVM is caused by mutations in the RASA1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
6q24-related transient neonatal diabetes mellitus is a type of diabetes that occurs in infants.
Between 1 in 215,000 and 1 in 400,000 babies are born with diabetes mellitus.
6q24-related transient neonatal diabetes mellitus is caused by the overactivity (overexpression) of certain genes in a region of the long (q) arm of chromosome 6 called 6q24.
Most cases of 6q24-related transient neonatal diabetes mellitus are not inherited, particularly those caused by paternal uniparental disomy.
Nonbullous congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (NBCIE) is a condition that mainly affects the skin.
NBCIE is estimated to affect 1 in 200,000 to 300,000 individuals in the United States.
Mutations in at least three genes can cause NBCIE.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Type 1 diabetes is a disorder characterized by abnormally high blood sugar levels.
Type 1 diabetes occurs in 10 to 20 per 100,000 people per year in the United States.
The causes of type 1 diabetes are unknown, although several risk factors have been identified.
A predisposition to develop type 1 diabetes is passed through generations in families, but the inheritance pattern is unknown.
Campomelic dysplasia is a severe disorder that affects development of the skeleton, reproductive system, and other parts of the body.
The prevalence of campomelic dysplasia is uncertain; estimates range from 1 in 40,000 to 200,000 people.
Mutations in or near the SOX9 gene cause campomelic dysplasia.
Campomelic dysplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glycogen storage disease type 0 (also known as GSD 0) is a condition caused by the body's inability to form a complex sugar called glycogen, which is a major source of stored energy in the body.
The prevalence of GSD 0 is unknown; fewer than 10 people with the muscle type and fewer than 30 people with the liver type have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the GYS1 gene cause muscle GSD 0, and mutations in the GYS2 gene cause liver GSD 0.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Congenital fiber-type disproportion is a condition that primarily affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles used for movement.
Congenital fiber-type disproportion is thought to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in multiple genes can cause congenital fiber-type disproportion.
Congenital fiber-type disproportion can have multiple inheritance patterns.
Type A insulin resistance syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by severe insulin resistance, a condition in which the body's tissues and organs do not respond properly to the hormone insulin.
Type A insulin resistance syndrome is estimated to affect about 1 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Type A insulin resistance syndrome results from mutations in the INSR gene.
Type A insulin resistance syndrome can have either an autosomal dominant or, less commonly, an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
Long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) deficiency is a rare condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats to energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
The incidence of LCHAD deficiency is unknown.
Mutations in the HADHA gene cause LCHAD deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Optic atrophy type 1 is a condition that affects vision.
Optic atrophy type 1 is estimated to affect 1 in 50,000 people worldwide.
Optic atrophy type 1 is caused by mutations in the OPA1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Geleophysic dysplasia is an inherited condition that affects many parts of the body.
Geleophysic dysplasia is a rare disorder whose prevalence is unknown.
Geleophysic dysplasia results from mutations in the ADAMTSL2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type V (HSAN5) is a condition that primarily affects the sensory nerve cells (sensory neurons), which transmit information about sensations such as pain, temperature, and touch.
HSAN5 is very rare.
Mutations in the NGF gene cause HSAN5.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cardiofaciocutaneous syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body, particularly the heart (cardio-), facial features (facio-), and the skin and hair (cutaneous).
Cardiofaciocutaneous syndrome is a very rare condition whose incidence is unknown.
Cardiofaciocutaneous syndrome can be caused by mutations in several genes.
Cardiofaciocutaneous syndrome is considered to be an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
UV-sensitive syndrome is a condition that is characterized by sensitivity to the ultraviolet (UV) rays in sunlight.
UV-sensitive syndrome appears to be a rare condition; only a small number of affected individuals have been reported in the scientific literature.
UV-sensitive syndrome can result from mutations in the ERCC6 gene (also known as the CSB gene), the ERCC8 gene (also known as the CSA gene), or the UVSSA gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
PDGFRA-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is a form of blood cell cancer characterized by an elevated number of cells called eosinophils in the blood.
PDGFRA-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is a rare condition; however, the exact prevalence is unknown.
PDGFRA-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is caused by mutations in the PDGFRA gene.
PDGFRA-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia is not inherited and occurs in people with no history of the condition in their families.
Tay-Sachs disease is a rare inherited disorder that progressively destroys nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and spinal cord.
Tay-Sachs disease is very rare in the general population.
Mutations in the HEXA gene cause Tay-Sachs disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Fryns syndrome is a condition that affects the development of many parts of the body.
The worldwide incidence of Fryns syndrome is unknown.
The cause of Fryns syndrome is unknown.
Fryns syndrome appears to be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of a gene in each cell have mutations.
Malonyl-CoA decarboxylase deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats to energy.
This condition is very rare; fewer than 30 cases have been reported.
Mutations in the MLYCD gene cause malonyl-CoA decarboxylase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Sick sinus syndrome (also known as sinus node dysfunction) is a group of related heart conditions that can affect how the heart beats.
Sick sinus syndrome accounts for 1 in 600 patients with heart disease who are over age 65.
Sick sinus syndrome can result from genetic or environmental factors.
Most cases of sick sinus syndrome are not inherited.
GM3 synthase deficiency is characterized by recurrent seizures (epilepsy) and problems with brain development.
GM3 synthase deficiency appears to be a rare condition.
Mutations in the ST3GAL5 gene have been found to cause GM3 synthase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myhre syndrome is a condition with features affecting many systems and functions of the body.
Myhre syndrome is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the SMAD4 gene cause Myhre syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
ADCY5-related dyskinesia is a movement disorder; the term "dyskinesia" refers to abnormal involuntary movements.
The prevalence of ADCY5-related dyskinesia is unknown.
As its name suggests, ADCY5-related dyskinesia is caused by mutations in the ADCY5 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Shwachman-Diamond syndrome is an inherited condition that affects many parts of the body, particularly the bone marrow, pancreas, and skeletal system.
Researchers are not sure how common Shwachman-Diamond syndrome is.
Mutations in the SBDS gene have been identified in about 90 percent of people with the characteristic features of Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Essential tremor is a movement disorder that causes involuntary, rhythmic shaking (tremor), especially in the hands.
Essential tremor is a common disorder, affecting up to 10 million people in the United States.
The causes of essential tremor are unknown.
Essential tremor can be passed through generations in families, but the inheritance pattern varies.
Spastic paraplegia type 7 is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
The prevalence of all hereditary spastic paraplegias combined is estimated to be 2 to 6 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the SPG7 gene cause spastic paraplegia type 7.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Muscular dystrophies are a group of genetic conditions characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting (atrophy).
Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies together affect 1 in 3,500 to 5,000 newborn males worldwide.
Mutations in the DMD gene cause the Duchenne and Becker forms of muscular dystrophy.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Combined pituitary hormone deficiency is a condition that causes a shortage (deficiency) of several hormones produced by the pituitary gland, which is located at the base of the brain.
The prevalence of combined pituitary hormone deficiency is estimated to be 1 in 8,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in at least eight genes have been found to cause combined pituitary hormone deficiency.
Most cases of combined pituitary hormone deficiency are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a group of progressive disorders that affect the peripheral nerves.
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is the most common inherited disorder that involves the peripheral nerves, affecting an estimated 150,000 people in the United States.
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is caused by mutations in many different genes.
The pattern of inheritance varies with the type of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.
Hypophosphatasia is an inherited disorder that affects the development of bones and teeth.
Severe forms of hypophosphatasia affect an estimated 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the ALPL gene cause hypophosphatasia.
The severe forms of hypophosphatasia that appear early in life are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Supravalvular aortic stenosis (SVAS) is a heart defect that develops before birth.
SVAS occurs in 1 in 20,000 newborns worldwide.
Mutations in the ELN gene cause SVAS.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Epidermolytic hyperkeratosis is a skin disorder that is present at birth.
Epidermolytic hyperkeratosis affects approximately 1 in 200,000 to 300,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the KRT1 or KRT10 genes are responsible for epidermolytic hyperkeratosis.
Epidermolytic hyperkeratosis can have different inheritance patterns.
Progressive familial heart block is a genetic condition that alters the normal beating of the heart.
The prevalence of progressive familial heart block is unknown.
Mutations in the SCN5A and TRPM4 genes cause most cases of progressive familial heart block types IA and IB, respectively.
Progressive familial heart block types I and II are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Fucosidosis is a condition that affects many areas of the body, especially the brain.
Fucosidosis is a rare condition; approximately 100 cases have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the FUCA1 gene cause fucosidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Alzheimer disease is a degenerative disease of the brain that causes dementia, which is a gradual loss of memory, judgment, and ability to function.
Alzheimer disease currently affects an estimated 2.
Most cases of early-onset Alzheimer disease are caused by gene mutations that can be passed from parent to child.
The early-onset form of Alzheimer disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Centronuclear myopathy is a condition characterized by muscle weakness (myopathy) and wasting (atrophy) in the skeletal muscles, which are the muscles used for movement.
Centronuclear myopathy is a rare condition; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Centronuclear myopathy is most often caused by mutations in the DNM2, BIN1, or TTN gene.

When centronuclear myopathy is caused by mutations in the DNM2 gene, it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered DNM2 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glutathione synthetase deficiency is a disorder that prevents the production of an important molecule called glutathione.
Glutathione synthetase deficiency is very rare.
Mutations in the GSS gene cause glutathione synthetase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Koolen-de Vries syndrome is a disorder characterized by developmental delay and mild to moderate intellectual disability.
The prevalence of Koolen-de Vries syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 16,000.
Koolen-de Vries syndrome is caused by genetic changes that eliminate the function of one copy of the KANSL1 gene in each cell.
Koolen-de Vries syndrome is considered an autosomal dominant condition because a deletion or mutation affecting one copy of the KANSL1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Williams syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Williams syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 7,500 to 10,000 people.
Williams syndrome is caused by the deletion of genetic material from a specific region of chromosome 7.
Most cases of Williams syndrome are not inherited but occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs or sperm) in a parent of an affected individual.
Juvenile primary osteoporosis is a skeletal disorder characterized by thinning of the bones (osteoporosis) that begins in childhood.
The prevalence of juvenile primary osteoporosis is unknown.
Mutations in the LRP5 gene can cause juvenile primary osteoporosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Acatalasemia is a condition characterized by very low levels of an enzyme called catalase.
More than 100 cases of acatalasemia have been reported in the medical literature.
Mutations in the CAT gene can cause acatalasemia.
Acatalasemia has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the CAT gene in each cell have mutations.
Kuskokwim syndrome is characterized by joint deformities called contractures that restrict the movement of affected joints.
Kuskokwim syndrome is extremely rare.
Kuskokwim syndrome is caused by mutations in the FKBP10 gene, which provides instructions for making the FKBP10 protein (formerly known as FKBP65).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ankylosing spondylitis is a form of ongoing joint inflammation (chronic inflammatory arthritis) that primarily affects the spine.
Ankylosing spondylitis is part of a group of related diseases known as spondyloarthropathies.
Ankylosing spondylitis is likely caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, most of which have not been identified.
Although ankylosing spondylitis can occur in more than one person in a family, it is not a purely genetic disease.
Renal tubular acidosis with deafness is a disorder characterized by kidney (renal) problems and hearing loss.
Renal tubular acidosis with deafness is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Renal tubular acidosis with deafness is caused by mutations in the ATP6V1B1 or ATP6V0A4 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Anhidrotic ectodermal dysplasia with immune deficiency (EDA-ID) is a form of ectodermal dysplasia, which is a group of conditions characterized by abnormal development of ectodermal tissues including the skin, hair, teeth, and sweat glands.
The prevalence of the X-linked recessive type of EDA-ID is estimated to be 1 in 250,000 individuals.
Mutations in the IKBKG gene cause X-linked recessive EDA-ID, and mutations in the NFKBIA gene cause autosomal dominant EDA-ID.
When EDA-ID is caused by mutations in the IKBKG gene, it is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
McLeod neuroacanthocytosis syndrome is primarily a neurological disorder that occurs almost exclusively in boys and men.
McLeod neuroacanthocytosis syndrome is rare; approximately 150 cases have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the XK gene cause McLeod neuroacanthocytosis syndrome.
McLeod neuroacanthocytosis syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Alagille syndrome is a genetic disorder that can affect the liver, heart, and other parts of the body.
The estimated prevalence of Alagille syndrome is 1 in 70,000 newborns.
In more than 90 percent of cases, mutations in the JAG1 gene cause Alagille syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered or deleted gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Nicolaides-Baraitser syndrome is a condition that affects many body systems.
Nicolaides-Baraitser syndrome is likely a rare condition; approximately 75 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
Nicolaides-Baraitser syndrome is caused by mutations in the SMARCA2 gene.
Nicolaides-Baraitser syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Laryngo-onycho-cutaneous (LOC) syndrome is a disorder that leads to abnormalities of the voicebox (laryngo-), finger- and toenails (onycho-), and skin (cutaneous).
LOC syndrome is a rare disorder that primarily affects families of Punjabi background from India and Pakistan, although the condition has also been reported in one family from Iran.
LOC syndrome is caused by mutations in the LAMA3 gene, which provides instructions for making one part (subunit) of a protein called laminin 332.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA is a condition characterized by nerve abnormalities in the legs and feet (peripheral neuropathy).
Hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA is a rare condition; its prevalence is estimated to be 1 to 2 per 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the SPTLC1 gene cause hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
SYNGAP1-related intellectual disability is a neurological disorder characterized by moderate to severe intellectual disability that is evident in early childhood.
SYNGAP1-related intellectual disability is a relatively common form of cognitive impairment.
SYNGAP1-related intellectual disability is caused by mutations in the SYNGAP1 gene.
SYNGAP1-related intellectual disability is classified as an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hypomyelination and congenital cataract is an inherited condition that affects the nervous system and the eyes.
The prevalence of hypomyelination and congenital cataract is unknown.
Mutations in the FAM126A gene cause hypomyelination and congenital cataract.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

ALG12-congenital disorder of glycosylation (ALG12-CDG, also known as congenital disorder of glycosylation type Ig) is an inherited disorder with varying signs and symptoms that can affect several body systems.
ALG12-CDG is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ALG12 gene cause ALG12-CDG.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is a disorder of water balance.
Neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is thought to be rare, although its exact incidence is unknown.
The familial form of neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is caused by mutations in the AVP gene.

Familial neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus is almost always inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered AVP gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Parkes Weber syndrome is a disorder of the vascular system, which is the body's complex network of blood vessels.
Parkes Weber syndrome is a rare condition; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Some cases of Parkes Weber syndrome result from mutations in the RASA1 gene.
Most cases of Parkes Weber syndrome occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.
5q minus (5q-) syndrome is a type of bone marrow disorder called myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).
MDS affects nearly 1 in 20,000 people in the United States.
5q- syndrome is caused by deletion of a region of DNA from the long (q) arm of chromosome 5.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from a mutation in the body's cells that occurs after conception.
Lafora progressive myoclonus epilepsy is a brain disorder characterized by recurrent seizures (epilepsy) and a decline in intellectual function.
The prevalence of Lafora progressive myoclonus epilepsy is unknown.
Lafora progressive myoclonus epilepsy can be caused by mutations in either the EPM2A gene or the NHLRC1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ring chromosome 20 syndrome is a condition that affects the normal development and function of the brain.
Ring chromosome 20 syndrome appears to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Ring chromosome 20 syndrome is caused by a chromosomal abnormality known as a ring chromosome 20 or r(20).
Ring chromosome 20 syndrome is almost never inherited.
Char syndrome is a condition that affects the development of the face, heart, and limbs.
Char syndrome is rare, although its exact incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the TFAP2B gene cause Char syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Fragile XE syndrome is a genetic disorder that impairs thinking ability and cognitive functioning.
Fragile XE syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 25,000 to 100,000 newborn males.
Fragile XE syndrome is caused by mutations in the AFF2 gene.
Fragile XE syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Sotos syndrome is a disorder characterized by a distinctive facial appearance, overgrowth in childhood, and learning disabilities or delayed development of mental and movement abilities.
Sotos syndrome is reported to occur in 1 in 10,000 to 14,000 newborns.
Mutations in the NSD1 gene are the primary cause of Sotos syndrome, accounting for up to 90 percent of cases.
About 95 percent of Sotos syndrome cases occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Infantile neuroaxonal dystrophy is a disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
Infantile neuroaxonal dystrophy is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the PLA2G6 gene have been identified in most individuals with infantile neuroaxonal dystrophy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tibial muscular dystrophy is a condition that affects the muscles at the front of the lower leg.
Tibial muscular dystrophy is most common in Finland, where it is estimated to affect at least 10 per 100,000 people.
Mutations in the TTN gene cause tibial muscular dystrophy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Familial pityriasis rubra pilaris is a rare genetic condition that affects the skin.
Familial pityriasis rubra pilaris is a rare condition.
In most cases of pityriasis rubra pilaris, the cause of the condition is unknown.
Familial pityriasis rubra pilaris usually has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hypochromic microcytic anemia with iron overload is a condition that impairs the normal transport of iron in cells.
Hypochromic microcytic anemia with iron overload is likely a rare disorder; at least five affected families have been reported in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the SLC11A2 gene cause hypochromic microcytic anemia with iron overload.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Congenital cataracts, facial dysmorphism, and neuropathy (CCFDN) is a rare disorder that affects several parts of the body.
The prevalence of CCFDN is unknown.
A mutation in the CTDP1 gene causes CCFDN.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Costeff syndrome is a condition characterized by vision loss, movement problems, and intellectual disability.
Costeff syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 10,000 individuals in the Iraqi Jewish population, in which at least 40 cases have been described.
Mutations in the OPA3 gene cause Costeff syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia syndrome is a rare condition characterized by hearing loss, diabetes, and a blood disorder called megaloblastic anemia.
Thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia syndrome has been reported in approximately 30 families worldwide.
Mutations in the SLC19A2 gene cause thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Sheldon-Hall syndrome, also known as distal arthrogryposis type 2B, is a disorder characterized by joint deformities (contractures) that restrict movement in the hands and feet.
The prevalence of Sheldon-Hall syndrome is unknown; however, it is thought to be the most common type of distal arthrogryposis.
Sheldon-Hall syndrome can be caused by mutations in the MYH3, TNNI2, TNNT3, or TPM2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Cholesteryl ester storage disease is a rare inherited condition involving the breakdown and use of fats and cholesterol in the body (lipid metabolism).
Cholesteryl ester storage disease appears to be a rare disorder.
Mutations in the LIPA gene cause cholesteryl ester storage disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a defect in the diaphragm.
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia affects approximately 1 in 2,500 newborns.
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia has many different causes.
Isolated congenital diaphragmatic hernia is rarely inherited.
Common variable immune deficiency (CVID) is a disorder that impairs the immune system.
CVID is estimated to affect 1 in 25,000 to 1 in 50,000 people worldwide, although the prevalence can vary across different populations.
CVID is believed to result from mutations in genes that are involved in the development and function of immune system cells called B cells.
Most cases of CVID are sporadic and occur in people with no apparent history of the disorder in their family.
Juvenile hyaline fibromatosis is a disorder that affects the skin, joints, and bones.
The prevalence of juvenile hyaline fibromatosis is unknown.
Mutations in the ANTXR2 gene (also known as the CMG2 gene) cause juvenile hyaline fibromatosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Infantile-onset ascending hereditary spastic paralysis is one of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
Infantile-onset ascending hereditary spastic paralysis is a rare disorder, with at least 30 cases reported in the scientific literature.
Infantile-onset ascending hereditary spastic paralysis is caused by mutations in the ALS2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Frontotemporal dementia with parkinsonism-17 (FTDP-17) is a progressive brain disorder that affects behavior, language, and movement.
The worldwide prevalence of FTDP-17 is unknown.
FTDP-17 is caused by mutations in the MAPT gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Autosomal recessive spastic ataxia of Charlevoix-Saguenay, more commonly known as ARSACS, is a condition affecting muscle movement.
The incidence of ARSACS in the Charlevoix-Saguenay region of Quebec is estimated to be 1 in 1,500 to 2,000 individuals.
Mutations in the SACS gene cause ARSACS.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Acromicric dysplasia is a condition characterized by severely short stature, short limbs, stiff joints, and distinctive facial features.
Acromicric dysplasia is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Acromicric dysplasia is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, which provides instructions for making a large protein called fibrillin-1.
Acromicric dysplasia is an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Chorea-acanthocytosis is primarily a neurological disorder that affects movement in many parts of the body.
It is estimated that 500 to 1,000 people worldwide have chorea-acanthocytosis.
Mutations in the VPS13A gene cause chorea-acanthocytosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cranioectodermal dysplasia is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Cranioectodermal dysplasia is a rare condition with an unknown prevalence.
Cranioectodermal dysplasia is caused by mutations in one of at least four genes: the WDR35, IFT122, WDR19, or IFT43 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked immunodeficiency with magnesium defect, Epstein-Barr virus infection, and neoplasia (typically known by the acronym XMEN) is a disorder that affects the immune system in males.
The prevalence of XMEN is unknown.
XMEN is caused by mutations in the MAGT1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Aminoacylase 1 deficiency is an inherited disorder that can cause neurological problems; the pattern and severity of signs and symptoms vary widely among affected individuals.
The prevalence of aminoacylase 1 deficiency is unknown.
Aminoacylase 1 deficiency is caused by mutations in the ACY1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mannose-binding lectin deficiency is a condition that affects the immune system.

Mannose-binding lectin deficiency is thought to affect approximately 5 to 10 percent of people worldwide; however, many affected individuals have no signs or symptoms related to low mannose-binding lectin levels.
Relatively common mutations in the MBL2 gene can lead to mannose-binding lectin deficiency.
The inheritance pattern of mannose-binding lectin deficiency is unclear.
Infantile systemic hyalinosis is a disorder that severely affects many areas of the body, including the skin, joints, bones, and internal organs.
The prevalence of infantile systemic hyalinosis is unknown.
Mutations in the ANTXR2 gene (also known as the CMG2 gene) cause infantile systemic hyalinosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Polycythemia vera is a condition characterized by an increased number of red blood cells in the bloodstream.
The prevalence of polycythemia vera varies worldwide.
Mutations in the JAK2 and TET2 genes are associated with polycythemia vera.
Most cases of polycythemia vera are not inherited.
Autosomal recessive congenital methemoglobinemia is an inherited condition that mainly affects the function of red blood cells.
The incidence of autosomal recessive congenital methemoglobinemia is unknown.
Autosomal recessive congenital methemoglobinemia is caused by mutations in the CYB5R3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hystrix-like ichthyosis with deafness (HID) is a disorder characterized by dry, scaly skin (ichthyosis) and hearing loss that is usually profound.
HID is a rare disorder.
HID is caused by mutations in the GJB2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
48,XXYY syndrome is a chromosomal condition that causes medical and behavioral problems in males.
48,XXYY syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 18,000 to 50,000 males.
48,XXYY syndrome is a condition related to the X and Y chromosomes (the sex chromosomes).
This condition is not inherited; it usually occurs as a random event during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm).
X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia tarda is a condition that impairs bone growth and occurs almost exclusively in males.
The prevalence of X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia tarda is estimated to be 1 in 150,000 to 200,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the TRAPPC2 gene (often called the SEDL gene) cause X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia tarda.
X-linked spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia tarda is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a condition that causes vision problems.
The late-onset form of Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a common condition, affecting approximately 4 percent of people over the age of 40.
The genetics of Fuchs endothelial dystrophy are unclear.
In some cases, Fuchs endothelial dystrophy appears to be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Weyers acrofacial dysostosis is a disorder that affects the development of the teeth, nails, and bones.
Weyers acrofacial dysostosis appears to be a rare disorder.
Most cases of Weyers acrofacial dysostosis result from mutations in the EVC2 gene.
Weyers acrofacial dysostosis is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered EVC or EVC2 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Phenylketonuria (commonly known as PKU) is an inherited disorder that increases the levels of a substance called phenylalanine in the blood.
The occurrence of PKU varies among ethnic groups and geographic regions worldwide.
Mutations in the PAH gene cause phenylketonuria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Retinitis pigmentosa is a group of related eye disorders that cause progressive vision loss.
Retinitis pigmentosa is one of the most common inherited diseases of the retina (retinopathies).
Mutations in more than 60 genes are known to cause nonsyndromic retinitis pigmentosa.
Retinitis pigmentosa often has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Stormorken syndrome is a rare condition that affects many body systems.
Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder.
Stormorken syndrome is caused by a mutation in the STIM1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Down syndrome is a chromosomal condition that is associated with intellectual disability, a characteristic facial appearance, and weak muscle tone (hypotonia) in infancy.
Down syndrome occurs in about 1 in 800 newborns.
Most cases of Down syndrome result from trisomy 21, which means each cell in the body has three copies of chromosome 21 instead of the usual two copies.
Most cases of Down syndrome are not inherited.
Desmosterolosis is a condition that is characterized by neurological problems, such as brain abnormalities and developmental delay, and can also include other signs and symptoms.
The prevalence of desmosterolosis is unknown; at least 10 affected individuals have been described in the scientific literature.
Desmosterolosis is caused by mutations in the DHCR24 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Kufs disease is a condition that primarily affects the nervous system, causing problems with movement and intellectual function that worsen over time.
Collectively, all forms of NCL affect an estimated 1 in 100,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the CLN6 or PPT1 gene cause Kufs disease type A, and mutations in the DNAJC5 or CTSF gene cause Kufs disease type B.
Kufs disease type A, caused by mutations in the CLN6 or PPT1 gene, has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

COG5-congenital disorder of glycosylation (COG5-CDG, formerly known as congenital disorder of glycosylation type IIi) is an inherited condition that causes neurological problems and other abnormalities.
COG5-CDG is a very rare disorder; fewer than 10 cases have been described in the medical literature.
COG5-CDG is caused by mutations in the COG5 gene, which provides instructions for making one piece of a group of proteins known as the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG) complex.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Nephronophthisis is a disorder that affects the kidneys.
Nephronophthisis is found in populations worldwide.
Nephronophthisis has several genetic causes, which are used to split the condition into distinct types.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an inherited disorder characterized by cancer of the large intestine (colon) and rectum.
The reported incidence of familial adenomatous polyposis varies from 1 in 7,000 to 1 in 22,000 individuals.
Mutations in the APC gene cause both classic and attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis.
Familial adenomatous polyposis can have different inheritance patterns.
Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II (CPT II) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from using certain fats for energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
CPT II deficiency is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the CPT2 gene cause CPT II deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked thrombocytopenia is a bleeding disorder that primarily affects males.
The estimated incidence of X-linked thrombocytopenia is between 1 and 10 per million males worldwide; this condition is rarer among females.
Mutations in the WAS gene cause X-linked thrombocytopenia.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Hereditary cerebral amyloid angiopathy is a condition that can cause a progressive loss of intellectual function (dementia), stroke, and other neurological problems starting in mid-adulthood.
The prevalence of hereditary cerebral amyloid angiopathy is unknown.
Mutations in the APP gene are the most common cause of hereditary cerebral amyloid angiopathy.

Hereditary cerebral amyloid angiopathy caused by mutations in the APP, CST3, or ITM2B gene is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glycogen storage disease type III (also known as GSDIII or Cori disease) is an inherited disorder caused by the buildup of a complex sugar called glycogen in the body's cells.
The incidence of GSDIII in the United States is 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the AGL gene cause GSDIII.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Van der Woude syndrome is a condition that affects the development of the face.
Van der Woude syndrome is believed to occur in 1 in 35,000 to 1 in 100,000 people, based on data from Europe and Asia.
Mutations in the IRF6 gene cause van der Woude syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Benign familial neonatal seizures (BFNS) is a condition characterized by recurrent seizures in newborn babies.
Benign familial neonatal seizures occurs in approximately 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in two genes, KCNQ2 and KCNQ3, have been found to cause BFNS.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy is a condition that chiefly affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles) and heart (cardiac) muscle.
