X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy is the most common form of this condition, affecting an estimated 1 in 100,000 people.
Mutations in the EMD and LMNA genes cause Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy.
Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy can have several different patterns of inheritance.
Most people tested for the 16p11.
People with 16p11.
Glaucoma is a group of eye disorders in which the optic nerves connecting the eyes and the brain are progressively damaged.
Primary congenital glaucoma affects approximately 1 in 10,000 people.
Approximately 10 percent to 33 percent of people with juvenile open-angle glaucoma have mutations in the MYOC gene.
Early-onset glaucoma can have different inheritance patterns.
Very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (VLCAD) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats to energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
VLCAD deficiency is estimated to affect 1 in 40,000 to 120,000 people.
Mutations in the ACADVL gene cause VLCAD deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial HDL deficiency is a condition characterized by low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood.
Familial HDL deficiency is a rare disorder, although the prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ABCA1 gene or the APOA1 gene cause familial HDL deficiency.
Familial HDL deficiency is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means an alteration in one copy of either the ABCA1 or the APOA1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
The combination of intrauterine growth restriction, metaphyseal dysplasia, adrenal hypoplasia congenita, and genital anomalies is commonly known by the acronym IMAGe.
IMAGe syndrome is very rare, with only about 20 cases reported in the medical literature.
IMAGe syndrome is caused by mutations in the CDKN1C gene.
The inheritance of IMAGe syndrome is complex.
Distal hereditary motor neuropathy, type II is a progressive disorder that affects nerve cells in the spinal cord.
The prevalence of distal hereditary motor neuropathy, type II is unknown.
Mutations in the HSPB1 and HSPB8 genes cause distal hereditary motor neuropathy, type II.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Primary hyperoxaluria is a rare condition characterized by recurrent kidney and bladder stones.
Primary hyperoxaluria is estimated to affect 1 in 58,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the AGXT, GRHPR, and HOGA1 genes cause primary hyperoxaluria types 1, 2, and 3, respectively.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary angiopathy with nephropathy, aneurysms, and muscle cramps (HANAC) syndrome is part of a group of conditions called the COL4A1-related disorders.
HANAC syndrome is a rare condition, although the exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the COL4A1 gene cause HANAC syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
African iron overload is a condition that involves absorption of too much iron from the diet.
African iron overload is common in rural areas of central and southern Africa; up to 10 percent of the population in these regions may be affected.

African iron overload was first noted in rural central and southern African populations among people who drink a traditional beer brewed in uncoated steel drums that allow iron (a component of steel) to leach into the beer.
African iron overload seems to run in families, and high iron in a family's diet seems to be the major contributor to development of the condition.
Partington syndrome is a neurological disorder that causes intellectual disability along with a condition called focal dystonia that particularly affects movement of the hands.
The prevalence of Partington syndrome is unknown.
Partington syndrome is caused by mutations in the ARX gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Congenital deafness with labyrinthine aplasia, microtia, and microdontia (also called LAMM syndrome) is a condition that affects development of the ears and teeth.
LAMM syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
LAMM syndrome is caused by mutations in the FGF3 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called fibroblast growth factor 3 (FGF3).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myosin storage myopathy is a condition that causes muscle weakness (myopathy) that does not worsen or worsens very slowly over time.
Myosin storage myopathy is a rare condition.
Mutations in the MYH7 gene cause myosin storage myopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Citrullinemia is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia and other toxic substances to accumulate in the blood.
Type I citrullinemia is the most common form of the disorder, affecting about 1 in 57,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the ASS1 and SLC25A13 genes cause citrullinemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome is a condition that results in malformations of the eyes, hands, and feet.
The prevalence of ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome is not known; approximately 35 cases have been reported in the medical literature.
Mutations in the SMOC1 gene cause ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Spastic paraplegia type 2 is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
The prevalence of all hereditary spastic paraplegias combined is estimated to be 2 to 6 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the PLP1 gene cause spastic paraplegia 2.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
2-hydroxyglutaric aciduria is a condition that causes progressive damage to the brain.
2-hydroxyglutaric aciduria is a rare disorder.
The different types of 2-hydroxyglutaric aciduria result from mutations in several genes.
D-2-HGA type I, L-2-HGA, and combined D,L-2-HGA all have an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Robinow syndrome is a rare disorder that affects the development of many parts of the body, particularly the bones.
Both the autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant forms of Robinow syndrome are rare.
Autosomal recessive Robinow syndrome results from mutations in the ROR2 gene.
As discussed above, Robinow syndrome can have either an autosomal recessive or an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by a large head size (macrocephaly), multiple noncancerous tumors and tumor-like growths called hamartomas, and dark freckles on the penis in males.
The prevalence of Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome is unknown, although it appears to be rare.
About 60 percent of all cases of Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome result from mutations in the PTEN gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Aromatic l-amino acid decarboxylase (AADC) deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects the way signals are passed between certain cells in the nervous system.
AADC deficiency is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the DDC gene cause AADC deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tubular aggregate myopathy is a disorder that primarily affects the skeletal muscles, which are muscles the body uses for movement.
Tubular aggregate myopathy is a rare disorder.
Tubular aggregate myopathy can be caused by mutations in the STIM1 gene.
Most cases of tubular aggregate myopathy, including those caused by STIM1 gene mutations, are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Arginine:glycine amidinotransferase deficiency is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the brain.
The prevalence of arginine:glycine amidinotransferase deficiency is unknown.
Mutations in the GATM gene cause arginine:glycine amidinotransferase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tangier disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood.
Tangier disease is a rare disorder with approximately 100 cases identified worldwide.
Mutations in the ABCA1 gene cause Tangier disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Prekallikrein deficiency is a blood condition that usually causes no health problems.
The prevalence of prekallikrein deficiency is unknown.
Prekallikrein deficiency is caused by mutations in the KLKB1 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called prekallikrein.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Congenital generalized lipodystrophy (also called Berardinelli-Seip congenital lipodystrophy) is a rare condition characterized by an almost total lack of fatty (adipose) tissue in the body and a very muscular appearance.
Congenital generalized lipodystrophy has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 10 million people worldwide.
Mutations in the AGPAT2, BSCL2, CAV1, and PTRF genes cause congenital generalized lipodystrophy types 1 through 4, respectively.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged-red fibers (MERRF) is a disorder that affects many parts of the body, particularly the muscles and nervous system.
MERRF is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the MT-TK gene are the most common cause of MERRF, occurring in more than 80 percent of all cases.
MERRF is inherited in a mitochondrial pattern, which is also known as maternal inheritance.
Multiminicore disease is a disorder that primarily affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
Multiminicore disease is thought to be a rare disorder, although its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the RYR1 and SEPN1 genes cause multiminicore disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Episodic ataxia is a group of related conditions that affect the nervous system and cause problems with movement.
Episodic ataxia is uncommon, affecting less than 1 in 100,000 people.
Episodic ataxia can be caused by mutations in several genes that play important roles in the nervous system.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is characterized by the buildup of a chemical called lactic acid in the body and a variety of neurological problems.
Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is believed to be a rare condition; however, its prevalence is unknown.
The genes involved in pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency each provide instructions for making a protein that is a component of a group of proteins called the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.
Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency can have different inheritance patterns.
Phosphoglycerate mutase deficiency is a disorder that primarily affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
Phosphoglycerate mutase deficiency is a rare condition; about 15 affected people have been reported in the medical literature.
Phosphoglycerate mutase deficiency is caused by mutations in the PGAM2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the PGAM2 gene in each cell have mutations.
Lenz microphthalmia syndrome is a condition characterized by abnormal development of the eyes and several other parts of the body.
Lenz microphthalmia syndrome is a very rare condition; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in at least two genes on the X chromosome are thought to be responsible for Lenz microphthalmia syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Prader-Willi syndrome is a complex genetic condition that affects many parts of the body.
Prader-Willi syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 10,000 to 30,000 people worldwide.
Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the loss of function of genes in a particular region of chromosome 15.
Most cases of Prader-Willi syndrome are not inherited, particularly those caused by a deletion in the paternal chromosome 15 or by maternal uniparental disomy.
Parkinson disease is a progressive disorder of the nervous system.
Parkinson disease affects more than 1 million people in North America and more than 4 million people worldwide.
Most cases of Parkinson disease probably result from a complex interaction of environmental and genetic factors.
Most cases of Parkinson disease occur in people with no apparent family history of the disorder.
Alpha thalassemia X-linked intellectual disability syndrome is an inherited disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Alpha thalassemia X-linked intellectual disability syndrome appears to be a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Alpha thalassemia X-linked intellectual disability syndrome results from mutations in the ATRX gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome is a disease that primarily affects kidney function.
The incidence of atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 500,000 people per year in the United States.
Atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome often results from a combination of environmental and genetic factors.
Most cases of atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome are sporadic, which means that they occur in people with no apparent history of the disorder in their family.

ALG1-congenital disorder of glycosylation (ALG1-CDG, also known as congenital disorder of glycosylation type Ik) is an inherited disorder with varying signs and symptoms that typically develop during infancy and can affect several body systems.
ALG1-CDG appears to be a rare disorder; fewer than 30 affected individuals have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the ALG1 gene cause ALG1-CDG.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Intestinal pseudo-obstruction is a condition characterized by impairment of the muscle contractions that move food through the digestive tract.
Primary intestinal pseudo-obstruction is a rare disorder.
In some individuals with primary intestinal pseudo-obstruction, the condition is caused by mutations in the FLNA gene.
Intestinal pseudo-obstruction is often not inherited.
Autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia is a disorder that affects the peripheral nerves.
Autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia is a rare form of inherited peripheral neuropathy.
Autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia is caused by mutations in the HINT1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Ataxia-telangiectasia is a rare inherited disorder that affects the nervous system, immune system, and other body systems.
Ataxia-telangiectasia occurs in 1 in 40,000 to 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the ATM gene cause ataxia-telangiectasia.
Ataxia-telangiectasia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the ATM gene in each cell have mutations.
Choroideremia is a condition characterized by progressive vision loss that mainly affects males.
The prevalence of choroideremia is estimated to be 1 in 50,000 to 100,000 people.
Mutations in the CHM gene cause choroideremia.
Choroideremia is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (PVOD) is characterized by the blockage (occlusion) of the blood vessels that carry oxygen-rich (oxygenated) blood from the lungs to the heart (the pulmonary veins).
The exact prevalence of PVOD is unknown.
The primary genetic cause of PVOD is mutations in the EIF2AK4 gene.
When caused by mutations in the EIF2AK4 gene, PVOD is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is an inherited condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats to energy, particularly during prolonged periods without food (fasting).
The exact incidence of 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is unknown; it has been reported in only a small number of people worldwide.
Mutations in the HADH gene cause 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Distal arthrogryposis type 1 is a disorder characterized by joint deformities (contractures) that restrict movement in the hands and feet.
Distal arthrogryposis type 1 affects an estimated 1 in 10,000 people worldwide.
Distal arthrogryposis type 1 can be caused by mutations in at least two genes: TPM2 and MYBPC1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Saethre-Chotzen syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis).
Saethre-Chotzen syndrome has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 25,000 to 50,000 people.
Mutations in the TWIST1 gene cause Saethre-Chotzen syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Mucolipidosis III gamma is a slowly progressive disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Mucolipidosis III gamma is a rare disorder, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the GNPTG gene cause mucolipidosis III gamma.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neonatal onset multisystem inflammatory disease (NOMID) is a disorder that causes persistent inflammation and tissue damage primarily affecting the nervous system, skin, and joints.
NOMID is a very rare disorder; approximately 100 affected individuals have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the NLRP3 gene (also known as CIAS1) cause NOMID.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Ewing sarcoma is a cancerous tumor that occurs in bones or soft tissues, such as cartilage or nerves.
Approximately 3 per 1 million children each year are diagnosed with a Ewing sarcoma.
The most common mutation that causes Ewing sarcoma involves two genes, the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from a mutation in the body's cells that occurs after conception.
Otopalatodigital syndrome type 1 is a disorder primarily involving abnormalities in skeletal development.
Otopalatodigital syndrome type 1 is a rare disorder, affecting fewer than 1 in every 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the FLNA gene cause otopalatodigital syndrome type 1.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Autoimmune Addison disease affects the function of the adrenal glands, which are small hormone-producing glands located on top of each kidney.
Addison disease affects approximately 11 to 14 in 100,000 people of European descent.
The cause of autoimmune Addison disease is complex and not completely understood.
A predisposition to develop autoimmune Addison disease is passed through generations in families, but the inheritance pattern is unknown.
Gorlin syndrome, also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, is a condition that affects many areas of the body and increases the risk of developing various cancerous and noncancerous tumors.
Gorlin syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 31,000 people.
Mutations in the PTCH1 gene cause Gorlin syndrome.
Gorlin syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.
Familial hemiplegic migraine is a form of migraine headache that runs in families.
The worldwide prevalence of familial hemiplegic migraine is unknown.
Mutations in the CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A, and PRRT2 genes have been found to cause familial hemiplegic migraine.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Protein S deficiency is a disorder of blood clotting.
Mild protein S deficiency is estimated to occur in approximately 1 in 500 individuals.
Protein S deficiency is caused by mutations in the PROS1 gene.
Protein S deficiency is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one altered copy of the PROS1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause mild protein S deficiency.
Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that disrupts the normal sleep-wake cycle.
Narcolepsy affects about 1 in 2,000 people in the United States and Western Europe.
Narcolepsy probably results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors, some of which have been identified, but many of which remain unknown.
Most cases of narcolepsy are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Troyer syndrome is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
About 20 cases of Troyer syndrome have been reported in the Old Order Amish population of Ohio.
Troyer syndrome is caused by a mutation in the SPG20 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism type II (MOPDII) is a condition characterized by short stature (dwarfism) with other skeletal abnormalities (osteodysplasia) and an unusually small head size (microcephaly).
MOPDII appears to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the PCNT gene cause MOPDII.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Genitopatellar syndrome is a rare condition characterized by genital abnormalities, missing or underdeveloped kneecaps (patellae), intellectual disability, and abnormalities affecting other parts of the body.
Genitopatellar syndrome is estimated to occur in fewer than 1 per million people.
Genitopatellar syndrome is caused by mutations in the KAT6B gene.
This condition has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive disease that affects motor neurons, which are specialized nerve cells that control muscle movement.
About 5,000 people in the United States are diagnosed with ALS each year.
Mutations in several genes can cause familial ALS and contribute to the development of sporadic ALS.
About 90 to 95 percent of ALS cases are sporadic, which means they are not inherited.
Giant congenital melanocytic nevus is a skin condition characterized by an abnormally dark, noncancerous skin patch (nevus) that is composed of pigment-producing cells called melanocytes.
Giant congenital melanocytic nevus occurs in approximately 1 in 20,000 newborns worldwide.
NRAS gene mutations cause most cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevus.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from a mutation in the body's cells that occurs after conception.

Cartilage-hair hypoplasia is a disorder of bone growth characterized by short stature (dwarfism) with other skeletal abnormalities; fine, sparse hair (hypotrichosis); and abnormal immune system function (immune deficiency) that can lead to recurrent infections.
Cartilage-hair hypoplasia occurs most often in the Old Order Amish population, where it affects about 1 in 1,300 newborns.
Cartilage-hair hypoplasia is caused by mutations in the RMRP gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Buschke-Ollendorff syndrome is a hereditary disorder of connective tissues, which are tissues that provide strength and flexibility to structures throughout the body.
Buschke-Ollendorff syndrome has an estimated incidence of 1 in 20,000 people worldwide.
Buschke-Ollendorff syndrome results from mutations in the LEMD3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a condition that causes inflammation that primarily affects the respiratory tract (including the lungs and airways) and the kidneys.
GPA is a rare disorder that affects an estimated 3 in 100,000 people in the United States.
The genetic basis of GPA is not well understood.
The inheritance pattern of GPA is unknown.
SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis is a kidney (renal) disorder that sometimes includes blood cell abnormalities.
The prevalence of SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis is unknown.
Both the autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive forms of SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis are caused by mutations in the SLC4A1 gene.
SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis can have different patterns of inheritance.
Infantile-onset spinocerebellar ataxia (IOSCA) is a progressive disorder that affects the nervous system.
More than 20 individuals with IOSCA have been identified in Finland.
Mutations in the C10orf2 gene cause IOSCA.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Androgenetic alopecia is a common form of hair loss in both men and women.
Androgenetic alopecia is a frequent cause of hair loss in both men and women.
A variety of genetic and environmental factors likely play a role in causing androgenetic alopecia.
The inheritance pattern of androgenetic alopecia is unclear because many genetic and environmental factors are likely to be involved.
Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis is an abnormal curvature of the spine that appears in late childhood or adolescence.
Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis is the most common spinal abnormality in children.
The term "idiopathic" means that the cause of this condition is unknown.
Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis can be sporadic, which means it occurs in people without a family history of the condition, or it can cluster in families.
Polycystic lipomembranous osteodysplasia with sclerosing leukoencephalopathy, commonly known as PLOSL, is a progressive disorder that affects the bones and brain.
PLOSL is a very rare condition.
Mutations in the TREM2 gene or the TYROBP gene (also called DAP12) can cause PLOSL.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Aromatase excess syndrome is a condition characterized by elevated levels of the female sex hormone estrogen in both males and females.
The prevalence of aromatase excess syndrome is unknown; more than 20 cases have been described in the medical literature.
Rearrangements of genetic material involving the CYP19A1 gene cause aromatase excess syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means a genetic rearrangement involving one copy of the CYP19A1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Juvenile primary lateral sclerosis is a rare disorder characterized by progressive weakness and tightness (spasticity) of muscles in the arms, legs, and face.
Juvenile primary lateral sclerosis is a rare disorder, with few reported cases.
Mutations in the ALS2 gene cause most cases of juvenile primary lateral sclerosis.
When caused by mutations in the ALS2 gene, juvenile primary lateral sclerosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myasthenia gravis is a disorder that causes weakness of the skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
Myasthenia gravis affects about 20 per 100,000 people worldwide.
Researchers believe that variations in particular genes may increase the risk of myasthenia gravis, but the identity of these genes is unknown.
In most cases, myasthenia gravis is not inherited and occurs in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Familial isolated pituitary adenoma (FIPA) is an inherited condition characterized by development of a noncancerous tumor in the pituitary gland (called a pituitary adenoma).
Pituitary adenomas, including sporadic tumors, are relatively common; they are identified in an estimated 1 in 1,000 people.
FIPA can be caused by mutations in the AIP gene.
FIPA is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Dopamine beta ()-hydroxylase deficiency is a condition that affects the autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary body processes such as the regulation of blood pressure and body temperature.
Dopamine -hydroxylase deficiency is a very rare disorder.
Mutations in the DBH gene cause dopamine -hydroxylase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to use the vitamin biotin effectively.
The exact incidence of this condition is unknown, but it is estimated to affect 1 in 87,000 people.
Mutations in the HLCS gene cause holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myoclonic epilepsy myopathy sensory ataxia, commonly called MEMSA, is part of a group of conditions called the POLG-related disorders.
The prevalence of myoclonic epilepsy myopathy sensory ataxia is unknown.
MEMSA is caused by mutations in the POLG gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Salih myopathy is an inherited muscle disease that affects the skeletal muscles, which are used for movement, and the heart (cardiac) muscle.
Salih myopathy appears to be a rare disorder, although its prevalence is unknown.
Salih myopathy is caused by mutations in the TTN gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Keratoderma with woolly hair is a group of related conditions that affect the skin and hair and in many cases increase the risk of potentially life-threatening heart problems.
Keratoderma with woolly hair is rare; its prevalence worldwide is unknown.
Mutations in the JUP, DSP, DSC2, and KANK2 genes cause keratoderma with woolly hair types I through IV, respectively.
Most cases of keratoderma with woolly hair have an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Progressive osseous heteroplasia is a disorder in which bone forms within skin and muscle tissue.
Progressive osseous heteroplasia is a rare condition.
Progressive osseous heteroplasia is caused by a mutation in the GNAS gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Miller-Dieker syndrome is a condition characterized by a pattern of abnormal brain development known as lissencephaly.
Miller-Dieker syndrome appears to be a rare disorder, although its prevalence is unknown.
Miller-Dieker syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material near the end of the short (p) arm of chromosome 17.
Most cases of Miller-Dieker syndrome are not inherited.
Congenital insensitivity to pain with anhidrosis (CIPA) has two characteristic features: the inability to feel pain and temperature, and decreased or absent sweating (anhidrosis).
CIPA is a rare condition; however, the prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the NTRK1 gene cause CIPA.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hypochondrogenesis is a rare, severe disorder of bone growth.
Hypochondrogenesis and achondrogenesis, type 2 (a similar skeletal disorder) together affect 1 in 40,000 to 60,000 newborns.
Hypochondrogenesis is one of the most severe conditions in a spectrum of disorders caused by mutations in the COL2A1 gene.
Hypochondrogenesis is considered an autosomal dominant disorder because one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition.
Krabbe disease (also called globoid cell leukodystrophy) is a degenerative disorder that affects the nervous system.
In the United States, Krabbe disease affects about 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in the GALC gene cause Krabbe disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Septo-optic dysplasia is a disorder of early brain development.
Septo-optic dysplasia has a reported incidence of 1 in 10,000 newborns.
In most cases of septo-optic dysplasia, the cause of the disorder is unknown.
Septo-optic dysplasia is usually sporadic, which means that the condition typically occurs in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Spondylothoracic dysostosis is a condition characterized by the malformation of the bones of the spine and ribs.
Spondylothoracic dysostosis affects about one in 200,000 people worldwide.
The MESP2 gene provides instructions for a protein that plays a critical role in the development of vertebrae.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial osteochondritis dissecans is a condition that affects the joints and is associated with abnormal cartilage.
Familial osteochondritis dissecans is a rare condition, although the prevalence is unknown.
Mutation of the ACAN gene can cause familial osteochondritis dissecans.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Sensorineural deafness and male infertility is a condition characterized by hearing loss and an inability to father children.
The prevalence of sensorineural deafness and male infertility is unknown.
Sensorineural deafness and male infertility is caused by a deletion of genetic material on the long (q) arm of chromosome 15.
Sensorineural deafness and male infertility is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of chromosome 15 in each cell have a deletion.
Unverricht-Lundborg disease is a rare inherited form of epilepsy.
Progressive myoclonus epilepsy is a rare condition.
Mutations in the CSTB gene cause Unverricht-Lundborg disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Bietti crystalline dystrophy is a disorder in which numerous small, yellow or white crystal-like deposits of fatty (lipid) compounds accumulate in the light-sensitive tissue that lines the back of the eye (the retina).
Bietti crystalline dystrophy has been estimated to occur in 1 in 67,000 people.
Bietti crystalline dystrophy is caused by mutations in the CYP4V2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Pallister-Killian mosaic syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Pallister-Killian mosaic syndrome appears to be a rare condition, although its exact prevalence is unknown.
Pallister-Killian mosaic syndrome is usually caused by the presence of an abnormal extra chromosome called an isochromosome 12p or i(12p).
Pallister-Killian mosaic syndrome is not inherited.
Central core disease is a disorder that affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
Central core disease is probably an uncommon condition, although its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the RYR1 gene cause central core disease.
Central core disease is most often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Naegeli-Franceschetti-Jadassohn syndrome/dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis (NFJS/DPR) represents a rare type of ectodermal dysplasia, a group of about 150 conditions characterized by abnormal development of ectodermal tissues including the skin, hair, nails, teeth, and sweat glands.
NFJS/DPR is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
NFJS/DPR results from mutations in the KRT14 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Fanconi anemia is a condition that affects many parts of the body.
Fanconi anemia occurs in 1 in 160,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in at least 15 genes can cause Fanconi anemia.
Fanconi anemia is most often inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
18q deletion syndrome is a chromosomal condition that results when a piece of chromosome 18 is missing.
18q deletion syndrome occurs in an estimated 1 in 40,000 newborns.
18q deletion syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material from the long (q) arm of chromosome 18.
Most cases of 18q deletion syndrome are not inherited.
X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is a genetic disorder that occurs primarily in males.
The prevalence of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is 1 in 20,000 to 50,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the ABCD1 gene cause X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy.
X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Familial restrictive cardiomyopathy is a genetic form of heart disease.
The prevalence of familial restrictive cardiomyopathy is unknown.
Mutations in several genes have been found to cause familial restrictive cardiomyopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Nail-patella syndrome is characterized by abnormalities of the nails, knees, elbows, and pelvis.
The prevalence of nail-patella syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 50,000 individuals.
Mutations in the LMX1B gene cause nail-patella syndrome.
Nail-patella syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Fraser syndrome is a rare disorder that affects development starting before birth.
Fraser syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 200,000 newborns.
Mutations in the FRAS1, FREM2, or GRIP1 gene can cause Fraser syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mayer-Rokitansky-Kster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a disorder that occurs in females and mainly affects the reproductive system.
MRKH syndrome affects approximately 1 in 4,500 newborn girls.
The cause of MRKH syndrome is unknown, although it probably results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of MRKH syndrome occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome is primarily an eye disorder, although it can also affect other parts of the body.
Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 200,000 people.
Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome results from mutations in at least two known genes, PITX2 and FOXC1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Spondylocarpotarsal synostosis syndrome is a disorder that affects the development of bones throughout the body.
Spondylocarpotarsal synostosis syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the FLNB gene cause spondylocarpotarsal synostosis syndrome.
Spondylocarpotarsal synostosis syndrome caused by FLNB gene mutations is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Paraganglioma is a type of noncancerous (benign) tumor that occurs in structures called paraganglia.
It is estimated that the prevalence of pheochromocytoma is 1 in 500,000 people, and the prevalence of other paragangliomas is 1 in 1 million people.
The VHL, RET, SDHB, and SDHD genes can be mutated in both syndromic and nonsyndromic forms of paraganglioma and pheochromocytoma.

Nonsyndromic paraganglioma can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing a paraganglioma or pheochromocytoma.
Hypomagnesemia with secondary hypocalcemia is an inherited condition caused by the body's inability to absorb and retain magnesium that is taken in through the diet.
Hypomagnesemia with secondary hypocalcemia is thought to be a rare condition, but its prevalence is unknown.
Hypomagnesemia with secondary hypocalcemia is caused by mutations in the TRPM6 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tetrasomy 18p is a chromosomal condition that affects many parts of the body.
Tetrasomy 18p is a rare disorder.
Tetrasomy 18p results from the presence of an abnormal extra chromosome, called an isochromosome 18p, in each cell.
Tetrasomy 18p is usually not inherited.
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 (SCA3) is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement.
The prevalence of SCA3 is unknown.
Mutations in the ATXN3 gene cause SCA3.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Inherited thyroxine-binding globulin deficiency is a genetic condition that typically does not cause any health problems.
The complete form of inherited thyroxine-binding globulin deficiency, TBG-CD, affects about 1 in 15,000 newborns worldwide.
Inherited thyroxine-binding globulin deficiency results from mutations in the SERPINA7 gene.
Inherited thyroxine-binding globulin deficiency has an X-linked pattern of inheritance.
Lysinuric protein intolerance is a disorder caused by the body's inability to digest and use certain protein building blocks (amino acids), namely lysine, arginine, and ornithine.
Lysinuric protein intolerance is estimated to occur in 1 in 60,000 newborns in Finland and 1 in 57,000 newborns in Japan.
Mutations in the SLC7A7 gene cause lysinuric protein intolerance.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Marfan syndrome is a disorder that affects the connective tissue in many parts of the body.
The incidence of Marfan syndrome is approximately 1 in 5,000 worldwide.
Mutations in the FBN1 gene cause Marfan syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic, progressive lung disease.
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis has an estimated prevalence of 13 to 20 per 100,000 people worldwide.
The cause of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is unknown, although the disease probably results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis are sporadic; they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Blau syndrome is an inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the skin, joints, and eyes.
Although Blau syndrome appears to be uncommon, its prevalence is unknown.
Blau syndrome results from mutations in the NOD2 gene.
Blau syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
McKusick-Kaufman syndrome is a condition that affects the development of the hands and feet, heart, and reproductive system.
This condition was first described in the Old Order Amish population, where it affects an estimated 1 in 10,000 people.
Mutations in the MKKS gene cause McKusick-Kaufman syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Caffey disease, also called infantile cortical hyperostosis, is a bone disorder that most often occurs in babies.
Caffey disease has been estimated to occur in approximately 3 per 1,000 infants worldwide.
A mutation in the COL1A1 gene causes Caffey disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is usually sufficient to cause the disorder.
Argininosuccinic aciduria is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood.
Argininosuccinic aciduria occurs in approximately 1 in 70,000 newborns.
Mutations in the ASL gene cause argininosuccinic aciduria.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial dysautonomia is a genetic disorder that affects the development and survival of certain nerve cells.
Familial dysautonomia occurs primarily in people of Ashkenazi (central or eastern European) Jewish descent.
Mutations in the IKBKAP gene cause familial dysautonomia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dandy-Walker malformation affects brain development, primarily development of the cerebellum, which is the part of the brain that coordinates movement.
Dandy-Walker malformation is estimated to affect 1 in 10,000 to 30,000 newborns.
Researchers have found mutations in a few genes that are thought to cause Dandy-Walker malformation, but these mutations account for only a small number of cases.
Most cases of Dandy-Walker malformation are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.

Danon disease is a condition characterized by weakening of the heart muscle (cardiomyopathy); weakening of the muscles used for movement, called skeletal muscles, (myopathy); and intellectual disability.
Danon disease is a rare condition, but the exact prevalence is unknown.
Danon disease is caused by mutations in the LAMP2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

Craniometaphyseal dysplasia is a rare condition characterized by progressive thickening of bones in the skull (cranium) and abnormalities at the ends of long bones in the limbs (metaphyseal dysplasia).
Craniometaphyseal dysplasia is a very rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the ANKH gene cause autosomal dominant craniometaphyseal dysplasia.
Craniometaphyseal dysplasia can have different inheritance patterns.
Waldenstrm macroglobulinemia is a rare blood cell cancer characterized by an excess of abnormal white blood cells called lymphoplasmacytic cells in the bone marrow.
Waldenstrm macroglobulinemia affects an estimated 3 per million people each year in the United States.
Waldenstrm macroglobulinemia is thought to result from a combination of genetic changes.
Waldenstrm macroglobulinemia is usually not inherited, and most affected people have no history of the disorder in their family.
Ghosal hematodiaphyseal dysplasia is a rare inherited condition characterized by abnormally thick bones and a shortage of red blood cells (anemia).
Ghosal hematodiaphyseal dysplasia is a rare disorder; only a few cases have been reported in the medical literature.
Ghosal hematodiaphyseal dysplasia results from mutations in the TBXAS1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Most people with a 15q13.

Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthetase superactivity (PRS superactivity) is characterized by the overproduction and accumulation of uric acid (a waste product of normal chemical processes) in the blood and urine.
PRS superactivity is believed to be a rare disorder.
Certain mutations in the PRPS1 gene cause PRS superactivity.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Neutral lipid storage disease with myopathy is a condition in which fats (lipids) are stored abnormally in organs and tissues throughout the body.
Neutral lipid storage disease with myopathy is a rare condition; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the PNPLA2 gene cause neutral lipid storage disease with myopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency is a disorder of hormone production.
The prevalence of cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency is unknown.
Cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency is caused by mutations in the POR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Langer mesomelic dysplasia is a disorder of bone growth.
The prevalence of Langer mesomelic dysplasia is unknown, although the condition appears to be rare.
Langer mesomelic dysplasia results from changes involving the SHOX gene.
Langer mesomelic dysplasia has a pseudoautosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
Ochoa syndrome is a disorder characterized by urinary problems and unusual facial expressions.
Ochoa syndrome is a rare disorder.
Ochoa syndrome can be caused by mutations in the HPSE2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
5-alpha reductase deficiency is a condition that affects male sexual development before birth and during puberty.
5-alpha reductase deficiency is a rare condition; the exact incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the SRD5A2 gene cause 5-alpha reductase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the SRD5A2 gene in each cell have mutations.
Pendred syndrome is a disorder typically associated with hearing loss and a thyroid condition called a goiter.
The prevalence of Pendred syndrome is unknown.
Mutations in the SLC26A4 gene cause about half of all cases of Pendred syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neurofibromatosis type 2 is a disorder characterized by the growth of noncancerous tumors in the nervous system.
Neurofibromatosis type 2 has an estimated incidence of 1 in 33,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the NF2 gene cause neurofibromatosis type 2.
Neurofibromatosis type 2 is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
Mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalopathy (MNGIE) disease is a condition that affects several parts of the body, particularly the digestive system and nervous system.
The prevalence of MNGIE disease is unknown.
Mutations in the TYMP gene (previously known as ECGF1) cause MNGIE disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the TYMP gene in each cell have mutations.
Corticosteroid-binding globulin deficiency is a condition with subtle signs and symptoms, the most frequent being extreme tiredness (fatigue), especially after physical exertion.
The prevalence of corticosteroid-binding globulin deficiency is unknown, but it is thought to be a rare disorder.
Mutations in the SERPINA6 gene cause corticosteroid-binding globulin deficiency.
This condition is reported to have an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia is one of many types of anemia, which is a group of conditions characterized by a shortage of healthy red blood cells.
Although iron deficiency anemia is relatively common, the prevalence of the iron-refractory form of the disease is unknown.
Mutations in the TMPRSS6 gene cause iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency is a condition characterized by significantly reduced activity of an enzyme that helps the body process drugs called thiopurines.
Studies suggest that less than 1 percent of individuals in the general population have TPMT deficiency.
TPMT deficiency results from changes in the TPMT gene.
The activity of the TPMT enzyme is inherited in a pattern described as autosomal codominant.
Progressive external ophthalmoplegia is a condition characterized by weakness of the eye muscles.
The prevalence of progressive external ophthalmoplegia is unknown.
Progressive external ophthalmoplegia is a condition caused by defects in mitochondria, which are structures within cells that use oxygen to convert the energy from food into a form cells can use.
Progressive external ophthalmoplegia can have different inheritance patterns depending on the gene involved.
Alveolar capillary dysplasia with misalignment of pulmonary veins (ACD/MPV) is a disorder affecting the development of the lungs and their blood vessels.
ACD/MPV is a rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
ACD/MPV can be caused by mutations in the FOXF1 gene.
ACD/MPV is usually not inherited, and most affected people have no history of the disorder in their family.
Diastrophic dysplasia is a disorder of cartilage and bone development.
Although the exact incidence of this condition is unknown, researchers estimate that it affects about 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Diastrophic dysplasia is one of several skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the SLC26A2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Primary carnitine deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from using certain fats for energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
The incidence of primary carnitine deficiency in the general population is approximately 1 in 100,000 newborns.
Mutations in the SLC22A5 gene cause primary carnitine deficiency.
Primary carnitine deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Inclusion body myopathy 2 is a condition that primarily affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
More than 200 people with inclusion body myopathy 2 have been reported.
Mutations in the GNE gene cause inclusion body myopathy 2.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Lactate dehydrogenase deficiency is a condition that affects how the body breaks down sugar to use as energy in cells, primarily muscle cells.
Lactate dehydrogenase deficiency is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the LDHA gene cause lactate dehydrogenase-A deficiency, and mutations in the LDHB gene cause lactate dehydrogenase-B deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Kallmann syndrome is a condition characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell.
Kallmann syndrome is estimated to affect 1 in 10,000 to 86,000 people and occurs more often in males than in females.
Mutations in the ANOS1, FGFR1, PROKR2, and PROK2 genes cause Kallmann syndrome.
Kallmann syndrome 1 (caused by ANOS1 gene mutations) has an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.
Bardet-Biedl syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
In most of North America and Europe, Bardet-Biedl syndrome has a prevalence of 1 in 140,000 to 1 in 160,000 newborns.
Bardet-Biedl syndrome can result from mutations in at least 14 different genes (often called BBS genes).
Bardet-Biedl syndrome is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of a BBS gene in each cell have mutations.

3-beta ()-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (HSD) deficiency is an inherited disorder that affects hormone-producing glands including the gonads (ovaries in females and testes in males) and the adrenal glands.
The exact prevalence of 3-HSD deficiency is unknown.
Mutations in the HSD3B2 gene cause 3-HSD deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Popliteal pterygium syndrome is a condition that affects the development of the face, skin, and genitals.
Popliteal pterygium syndrome is a rare condition, occurring in approximately 1 in 300,000 individuals.
Mutations in the IRF6 gene cause popliteal pterygium syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
White sponge nevus is a condition characterized by the formation of white patches of tissue called nevi (singular: nevus) that appear as thickened, velvety, sponge-like tissue.
The exact prevalence of white sponge nevus is unknown, but it is estimated to affect less than 1 in 200,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the KRT4 or KRT13 gene cause white sponge nevus.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell can be sufficient to cause the disorder.
Maffucci syndrome is a disorder that primarily affects the bones and skin.
Maffucci syndrome is very rare.
In most people with Maffucci syndrome, the disorder is caused by mutations in the IDH1 or IDH2 gene.
Maffucci syndrome is not inherited.
Hereditary antithrombin deficiency is a disorder of blood clotting.
Hereditary antithrombin deficiency is estimated to occur in about 1 in 2,000 to 3,000 individuals.
Hereditary antithrombin deficiency is caused by mutations in the SERPINC1 gene.
Hereditary antithrombin deficiency is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one altered copy of the SERPINC1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glycogen storage disease type V (also known as GSDV or McArdle disease) is an inherited disorder caused by an inability to break down a complex sugar called glycogen in muscle cells.
GSDV is a rare disorder; however, its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the PYGM gene cause GSDV.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
COL4A1-related brain small-vessel disease is part of a group of conditions called the COL4A1-related disorders.
COL4A1-related brain small-vessel disease is a rare condition, although the exact prevalence is unknown.
As the name suggests, mutations in the COL4A1 gene cause COL4A1-related brain small vessel disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Canavan disease is a rare inherited disorder that damages the ability of nerve cells (neurons) in the brain to send and receive messages.
While this condition occurs in people of all ethnic backgrounds, it is most common in people of Ashkenazi (eastern and central European) Jewish heritage.
Mutations in the ASPA gene cause Canavan disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Brugada syndrome is a condition that causes a disruption of the heart's normal rhythm.
The exact prevalence of Brugada syndrome is unknown, although it is estimated to affect 5 in 10,000 people worldwide.
Brugada syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of several genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

The Say-Barber-Biesecker-Young-Simpson (SBBYS) variant of Ohdo syndrome is a rare condition characterized by genital abnormalities in males, missing or underdeveloped kneecaps (patellae), intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and abnormalities affecting other parts of the body.
The SBBYS variant of Ohdo syndrome is estimated to occur in fewer than 1 per million people.
The SBBYS variant of Ohdo syndrome is caused by mutations in the KAT6B gene.
This condition has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
X-linked juvenile retinoschisis is a condition characterized by impaired vision that begins in childhood and occurs almost exclusively in males.
The prevalence of X-linked juvenile retinoschisis is estimated to be 1 in 5,000 to 25,000 men worldwide.
Mutations in the RS1 gene cause most cases of X-linked juvenile retinoschisis.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Bradyopsia is a rare condition that affects vision.
Bradyopsia appears to be rare.
Bradyopsia can be caused by mutations in the RGS9 gene or in the RGS9BP gene (which is also known as R9AP).
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Stargardt macular degeneration is a genetic eye disorder that causes progressive vision loss.
Stargardt macular degeneration is the most common form of juvenile macular degeneration, the signs and symptoms of which begin in childhood.
In most cases, Stargardt macular degeneration is caused by mutations in the ABCA4 gene.
Stargardt macular degeneration can have different inheritance patterns.
Essential pentosuria is a condition characterized by high levels of a sugar called L-xylulose in urine.
Essential pentosuria occurs almost exclusively in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry.
Essential pentosuria is caused by mutations in the DCXR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Leptin receptor deficiency is a condition that causes severe obesity beginning in the first few months of life.
The prevalence of leptin receptor deficiency is unknown.
Leptin receptor deficiency is caused by mutations in the LEPR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Loeys-Dietz syndrome is a disorder that affects the connective tissue in many parts of the body.
The prevalence of Loeys-Dietz syndrome is unknown.

The four types of Loeys-Dietz syndrome are distinguished by their genetic cause: mutations in the TGFBR1 gene cause type I, mutations in the TGFBR2 gene cause type II, mutations in the SMAD3 gene cause type III, and mutations in the TGFB2 gene cause type IV.
Loeys-Dietz syndrome is considered to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a disorder of water balance.
The prevalence of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is unknown, although the condition is thought to be rare.
The hereditary form of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus can be caused by mutations in at least two genes.
When nephrogenic diabetes insipidus results from mutations in the AVPR2 gene, the condition has an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.
Leukoencephalopathy with brainstem and spinal cord involvement and lactate elevation (commonly referred to as LBSL) is a progressive disorder that affects the brain and spinal cord.
LBSL is a rare condition.
LBSL is caused by mutations in the DARS2 gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called mitochondrial aspartyl-tRNA synthetase.
LBSL is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Waardenburg syndrome is a group of genetic conditions that can cause hearing loss and changes in coloring (pigmentation) of the hair, skin, and eyes.
Waardenburg syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 40,000 people.
Mutations in the EDN3, EDNRB, MITF, PAX3, SNAI2, and SOX10 genes can cause Waardenburg syndrome.
Waardenburg syndrome is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glutaric acidemia type I is an inherited disorder in which the body is unable to process certain proteins properly.
Glutaric acidemia type I occurs in approximately 1 of every 30,000 to 40,000 individuals.
Mutations in the GCDH gene cause glutaric acidemia type I.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Pseudohypoaldosteronism type 2 (PHA2) is caused by problems that affect regulation of the amount of sodium and potassium in the body.
PHA2 is a rare condition; however, the prevalence is unknown.
PHA2 can be caused by mutations in the WNK1, WNK4, CUL3, or KLHL3 gene.
This condition is usually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Nonsyndromic hearing loss is a partial or total loss of hearing that is not associated with other signs and symptoms.
Between 2 and 3 per 1,000 children in the United States are born with detectable hearing loss in one or both ears.
The causes of nonsyndromic hearing loss are complex.
As discussed above, nonsyndromic hearing loss has different patterns of inheritance.
Cap myopathy is a disorder that primarily affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
Cap myopathy is a rare disorder that has been identified in only a small number of individuals.
Mutations in the ACTA1, TPM2, or TPM3 genes can cause cap myopathy.
Cap myopathy is an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Donnai-Barrow syndrome is an inherited disorder that affects many parts of the body.
Although its prevalence is unknown, Donnai-Barrow syndrome appears to be a rare disorder.
Mutations in the LRP2 gene cause Donnai-Barrow syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Renal coloboma syndrome (also known as papillorenal syndrome) is a condition that primarily affects kidney (renal) and eye development.
The prevalence of renal coloboma syndrome is unknown; at least 60 cases have been reported in the scientific literature.
Renal coloboma syndrome is caused by mutations in the PAX2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Sjgren-Larsson syndrome is a condition characterized by dry, scaly skin (ichthyosis); neurological problems; and eye problems.
Sjgren-Larsson syndrome was first observed in Sweden, where the prevalence of this condition is 1 per 250,000 individuals.
Mutations in the ALDH3A2 gene cause Sjgren-Larsson syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
CHMP2B-related frontotemporal dementia is a progressive brain disorder that affects personality, behavior, and language.
CHMP2B-related frontotemporal dementia has been reported in one large family in Denmark and a few unrelated individuals from other countries.
CHMP2B-related frontotemporal dementia results from mutations in the CHMP2B gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency is a rare disorder characterized by a shortage (deficiency) of a molecule called tetrahydrobiopterin or BH4.
This condition is rare, affecting an estimated 1 in 500,000 to 1 in 1 million newborns.
Tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency can be caused by mutations in one of several genes, including GCH1, PCBD1, PTS, and QDPR.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Weissenbacher-Zweymller syndrome is a condition that affects bone growth.
Weissenbacher-Zweymller syndrome is very rare; only a few families with the disorder have been reported worldwide.
Mutations in the COL11A2 gene cause Weissenbacher-Zweymller syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Dystonia 6 is one of many forms of dystonia, which is a group of conditions characterized by involuntary movements, twisting (torsion) and tensing of various muscles, and unusual positioning of affected body parts.
The prevalence of dystonia 6 is unknown.
Dystonia 6 is caused by mutations in the THAP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell can be sufficient to cause the disorder.
Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy, also known as Kennedy disease, is a disorder of specialized nerve cells that control muscle movement (motor neurons).
This condition affects fewer than 1 in 150,000 males and is very rare in females.
Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy results from a particular type of mutation in the AR gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
MPV17-related hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome is an inherited disorder that can cause liver disease and neurological problems.
MPV17-related hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome is thought to be a rare condition.
As the condition name suggests, mutations in the MPV17 gene cause MPV17-related hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
CHARGE syndrome is a disorder that affects many areas of the body.
CHARGE syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 8,500 to 10,000 individuals.
Mutations in the CHD7 gene cause more than half of all cases of CHARGE syndrome.
CHARGE syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome is a blood cancer that involves different types of blood cells.
The prevalence of 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome is unknown.
8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome is caused by rearrangements of genetic material (translocations) between two chromosomes.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from a mutation in the body's cells that occurs after conception.
Hepatic lipase deficiency is a disorder that affects the body's ability to break down fats (lipids).
Hepatic lipase deficiency is likely a rare disorder; only a few affected families have been reported in the scientific literature.
Hepatic lipase deficiency is caused by mutations in the LIPC gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
C3 glomerulopathy is a group of related conditions that cause the kidneys to malfunction.
C3 glomerulopathy is very rare, affecting 1 to 2 per million people worldwide.
C3 glomerulopathy is associated with changes in many genes.
Most cases of C3 glomerulopathy are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.

Spina bifida is a condition in which the neural tube, a layer of cells that ultimately develops into the brain and spinal cord, fails to close completely during the first few weeks of embryonic development.
Spina bifida is one of the most common types of neural tube defect, affecting an estimated 1 in 2,500 newborns worldwide.
Spina bifida is a complex condition that is likely caused by the interaction of multiple genetic and environmental factors.
Most cases of spina bifida are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Mandibuloacral dysplasia is a condition that causes a variety of abnormalities involving bone development, skin coloring (pigmentation), and fat distribution.
Mandibuloacral dysplasia is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
The two forms of mandibuloacral dysplasia are caused by mutations in different genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mucopolysaccharidosis type VI (MPS VI), also known as Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome, is a progressive condition that causes many tissues and organs to enlarge and become inflamed or scarred.
The exact incidence of MPS VI is unknown, although it is estimated to occur in 1 in 250,000 to 600,000 newborns.
Mutations in the ARSB gene cause MPS VI.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Hereditary neuralgic amyotrophy is a disorder characterized by episodes of severe pain and muscle wasting (amyotrophy) in one or both shoulders and arms.
Hereditary neuralgic amyotrophy is a rare disorder, but its specific prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the SEPT9 gene cause hereditary neuralgic amyotrophy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Sialidosis is a severe inherited disorder that affects many organs and tissues, including the nervous system.
The overall prevalence of sialidosis is unknown.
Mutations in the NEU1 gene cause sialidosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tetra-amelia syndrome is a very rare disorder characterized by the absence of all four limbs.
Tetra-amelia syndrome has been reported in only a few families worldwide.
Researchers have found a mutation in the WNT3 gene in people with tetra-amelia syndrome from one large family.
In most of the families reported so far, tetra-amelia syndrome appears to have an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
Trichohepatoenteric syndrome is a condition that affects the hair (tricho-), liver (hepato-), and intestines (enteric), as well as other tissues and organs in the body.
Trichohepatoenteric syndrome is a rare condition with an estimated prevalence of about 1 in 1 million people.
Trichohepatoenteric syndrome can be caused by mutations in the TTC37 or SKIV2L gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Abetalipoproteinemia is an inherited disorder that affects the absorption of dietary fats, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins.
Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare disorder with approximately 100 cases described worldwide.
Mutations in the MTTP gene cause abetalipoproteinemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
X-linked intellectual disability, Siderius type is a condition characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability that affects only males.
While X-linked intellectual disability of all types and causes is relatively common, with a prevalence of 1 in 600 to 1,000 males, the prevalence of the Siderius type is unknown.
X-linked intellectual disability, Siderius type is caused by mutations in the PHF8 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Myofibrillar myopathy is part of a group of disorders called muscular dystrophies that affect muscle function and cause weakness.
The prevalence of myofibrillar myopathy is unknown.
Mutations in several genes can cause myofibrillar myopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Rotor syndrome is a relatively mild condition characterized by elevated levels of a substance called bilirubin in the blood (hyperbilirubinemia).
Rotor syndrome is a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
The SLCO1B1 and SLCO1B3 genes are involved in Rotor syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Bart-Pumphrey syndrome is characterized by nail and skin abnormalities and hearing loss.
Bart-Pumphrey syndrome is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Bart-Pumphrey syndrome is caused by mutations in the GJB2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Amish lethal microcephaly is a disorder in which infants are born with a very small head and underdeveloped brain.
Amish lethal microcephaly occurs in approximately 1 in 500 newborns in the Old Order Amish population of Pennsylvania.
Mutations in the SLC25A19 gene cause Amish lethal microcephaly.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Miyoshi myopathy is a muscle disorder that primarily affects muscles away from the center of the body (distal muscles), such as those in the legs.
The exact prevalence of Miyoshi myopathy is unknown.
Miyoshi myopathy is caused by mutations in the DYSF or ANO5 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
17-beta hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 3 deficiency is a condition that affects male sexual development.
17-beta hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 3 deficiency is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the HSD17B3 gene cause 17-beta hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 3 deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
A gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is a type of tumor that occurs in the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly in the stomach or small intestine.
Approximately 5,000 new cases of GIST are diagnosed in the United States each year.
Genetic changes in one of several genes are involved in the formation of GISTs.
Most cases of GIST are not inherited.
Recombinant 8 syndrome is a condition that involves heart and urinary tract abnormalities, moderate to severe intellectual disability, and a distinctive facial appearance.
Recombinant 8 syndrome is a rare condition; its exact incidence is unknown.
