Recombinant 8 syndrome is caused by a rearrangement of chromosome 8 that results in a deletion of a piece of the short (p) arm and a duplication of a piece of the long (q) arm.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the recombinant chromosome 8 in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Triple X syndrome, also called trisomy X or 47,XXX, is characterized by the presence of an additional X chromosome in each of a female's cells.
This condition occurs in about 1 in 1,000 newborn girls.
People normally have 46 chromosomes in each cell.
Most cases of triple X syndrome are not inherited.
Norrie disease is an inherited eye disorder that leads to blindness in male infants at birth or soon after birth.
Norrie disease is a rare disorder; its exact incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the NDP gene cause Norrie disease.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Sepiapterin reductase deficiency is a condition characterized by movement problems, most often a pattern of involuntary, sustained muscle contractions known as dystonia.
Sepiapterin reductase deficiency appears to be a rare condition.
Mutations in the SPR gene cause sepiapterin reductase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial acute myeloid leukemia with mutated CEBPA is one form of a cancer of the blood-forming tissue (bone marrow) called acute myeloid leukemia.
Acute myeloid leukemia occurs in approximately 3.
As its name suggests, familial acute myeloid leukemia with mutated CEBPA is caused by mutations in the CEBPA gene that are passed down within families.
Familial acute myeloid leukemia with mutated CEBPA is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
Carney complex is a disorder characterized by an increased risk of several types of tumors.
Carney complex is a rare disorder; fewer than 750 affected individuals have been identified.
Mutations in the PRKAR1A gene cause most cases of Carney complex.
Carney complex is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by the development of noncancerous growths called hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract (particularly the stomach and intestines) and a greatly increased risk of developing certain types of cancer.
The prevalence of this condition is uncertain; estimates range from 1 in 25,000 to 300,000 individuals.
Mutations in the STK11 gene (also known as LKB1) cause most cases of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of developing noncancerous polyps and cancerous tumors.
Congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency is a disorder that affects a person's ability to digest certain sugars.
The prevalence of congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency is estimated to be 1 in 5,000 people of European descent.
Mutations in the SI gene cause congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
An epidermal nevus (plural: nevi) is an abnormal, noncancerous (benign) patch of skin caused by an overgrowth of skin cells.
Epidermal nevi affect approximately 1 in 1,000 people.
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene have been found in approximately 30 percent of people with a type of nevus in the keratinocytic epidermal nevi group.
This condition is generally not inherited but arises from mutations in the body's cells that occur after conception.
Trisomy 18, also called Edwards syndrome, is a chromosomal condition associated with abnormalities in many parts of the body.
Trisomy 18 occurs in about 1 in 5,000 live-born infants; it is more common in pregnancy, but many affected fetuses do not survive to term.
Most cases of trisomy 18 result from having three copies of chromosome 18 in each cell in the body instead of the usual two copies.
Most cases of trisomy 18 are not inherited, but occur as random events during the formation of eggs and sperm.
Langer-Giedion syndrome is a condition that causes bone abnormalities and distinctive facial features.
Langer-Giedion syndrome is a rare condition; its incidence is unknown.
Langer-Giedion syndrome is caused by the deletion or mutation of at least two genes on chromosome 8.
Most cases of Langer-Giedion syndrome are not inherited, but occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs or sperm) in a parent of an affected individual.
Leigh syndrome is a severe neurological disorder that typically arises in the first year of life.
Leigh syndrome affects at least 1 in 40,000 newborns.
Leigh syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of over 30 different genes.
Leigh syndrome can have different inheritance patterns.
Heterotaxy syndrome is a condition in which the internal organs are abnormally arranged in the chest and abdomen.
The prevalence of heterotaxy syndrome is estimated to be 1 in 10,000 people worldwide.
Heterotaxy syndrome can be caused by mutations in many different genes.
Most often, heterotaxy syndrome is sporadic, meaning that only one person in a family is affected.
Congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens occurs in males when the tubes that carry sperm out of the testes (the vas deferens) fail to develop properly.
This condition is responsible for 1 percent to 2 percent of all infertility in men.
Mutations in the CFTR gene cause congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens.
When this condition is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, it is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Mitochondrial trifunctional protein deficiency is a rare condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats to energy, particularly during periods without food (fasting).
Mitochondrial trifunctional protein deficiency is a rare disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the HADHA and HADHB genes cause mitochondrial trifunctional protein deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Glycogen storage disease type I (also known as GSDI or von Gierke disease) is an inherited disorder caused by the buildup of a complex sugar called glycogen in the body's cells.
The overall incidence of GSDI is 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Mutations in two genes, G6PC and SLC37A4, cause GSDI.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (SCAD) deficiency is a condition that prevents the body from converting certain fats into energy, especially during periods without food (fasting).
This disorder is thought to affect approximately 1 in 35,000 to 50,000 newborns.
Mutations in the ACADS gene cause SCAD deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Refsum disease is an inherited condition that causes vision loss, absence of the sense of smell (anosmia), and a variety of other signs and symptoms.
The prevalence of Refsum disease is unknown, although the condition is thought to be uncommon.
More than 90 percent of all cases of Refsum disease result from mutations in the PHYH gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
DMD-associated dilated cardiomyopathy is a form of heart disease that is caused by mutations in the DMD gene.
DMD-associated dilated cardiomyopathy appears to be an uncommon condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
DMD-associated dilated cardiomyopathy results from mutations in the DMD gene.
DMD-associated dilated cardiomyopathy has an X-linked pattern of inheritance.
Sporadic hemiplegic migraine is a rare form of migraine headache.
The worldwide prevalence of sporadic hemiplegic migraine is unknown.
Mutations in the ATP1A2 and CACNA1A genes have been found to cause sporadic hemiplegic migraine.
Sporadic means that the condition occurs in individuals with no history of the disorder in their family.
Isolated Duane retraction syndrome is a disorder of eye movement.
Isolated Duane retraction syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 1,000 people worldwide.
In most people with isolated Duane retraction syndrome, the cause of the condition is unknown.
Isolated Duane retraction syndrome usually occurs in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
Farber lipogranulomatosis is a rare inherited condition involving the breakdown and use of fats in the body (lipid metabolism).
Farber lipogranulomatosis is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the ASAH1 gene cause Farber lipogranulomatosis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Oculofaciocardiodental (OFCD) syndrome is a condition that affects the development of the eyes (oculo-), facial features (facio-), heart (cardio-) and teeth (dental).
OFCD syndrome is very rare; the incidence is estimated to be less than 1 in 1 million people.
Mutations in the BCOR gene cause OFCD syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
VLDLR-associated cerebellar hypoplasia is an inherited condition that affects the development of the brain.
VLDLR-associated cerebellar hypoplasia is rare; its prevalence is unknown.
As its name suggests, VLDLR-associated cerebellar hypoplasia results from mutations in the VLDLR gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Coffin-Siris syndrome is a condition that affects several body systems.
Coffin-Siris syndrome is a rare condition that is diagnosed in females more frequently than in males.
Coffin-Siris syndrome is caused by mutations in the ARID1A, ARID1B, SMARCA4, SMARCB1, or SMARCE1 gene.
Coffin-Siris syndrome appears to follow an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hidradenitis suppurativa, also known as acne inversa, is a chronic skin disease characterized by recurrent boil-like lumps (nodules) under the skin.
Hidradenitis suppurativa was once thought to be a rare condition because only the most severe cases were reported.
In most cases, the cause of hidradenitis suppurativa is unknown.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has been reported to run in families.
GRN-related frontotemporal dementia is a progressive brain disorder that can affect behavior, language, and movement.
GRN-related frontotemporal dementia affects an estimated 3 to 15 per 100,000 people aged 45 to 64.
GRN-related frontotemporal dementia results from mutations in the GRN gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
IRAK-4 deficiency is an inherited disorder of the immune system (primary immunodeficiency).
IRAK-4 deficiency is a very rare condition, although the exact prevalence is unknown.
IRAK-4 deficiency is caused by mutations in the IRAK4 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein that plays an important role in stimulating the immune system to respond to infection.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

WAGR syndrome is a disorder that affects many body systems and is named for its main features: Wilms tumor, anirida, genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability (formerly referred to as mental retardation).
The prevalence of WAGR syndrome ranges from 1 in 500,000 to one million individuals.
WAGR syndrome is caused by a deletion of genetic material on the short (p) arm of chromosome 11.
Most cases of WAGR syndrome are not inherited.
Pontocerebellar hypoplasia is a group of related conditions that affect the development of the brain.
The prevalence of pontocerebellar hypoplasia is unknown, although most forms of the disorder appear to be very rare.
Pontocerebellar hypoplasia can result from mutations in several genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Imerslund-Grsbeck syndrome is a condition caused by low levels of vitamin B12 (also known as cobalamin).
Imerslund-Grsbeck syndrome is a rare condition that was first described in Finland and Norway; in these regions, the condition is estimated to affect 1 in 200,000 people.
Mutations in the AMN or CUBN gene can cause Imerslund-Grsbeck syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Fukuyama congenital muscular dystrophy is an inherited condition that predominantly affects the muscles, brain, and eyes.
Fukuyama congenital muscular dystrophy is seen almost exclusively in Japan, where it is the second most common form of childhood muscular dystrophy (after Duchenne muscular dystrophy).
Fukuyama congenital muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the FKTN gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Klinefelter syndrome is a chromosomal condition that affects male physical and cognitive development.
Klinefelter syndrome affects 1 in 500 to 1,000 newborn males.
Klinefelter syndrome is a condition related to the X and Y chromosomes (the sex chromosomes).
Klinefelter syndrome and its variants are not inherited; these chromosomal changes usually occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) in a parent.
Majeed syndrome is a rare condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and inflammation in the bones and skin.
Majeed syndrome appears to be very rare; it has been reported in three families, all from the Middle East.
Majeed syndrome results from mutations in the LPIN2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
L1 syndrome is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
L1 syndrome is estimated to occur in 1 in 25,000 to 60,000 males.
L1 syndrome is caused by mutations in the L1CAM gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Christianson syndrome is a disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
Christianson syndrome is a rare condition, although the exact prevalence is unknown.
Christianson syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC9A6 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called sodium/hydrogen exchanger 6 (Na+/H+ exchanger 6 or NHE6).
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is a condition that causes episodes of extreme muscle weakness typically beginning in childhood or adolescence.
Although its exact prevalence is unknown, hypokalemic periodic paralysis is estimated to affect 1 in 100,000 people.
Mutations in the CACNA1S and SCN4A genes cause hypokalemic periodic paralysis.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Townes-Brocks syndrome is a genetic condition that affects several parts of the body.
The prevalence of this condition is unknown, although one study estimated that it may affect 1 in 250,000 people.
Mutations in the SALL1 gene cause Townes-Brocks Syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Glycogen storage disease type IV (GSD IV) is an inherited disorder caused by the buildup of a complex sugar called glycogen in the body's cells.
GSD IV is estimated to occur in 1 in 600,000 to 800,000 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the GBE1 gene cause GSD IV.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Color vision deficiency (sometimes called color blindness) represents a group of conditions that affect the perception of color.
Red-green color vision defects are the most common form of color vision deficiency.
Mutations in the OPN1LW, OPN1MW, and OPN1SW genes cause the forms of color vision deficiency described above.
Red-green color vision defects and blue cone monochromacy are inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
X-linked creatine deficiency is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the brain.
The prevalence of X-linked creatine deficiency is unknown.
Mutations in the SLC6A8 gene cause X-linked creatine deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Coffin-Lowry syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body.
The incidence of this condition is uncertain, but researchers estimate that the disorder affects 1 in 40,000 to 50,000 people.
Mutations in the RPS6KA3 gene cause Coffin-Lowry syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the dramatic, rapid appearance of aging beginning in childhood.
This condition is very rare; it is reported to occur in 1 in 4 million newborns worldwide.
Mutations in the LMNA gene cause Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome.
Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome is considered an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Lattice corneal dystrophy type I is an eye disorder that affects the clear, outer covering of the eye called the cornea.

Lattice corneal dystrophy type I is one of the most common disorders in a group of conditions that are characterized by protein deposits in the cornea (corneal dystrophies); however, it is still a rare condition.
Lattice corneal dystrophy type I is caused by mutations in the TGFBI gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Emanuel syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that disrupts normal development and affects many parts of the body.
Emanuel syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Emanuel syndrome is caused by the presence of extra genetic material from chromosome 11 and chromosome 22 in each cell.
Almost everyone with Emanuel syndrome inherits the der(22) chromosome from an unaffected parent.
Congenital neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (NCL) is an inherited disorder that primarily affects the nervous system.
Congenital NCL is the rarest type of NCL; approximately 10 cases have been described.
Mutations in the CTSD gene cause congenital NCL.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Malignant hyperthermia is a severe reaction to particular drugs that are often used during surgery and other invasive procedures.
Malignant hyperthermia occurs in 1 in 5,000 to 50,000 instances in which people are given anesthetic gases.
Variations of the CACNA1S and RYR1 genes increase the risk of developing malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia susceptibility is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of a severe reaction to certain drugs used during surgery.
Small fiber neuropathy is a condition characterized by severe pain attacks that typically begin in the feet or hands.
The prevalence of small fiber neuropathy is unknown.
Mutations in the SCN9A or SCN10A gene can cause small fiber neuropathy.
Small fiber neuropathy is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered SCN9A gene or SCN10A gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hypermethioninemia is an excess of a particular protein building block (amino acid), called methionine, in the blood.
Primary hypermethioninemia that is not caused by other disorders or excess methionine intake appears to be rare; only a small number of cases have been reported.
Mutations in the AHCY, GNMT, and MAT1A genes cause hypermethioninemia.
Hypermethioninemia can have different inheritance patterns.
Chylomicron retention disease is an inherited disorder that affects the absorption of dietary fats, cholesterol, and certain fat-soluble vitamins.
Chylomicron retention disease is a rare condition with approximately 40 cases described worldwide.
Mutations in the SAR1B gene cause chylomicron retention disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neuromyelitis optica is an autoimmune disorder that affects the nerves of the eyes and the central nervous system, which includes the brain and spinal cord.
Neuromyelitis optica affects approximately 1 to 2 per 100,000 people worldwide.
No genes associated with neuromyelitis optica have been identified.
Neuromyelitis optica is usually not inherited.
Renal tubular dysgenesis is a severe kidney disorder characterized by abnormal development of the kidneys before birth.
Renal tubular dysgenesis is a rare disorder, but its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the ACE, AGT, AGTR1, or REN gene can cause renal tubular dysgenesis.
Renal tubular dysgenesis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the affected gene in each cell have mutations.
Crohn disease is a complex, chronic disorder that primarily affects the digestive system.
Crohn disease is most common in western Europe and North America, where it affects 100 to 150 in 100,000 people.
Crohn disease is related to chromosomes 5 and 10.
The inheritance pattern of Crohn disease is unclear because many genetic and environmental factors are likely to be involved.
Adiposis dolorosa is a condition characterized by painful folds of fatty (adipose) tissue or the growth of multiple noncancerous (benign) fatty tumors called lipomas.
Adiposis dolorosa is a rare condition whose prevalence is unknown.
The cause of adiposis dolorosa is unknown.
Most cases of adiposis dolorosa are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family.
CATSPER1-related nonsyndromic male infertility is a condition that affects the function of sperm, leading to an inability to father children.
The prevalence of CATSPER1-related nonsyndromic male infertility is unknown.
Mutations in the CATSPER1 gene cause CATSPER1-related nonsyndromic male infertility.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Aicardi-Goutieres syndrome is a disorder that mainly affects the brain, the immune system, and the skin.
Aicardi-Goutieres syndrome is a rare disorder.
Mutations in the TREX1, RNASEH2A, RNASEH2B, RNASEH2C, and SAMHD1 genes have been identified in people with Aicardi-Goutieres syndrome.
Aicardi-Goutieres syndrome can have different inheritance patterns.

Microcephaly-capillary malformation syndrome is an inherited disorder characterized by an abnormally small head size (microcephaly) and abnormalities of small blood vessels in the skin called capillaries (capillary malformations).
Microcephaly-capillary malformation syndrome is rare.
Microcephaly-capillary malformation syndrome results from mutations in the STAMBP gene.
This condition has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the STAMBP gene in each cell have mutations.
Atopic dermatitis (also known as atopic eczema) is a disorder characterized by inflammation of the skin (dermatitis).
Atopic dermatitis is a common disorder that affects 10 to 20 percent of children and 5 to 10 percent of adults.
The genetics of atopic dermatitis are not completely understood.
Allergic disorders tend to run in families; having a parent with atopic dermatitis, asthma, or hay fever raises the chances a person will develop atopic dermatitis.
Renal hypouricemia is a kidney (renal) disorder that results in a reduced amount of uric acid in the blood.
The prevalence of renal hypouricemia is unknown; at least 150 affected individuals have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the SLC22A12 or SLC2A9 gene cause renal hypouricemia.
This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the SLC22A12 or SLC2A9 gene in each cell have mutations.

3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA lyase deficiency (also known as HMG-CoA lyase deficiency) is an uncommon inherited disorder in which the body cannot process a particular protein building block (amino acid) called leucine.
HMG-CoA lyase deficiency is a rare condition; it has been reported in fewer than 100 individuals worldwide.
Mutations in the HMGCL gene cause HMG-CoA lyase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Poland syndrome is a disorder in which affected individuals are born with missing or underdeveloped muscles on one side of the body, resulting in abnormalities that can affect the chest, shoulder, arm, and hand.
Poland syndrome has been estimated to occur in 1 in 20,000 newborns.
The cause of Poland syndrome is unknown.
Most cases of Poland syndrome are sporadic, which means they are not inherited and occur in people with no history of the disorder in their families.
Myopathy with deficiency of iron-sulfur cluster assembly enzyme is an inherited disorder that primarily affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
This condition has been reported in several families of northern Swedish ancestry.
Myopathy with deficiency of iron-sulfur cluster assembly enzyme is caused by mutations in the ISCU gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dyskeratosis congenita is a disorder that can affect many parts of the body.
The exact prevalence of dyskeratosis congenita is unknown.
In about half of people with dyskeratosis congenita, the disorder is caused by mutations in the TERT, TERC, DKC1, or TINF2 gene.
Dyskeratosis congenita can have different inheritance patterns.
Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition that affects red blood cells.
Hereditary spherocytosis occurs in 1 in 2,000 individuals of Northern European ancestry.
Mutations in at least five genes cause hereditary spherocytosis.
In about 75 percent of cases, hereditary spherocytosis is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Achondrogenesis is a group of severe disorders that affect cartilage and bone development.
Achondrogenesis types 1A and 1B are rare genetic disorders; their incidence is unknown.
Mutations in the TRIP11, SLC26A2, and COL2A1 genes cause achondrogenesis type 1A, type 1B, and type 2, respectively.
Achondrogenesis type 1A and type 1B both have an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of the TRIP11 or SLC26A2 gene in each cell have mutations.
Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata is a condition that impairs the normal development of many parts of the body.
Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata affects fewer than 1 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata results from mutations in one of three genes.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Lactose intolerance is an impaired ability to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.
Lactose intolerance in infancy resulting from congenital lactase deficiency is a rare disorder.
Lactose intolerance in infants (congenital lactase deficiency) is caused by mutations in the LCT gene.

The type of lactose intolerance that occurs in infants (congenital lactase deficiency) is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the LCT gene in each cell have mutations.
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2 (SCA2) is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement.
The prevalence of SCA2 is unknown.
Mutations in the ATXN2 gene cause SCA2.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Beta-ureidopropionase deficiency is a disorder that causes excessive amounts of molecules called N-carbamyl-beta-aminoisobutyric acid and N-carbamyl-beta-alanine to be released in the urine.
The prevalence of beta-ureidopropionase deficiency is unknown.
Beta-ureidopropionase deficiency is caused by mutations in the UPB1 gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called beta-ureidopropionase.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Microvillus inclusion disease is a condition characterized by chronic, watery, life-threatening diarrhea typically beginning in the first hours to days of life.
The prevalence of microvillus inclusion disease is unknown.
Mutations in the MYO5B gene cause microvillus inclusion disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

Weaver syndrome is a condition that involves tall stature with or without a large head size (macrocephaly), a variable degree of intellectual disability (usually mild), and characteristic facial features.
The prevalence of Weaver syndrome is unknown.
Weaver syndrome is usually caused by mutations in the EZH2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Pfeiffer syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis).
Pfeiffer syndrome affects about 1 in 100,000 individuals.
Pfeiffer syndrome results from mutations in the FGFR1 or FGFR2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Beta-ketothiolase deficiency is an inherited disorder in which the body cannot effectively process a protein building block (amino acid) called isoleucine.
Beta-ketothiolase deficiency appears to be very rare.
Mutations in the ACAT1 gene cause beta-ketothiolase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Familial thoracic aortic aneurysm and dissection (familial TAAD) involves problems with the aorta, which is the large blood vessel that distributes blood from the heart to the rest of the body.
Familial TAAD is believed to account for at least 20 percent of thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections.
Mutations in any of several genes are associated with familial TAAD.
Familial TAAD is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell can be sufficient to cause the condition.
Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency is an inherited condition that disrupts the normal breakdown of fats in the body, resulting in an increase of certain kinds of fats.
This condition affects about 1 per million people worldwide.
Mutations in the LPL gene cause familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) is a condition that causes a variety of signs and symptoms chiefly affecting the nervous system.
The prevalence of NARP is unknown.
NARP results from mutations in the MT-ATP6 gene.
This condition is inherited in a mitochondrial pattern, which is also known as maternal inheritance.
Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies (FENIB) is a disorder that causes progressive dysfunction of the brain (encephalopathy).
This condition appears to be rare; only a few affected individuals have been reported worldwide.
FENIB results from mutations in the SERPINI1 gene.
FENIB is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Dentinogenesis imperfecta is a disorder of tooth development.
Dentinogenesis imperfecta affects an estimated 1 in 6,000 to 8,000 people.
Mutations in the DSPP gene have been identified in people with dentinogenesis imperfecta type II and type III.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Vitiligo is a condition that causes patchy loss of skin coloring (pigmentation).
Vitiligo is a common disorder, affecting between 0.
Variations in over 30 genes, occurring in different combinations, have been associated with an increased risk of developing vitiligo.
Vitiligo sometimes runs in families, but the inheritance pattern is complex since multiple causative factors are involved.
Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency is a disorder characterized by a wide range of severity, with neurological problems in some individuals and no signs or symptoms in others.
Severe dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency, with its early-onset neurological symptoms, is a rare disorder.
Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency is caused by mutations in the DPYD gene.
Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Frasier syndrome is a condition that affects the kidneys and genitalia.
Frasier syndrome is thought to be a rare condition; approximately 50 cases have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the WT1 gene cause Frasier syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Hyperlysinemia is an inherited condition characterized by elevated blood levels of the amino acid lysine, a building block of most proteins.
The incidence of hyperlysinemia is unknown.
Mutations in the AASS gene cause hyperlysinemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Zellweger spectrum disorder is a group of conditions that have overlapping signs and symptoms and affect many parts of the body.
Zellweger spectrum disorder is estimated to occur in 1 in 50,000 individuals.
Mutations in at least 12 genes have been found to cause Zellweger spectrum disorder.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Swyer syndrome is a condition that affects sexual development.
Swyer syndrome occurs in approximately 1 in 80,000 people.
Mutations in the SRY gene have been identified in approximately 15 percent of individuals with Swyer syndrome.
Most cases of Swyer syndrome are not inherited; they occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.
Spastic paraplegia type 11 is part of a group of genetic disorders known as hereditary spastic paraplegias.
Over 100 cases of spastic paraplegia type 11 have been reported.
Mutations in the SPG11 gene cause spastic paraplegia type 11.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Paroxysmal extreme pain disorder is a condition characterized by skin redness and warmth (flushing) and attacks of severe pain in various parts of the body.
Paroxysmal extreme pain disorder is a rare condition; approximately 80 affected individuals have been described in the scientific literature.
Mutations in the SCN9A gene cause paroxysmal extreme pain disorder.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Multicentric osteolysis, nodulosis, and arthropathy (MONA) describes a rare inherited disease characterized by a loss of bone tissue (osteolysis), particularly in the hands and feet.
MONA is rare; its prevalence is unknown.
MONA results from mutations in the MMP2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Histidinemia is an inherited condition characterized by elevated blood levels of the amino acid histidine, a building block of most proteins.
Estimates of the incidence of histidinemia vary widely, ranging between 1 in 8,600 to 1 in 90,000 people.
Histidinemia is caused by mutations in the HAL gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called histidase.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Myotonia congenita is a disorder that affects muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles).
Myotonia congenita is estimated to affect 1 in 100,000 people worldwide.
Mutations in the CLCN1 gene cause myotonia congenita.
The two forms of myotonia congenita have different patterns of inheritance.
Glutaric acidemia type II is an inherited disorder that interferes with the body's ability to break down proteins and fats to produce energy.
Glutaric acidemia type II is a very rare disorder; its precise incidence is unknown.
Mutations in any of three genes, ETFA, ETFB, and ETFDH, can result in glutaric acidemia type II.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Atelosteogenesis type 2 is a severe disorder of cartilage and bone development.
Atelosteogenesis type 2 is an extremely rare genetic disorder; its incidence is unknown.
Atelosteogenesis type 2 is one of several skeletal disorders caused by mutations in the SLC26A2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Mevalonate kinase deficiency is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever, which typically begin during infancy.
More than 200 people with mevalonate kinase deficiency have been reported worldwide; the majority of these individuals have HIDS.
Mutations in the MVK gene cause mevalonate kinase deficiency.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome is a rare, inherited bone disorder that affects primarily the hands and feet.
This condition is very rare; however, the exact prevalence is unknown.
Tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome is caused by mutations in the NOG gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called noggin.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Persistent Mllerian duct syndrome is a disorder of sexual development that affects males.
Persistent Mllerian duct syndrome is a rare disorder; however, the prevalence of the condition is unknown.
Most people with persistent Mllerian duct syndrome have mutations in the AMH gene or the AMHR2 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Deoxyguanosine kinase deficiency is an inherited disorder that can cause liver disease and neurological problems.
The prevalence of deoxyguanosine kinase deficiency is unknown.
The DGUOK gene provides instructions for making the enzyme deoxyguanosine kinase.
Deoxyguanosine kinase deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.

17 alpha()-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency is a condition that affects the function of certain hormone-producing glands called the gonads (ovaries in females and testes in males) and the adrenal glands.
17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency accounts for about 1 percent of congenital adrenal hyperplasia cases.
17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency is caused by mutations in the CYP17A1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Aceruloplasminemia is a disorder in which iron gradually accumulates in the brain and other organs.
Aceruloplasminemia has been seen worldwide, but its overall prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the CP gene cause aceruloplasminemia.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Complement factor I deficiency is a disorder that affects the immune system.
Complement factor I deficiency is a rare disorder; its exact prevalence is unknown.
Complement factor I deficiency is caused by mutations in the CFI gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Dowling-Degos disease is a skin condition characterized by a lacy or net-like (reticulate) pattern of abnormally dark skin coloring (hyperpigmentation), particularly in the body's folds and creases.
Dowling-Degos disease appears to be a rare condition, although its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the KRT5 gene cause Dowling-Degos disease.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome, type 1 is an inherited condition that affects many of the body's organs.
Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome, type 1 is thought to be a rare condition, with about 500 cases reported worldwide.
Mutations in the AIRE gene cause autoimmune polyglandular syndrome, type 1.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Renpenning syndrome is a disorder that almost exclusively affects males, causing developmental delay, moderate to severe intellectual disability, and distinctive physical features.
Renpenning syndrome is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Renpenning syndrome is caused by mutations in the PQBP1 gene.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern.
Asperger syndrome is a disorder on the autism spectrum, which is a group of conditions characterized by impaired communication and social interaction.
The prevalence of Asperger syndrome is not well established.
While genetic factors are believed to contribute to the development of Asperger syndrome, no related genes have been confirmed.
Autism spectrum disorders including Asperger syndrome have a tendency to run in families, but the inheritance pattern is unknown.

Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a disorder in which inflammation and extensive scar tissue (fibrosis) occur in the back of the abdominal cavity, behind (retro-) the membrane that surrounds the organs of the digestive system (the peritoneum).
Retroperitoneal fibrosis occurs in 1 in 200,000 to 500,000 people per year.
No genes associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis have been identified.
Most cases of retroperitoneal fibrosis are sporadic, which means that they occur in people with no apparent history of the disorder in their family.
Legg-Calv-Perthes disease is a bone disorder that affects the hips.
The incidence of Legg-Calv-Perthes disease varies by population.
Legg-Calv-Perthes disease is usually not caused by genetic factors.

When associated with COL2A1 gene mutations, the condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered COL2A1 gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body.
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 13,700 newborns worldwide.
The genetic causes of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are complex.
In about 85 percent of cases of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, only one person in a family has been diagnosed with the condition.
Ataxia with oculomotor apraxia is a condition characterized by progressive problems with movement.
Ataxia with oculomotor apraxia is a rare condition.
Mutations in the APTX and SETX genes cause ataxia with oculomotor apraxia types 1 and 2, respectively.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Costello syndrome is a disorder that affects many parts of the body.
This condition is very rare; it probably affects 200 to 300 people worldwide.
Mutations in the HRAS gene cause Costello syndrome.
Costello syndrome is considered to be an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Craniofacial-deafness-hand syndrome is characterized by distinctive facial features, profound hearing loss, and hand abnormalities.
Craniofacial-deafness-hand syndrome is an extremely rare condition.
Craniofacial-deafness-hand syndrome is caused by mutations in the PAX3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Laing distal myopathy is a condition that affects skeletal muscles, which are muscles that the body uses for movement.
Although Laing distal myopathy is thought to be rare, its prevalence is unknown.
Mutations in the MYH7 gene cause Laing distal myopathy.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Biotin-thiamine-responsive basal ganglia disease is a disorder that affects the nervous system, including a group of structures in the brain called the basal ganglia, which help control movement.
Biotin-thiamine-responsive basal ganglia disease is a rare disorder; its prevalence is unknown.
Biotin-thiamine-responsive basal ganglia disease is caused by mutations in the SLC19A3 gene.
This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Pearson marrow-pancreas syndrome is a severe disorder that usually begins in infancy.
Pearson marrow-pancreas syndrome is a rare condition; its prevalence is unknown.
Pearson marrow-pancreas syndrome is caused by defects in mitochondria, which are structures within cells that use oxygen to convert the energy from food into a form cells can use.
Pearson marrow-pancreas syndrome is generally not inherited but arises from new (de novo) mutations that likely occur in early embryonic development.
Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia is one of about 150 types of ectodermal dysplasia in humans.
Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia is the most common form of ectodermal dysplasia in humans.
Mutations in the EDA, EDAR, and EDARADD genes cause hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia.
Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia has several different inheritance patterns.
Achondroplasia is a form of short-limbed dwarfism.
Achondroplasia is the most common type of short-limbed dwarfism.
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene cause achondroplasia.
Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Squamous cell carcinoma is a cancer that arises from particular cells called squamous cells.
HNSCC is the seventh most common cancer worldwide.
HNSCC is caused by a variety of factors that can alter the DNA in cells.
HNSCC is generally not inherited; it typically arises from mutations in the body's cells that occur during an individual's lifetime.
Lowe syndrome is a condition that primarily affects the eyes, brain, and kidneys.
Lowe syndrome is an uncommon condition.
Mutations in the OCRL gene cause Lowe syndrome.
This condition is inherited in an X-linked pattern.
Zika virus infection is spread to people primarily through the bite of an infected mosquito.
Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a form of degenerative arthritis in which the ligaments (connective tissues that connect bones) around the spine turn into bone.
What causes diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis ? The exact underlying cause of diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is poorly understood.

Hypertrichosis lanuginosa congenita is a congenital (present from birth) skin disease characterized by excessive lanugo (very fine, soft, unpigmented) hair covering the entire body, with the exception of the palms, soles, and mucous membranes.

Acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis - also known as Sweet syndrome - is a skin condition marked by fever, inflammation of the joints (arthritis), and painful skin lesions that appear mainly on the face, neck, back and arms.
What causes acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis? In many cases, the cause of acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis is unknown (idiopathic).
Q fever is a worldwide disease with acute and chronic stages caused by the bacteria known as Coxiella burnetii.
Danon disease is a type of lysosomal storage disorder.
What causes Danon disease? Danon disease is caused by mutation in the LAMP2 gene.
How is Danon disease inherited? Dannon disease is inherited in an X-linked fashion.
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a group of inherited connective tissue disorders that is caused by abnormalities in the structure, production, and/or processing of collagen.
What causes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome? Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can be caused by changes (mutations) in several different genes (COL5A1, COL5A2, COL1A1, COL3A1, TNXB, PLOD1, COL1A2, and ADAMTS2).
Is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome inherited? The inheritance pattern of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) varies by subtype.
Polycystic kidney disease refers to a group of inherited kidney disorders characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in both kidneys.
Autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy (AAG) is rare autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks and damages certain parts of the autonomic nervous system.
What causes autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy? The cause of autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy is not fully understood.
Oral leukoplakia is a diagnosis of exclusion.
Muscular dystrophy (MD) refers to a group of more than 30 genetic diseases characterized by progressive weakness and degeneration of the skeletal muscles that control movement.
A thyroglossal duct cyst is a neck mass or lump that develops from cells and tissues remaining after the formation of the thyroid gland during embryonic development.
Can thyroglossal duct cysts cause weight loss? Weight loss is not commonly cited as a specific symptom of thyroglossal duct cysts, however large cysts can cause difficulty swallowing and breathing.
Chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatosis with lipodystrophy and elevated temperature, also known as CANDLE syndrome, is a rare autoinflammatory condition.
Lesch Nyhan syndrome is a condition characterized by neurological and behavioral abnormalities and the overproduction of uric acid in the body.
How is Lesch Nyhan syndrome inherited? Lesch Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.
Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria (BPP) is a rare neurological disorder that affects the cerebral cortex (the outer surface of the brain).
What causes bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria? The exact underlying cause of bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria (BPP) is unknown.
Is bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria inherited? In most cases, bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria (BPP) occurs sporadically in people with no family history of the condition.
Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that may develop after infection with group A Streptococcus bacteria, such as strep throat or scarlet fever.

What causes rheumatic fever? Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that may develop approximately 14-28 days after infection with group A Streptococcus bacteria, such as strep throat or scarlet fever.
Is rheumatic fever inherited? Rheumatic fever is likely inherited in a multifactorial manner, which means it is caused by multiple genes interacting with each other and with environmental factors.

47 XXX syndrome, also called trisomy X or triple X syndrome, is characterized by the presence of an additional (third) X chromosome in each of a female's cells (which normally have two X chromosomes).
Is 47 XXX syndrome inherited? Most cases of 47 XXX syndrome are not inherited.
Severe intellectual disability-progressive spastic diplegia syndrome is a rare condition that has been described in a few people with severe intellectual disability .
Alpha-thalassemia is a blood disorder that reduces the body's production of hemoglobin.
How is alpha-thalassemia inherited? The inheritance of alpha-thalassemia is complex because the condition involves two genes: HBA1 and HBA2.
Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a bleeding disorder characterized by too few platelets in the blood.
Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) is a rare, movement disorder characterized by a progressive degeneration of the nervous system (neurodegenerative disorder).
Glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1 deficiency syndrome) is an inherited condition that affects the nervous system.
What causes glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome? Glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1 deficiency syndrome) is caused by changes (mutations) in the SLC2A1 gene.
Is glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome inherited? Glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1 deficiency syndrome) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Eales disease is a rare vision disorder that appears as an inflammation and white haze around the outercoat of the veins in the retina.
Cleidocranial dysplasia is a condition that primarily affects the development of the bones and teeth.
What causes cleidocranial dysplasia? Cleidocranial dysplasia is caused by mutations in the RUNX2 (CBFA1) gene.

How is cleidocranial dysplasia inherited? Cleidocranial dysplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Apocrine carcinoma is a cancer of a sweat gland.

X-linked Hypophosphatemia (XLH) is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by low phosphate levels in the blood that can lead to softening and weakening of bones (rickets) as a result of improper processing of phosphate in the kidneys leading to phosphate wasting.
What causes X-linked hypophosphatemia? X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) is caused by mutations in the PHEX  gene on the X chromosome.
How is X-linked hypophosphatemia inherited? X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH) is caused by mutations in the PHEX gene, and is inherited in an X-linked dominant manner.

Ambras syndrome is a very rare type of hypertrichosis lanuginosa congenita, a congenital skin disease characterized by excessive hair growth on the entire body, with the exception of the palms, soles, and mucous membranes.
Mucolipidosis type 4 is a metabolic condition that affects the body's ability to process certain carbohydrates and fats.
Myotonic dystrophy is an inherited condition that affects the muscles and other body systems.
What causes myotonic dystrophy? Myotonic dystrophy is caused by mutations called nucleotide repeat expansions in either the DMPK gene (in type 1) or the CNBP gene (in type 2).
Autoimmune pancreatitis affects the pancreas, a gland behind the stomach and in front of the spine, and can also affect the bile ducts, salivary glands, kidneys, and lymph nodes.
Bartter syndrome is a group of similar kidney disorders that cause an imbalance of potassium, sodium, chloride, and other molecules in the body.

What causes Bartter syndrome? Bartter syndrome may be caused by mutations in any one of several genes; the genetic cause in each case corresponds to the type of Bartter syndrome each affected individual has.

How is Bartter syndrome inherited? Bartter syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means that both copies of the disease-causing gene (one inherited from each parent) have a mutation in an affected individual.
Mevalonic aciduria is the severe form of mevalonate kinase deficiency, a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever that typically begin during infancy.
Retinochoroidal coloboma is an eye abnormality that occurs before birth.

Gordon Syndrome is a rare, inherited type of distal arthrogryposis typically characterized by a combination of camptodactyly (a permanent fixation of several fingers in a flexed position), clubfoot (abnormal bending inward of the foot), and less frequently, cleft palate.

How is Gordon syndrome inherited? While some reports suggest Gordon syndrome may be inherited in an X-linked dominant manner, most agree that it is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with reduced expressivity and incomplete penetrance in females.
Retinal vasculopathy with cerebral leukodystrophy (RVCL) is a rare, genetic condition that primarily affects the central nervous system.

Vici syndrome is a multisystem disorder characterized by agenesis (failure to develop) of the corpus callosum, cataracts , hypopigmentation of the eyes and hair, cardiomyopathy, and combined immunodeficiency.

Chronic fatigue syndrome, also known as systemic exertion intolerance disease, is a condition that causes extreme, long-lasting fatigue which can limit the ability to participate in ordinary, daily activities.
Choroideremia is a genetic condition that causes vision loss.
Paroxysmal nonkinesigenic dyskinesia is a disorder of the nervous system that causes periods of involuntary movement.
Are there non-genetic causes of paroxysmal nonkinesigenic dyskinesia? Yes.
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), congenital is a blood disorder characterized by low platelets (i.
Metachondromatosis (MC) is a rare bone disorder characterized by the presence of both multiple enchondromas and osteochondroma-like lesions.
What causes Askins tumor? In 80% to 90% of Askins tumors, a part of chromosome 11 and chromosome 22 are translocated.
Febrile ulceronecrotic Mucha-Habermann disease (FUMHD) is a rare and severe form of pityriasis lichenoides et varioliformis acuta (PLEVA).
What causes febrile ulceronecrotic Mucha-Habermann disease? The cause of FUMHD is not known (idiopathic).
Familial mixed cryoglobulinemia is a rare condition that is characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins (called cryoglobulins) in the blood.
Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD) is a rare condition that affects the lymph nodes and related tissues.
What causes multicentric Castleman disease? The exact underlying cause of multicentric Castleman disease (MCD) is poorly understood.

Is multicentric Castleman disease inherited? Although the exact underlying cause of multicentric Castleman disease is unknown, it is thought to occur sporadically in people with no family history of the condition.
Congenital pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a rare form of respiratory failure that is present from birth.
Klippel Feil syndrome (KFS) is a congenital, musculoskeletal condition characterized by the fusion of at least two vertebrae of the neck.
What causes Klippel Feil syndrome (KFS)?  The specific underlying causes and mechanisms of Klippel Feil syndrome (KFS)are not well understood.
Is Klippel Feil syndrome inherited? In some cases, Klippel Feil syndrome (KFS) appears to occur randomly for unknown reasons (sporadically).

Nodular nonsuppurative panniculitis describes a rare group of skin disorders characterized by tender, painful bumps below the surface of the skin (subcutaneous nodules) that usually lead to inflammation of the subcutaneous layer of fat (panniculitis).
Osteogenesis imperfecta type 6 is a form of osteogenesis imperfecta which results in weakened bones that breaks easily.
How is osteogenesis imperfecta type 6 inherited? Osteogenesis imperfecta type 6 has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
Cone-rod dystrophies (CRDs) are a group of inherited eye disorders that affect both the cone and rod cells of the retina (photosenstitive receptor cells).
Sjgren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder in which immune cells attack and destroy the glands that produce tears and saliva.
What causes Sjogren syndrome? Sjogren syndrome likely results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors (multifactorial).
Is Sjogren syndrome inherited? A genetic predisposition to Sjogren syndrome has been suggested.
Stickler syndrome is a group of hereditary connective tissue disorders characterized by distinctive facial features, eye abnormalities, hearing loss, and joint problems.

Orofaciodigital syndrome 1 (OFD1), also called orofaciodigital syndrome type 1, is a condition that affects the development of the oral cavity (the mouth and teeth), facial features, and digits (fingers and toes).
Potocki-Lupski syndrome (PTLS) is a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of an extra copy of a tiny portion of chromosome 17 (duplication of 17p11.
Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is an immune disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling.
Endometrial stromal sarcoma is a rare form of cancer that occurs due to abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth in the uterus.
Achondrogenesis is a group of severe disorders that are present from birth and affect the development of cartilage and bone.
What causes achondrogenesis? Research has shown that changes (mutations) in the SLC26A2 and COL2A1 genes cause achondrogenesis types 1B and 2, respectively.
How is achondrogenesis inherited? Achondrogenesis type 1A and type 1B are believed to be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Congenital varicella syndrome is an extremely rare disorder in which affected infants have distinctive abnormalities at birth  due to the mother's infection with chickenpox (maternal varicella zoster) early during pregnancy (i.
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare fatal brain disorder that usually occurs later in life and runs a rapid course.
What causes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease? Some researchers believe an unusual 'slow virus' or another organism causes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).
Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) is a condition characterized mainly by a loss of the muscle functions involved in eye and eyelid movement.

Is chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia inherited? Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO) can be inherited, or it can occur sporadically (due to a new mutation in an individual with no history of the condition in the family).
Popliteal pterygium syndrome is a condition that affects the development of the face, skin, and genitals.
Familial esophageal achalasia refers to a cluster of achalasia within a family.
Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that affects infants from birth and results from a partial or complete loss of thyroid function (hypothyroidism).
Human T-cell leukemia virus, type 1 (HTLV-1) is a retroviral infection that affect the T cells (a type of white blood cell).
What causes human T-cell leukemia virus, type 1? Human T-cell leukemia virus, type 1 (HTLV-1) occurs when a person is infected by the human T-cell leukemia retrovirus.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is one of a group of disorders (collectively called congenital adrenal hyperplasia) that affect the adrenal glands.
How is 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency inherited? This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis type 2 (PFIC2) is a rare condition that affects the liver.
Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) is a group of disorders in which the immune system cannot make antibodies against agents that cause infection (such as bacteria).
What causes common variable immunodeficiency (CVID)? Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) is usually sporadic and thought to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by raised and crusted lesions which affect the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
Lipoic acid synthetase deficiency is a rare condition that affects the mitochondria.
Acute zonal occult outer retinopathy (AZOOR) is a rare condition that affects the eyes.
Synovial chondromatosis is a type of non-cancerous tumor that arises in the lining of a joint.
What causes synovial chondromatosis? The exact underlying cause of synovial chondromatosis is unknown.
Hemangioma thrombocytopenia syndrome is characterized by profound thrombocytopenia in association with two rare vascular tumors: kaposiform hemangioendotheliomas and tufted angiomas.
Tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS) is an inherited condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever.
What causes tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS)? TRAPS is a genetic condition caused by mutations in a gene called TNFRSF1A.
How is tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS) inherited? TRAPS is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Human T-cell leukemia virus, type 2 (HTLV-2) is a retroviral infection that affect the T cells (a type of white blood cell).
What causes human T-cell leukemia virus, type 2? Human T-cell leukemia virus, type 2 (HTLV-2) occurs when a person is infected by the human T-cell leukemia retrovirus.
Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1C is a genetic disorder that is very similar to hypoparathyroidism (parathyroid hormone levels are too low).
Prurigo nodularis is a skin condition characterized by hard crusty lumps that itch intensely.
Isovaleric acidemia (IVA) is a type of organic acid disorder in which affected individuals have problems breaking down an amino acid called leucine from the food they eat.
What causes isovaleric acidemia? Isovaleric acidemia is caused by mutations in the IVD gene.
How is isovaleric acidemia inherited? Isovaleric acidemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) is a tumor that develops from nerve tissue.
BRCA1 hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome (BRCA1 HBOC) is an inherited condition that is characterized by an increased risk for a variety of different cancers.
Mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly (MFDM) is a disorder characterized by developmental delay and abnormalities of the head and face.
What causes mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly? Mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly (MFDM) is caused by mutations in the EFTUD2 gene.
How is mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly inherited? Mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly (MFDM) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Rett syndrome is a progressive, neuro-developmental condition that primarily affects girls.
What causes Rett syndrome? Rett syndrome is typically caused by changes (mutations) in the MECP2 gene.
Is Rett syndrome inherited? Although Rett syndrome is a genetic disorder, less than 1 percent of recorded cases are inherited or passed from one generation to the next.

Peters plus syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by abnormalities of the front part of the eye called the anterior chamber, short stature, cleft lip with or without cleft palate, and distinctive facial features.
Is there anything that I might have done that could have caused or prevented Peters plus syndrome? No.

How is Peters plus syndrome inherited? Peters plus syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, which means that an individual needs to inherit two disease-causing mutations of the B3GALTL gene-one from each parent-in order to have symptoms of the condition.
Chromosome 4q deletion is a chromosome abnormality that affects many different parts of the body.
What causes chromosome 4q deletion? People with chromosome 4q deletion are missing genetic material located on the long arm (q) of chromosome 4 in each cell.
How is chromosome 4q deletion inherited? Chromosome 4q deletion is usually not inherited.
Primary lateral sclerosis is a type of motor neuron disease, where nerve cells that control voluntary muscle movement breakdown and die.

Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia with hypothyroidism and ciliary dyskinesia is a rare condition characterized by alopecia (hair loss); nail dystrophy (abnormal development of the nails); ophthalmic (eye-related) complications; thyroid dysfunction (primary hypothyroidism); hypohidrosis; ephelides (freckles); enteropathy (disease of the intestine); and respiratory tract infections due to ciliary dyskinesia.

Sertoli cell-only syndrome (SCO syndrome) is a condition of the testes that causes infertility in males due to having only Sertoli cells (cells that nurture immature sperm) lining the seminiferous tubules (tubes inside the testicles where sperm develop).
MYH7-related scapuloperoneal myopathy is an inherited muscular dystrophy characterized by weakness and wasting of the muscles in the lower legs and the area of the shoulder blades.
What causes MYH7-related scapuloperoneal myopathy? MYH7-related scapuloperoneal myopathy is caused by mutations in the MYH7 gene.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a rare, inherited condition that is characterized primarily by changes in skin coloring and the development of multiple benign tumors along the nerves of the skin, brain, and other parts of the body.
What causes neurofibromatosis type 1? Neurofibromatosis type 1 is caused by changes (mutations) in the NF1 gene.
How is neurofibromatosis type 1 inherited? Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Glycogen storage disease type 13 (GSD13), also known as -enolase deficiency, is an inherited disease of the muscles.
What causes glycogen storage disease type 13? Glycogen storage disease type 13 (GSD13) is caused by changes (mutations) in the ENO3 gene.

Mollaret meningitis is a rare type of meningitis that is characterized by repeated episodes of fever, stiff neck (meningismus), muscle aches, and severe headaches separated by weeks or months of no symptoms.
An inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT) is an uncommon, presumably benign (non-cancerous) tumor made up of cells called myofibroblastic spindle cells.
What causes inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors? The underlying cause of inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors (IMTs) remains unknown.
Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) is a lung disease that causes inflammation in the small air tubes (bronchioles) and air sacs (alveoli).

What causes bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP)? BOOP may be caused by a variety of factors, including viral infections, inhalation of toxic gases, drugs, connective tissue disorders, radiation therapy, cocaine, inflammatory bowl disease, and HIV infection.
Metaplastic carcinoma of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer.
Disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis (DSAP) is a skin condition that causes dry patches.
Chiari malformations are structural defects in the cerebellum, the part of the brain that controls balance.
Adenoameloblastoma is a lesion that is often found in the upper jaw.
What causes adenoameloblastoma? Currently the cause of adenoameloblastoma is not well understood.
Duane syndrome type 3 is a disorder of eye movement.
Spondylocostal dysostosis is a group of conditions characterized by abnormal development of the bones in the spine and ribs.
Porencephaly is a rare condition that affects the central nervous system.
Laryngomalacia is an abnormality of the cartilage of the voice box (larynx) that is present at birth.
Is laryngomalacia inherited? Laryngomalacia may be inherited in some instances.

Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy is a syndrome with a wide range of manifestations including short stature, obesity, round face, subcutaneous (under the skin) ossifications (gradual replacement of cartilage by bone), and characteristic shortening and widening of the bones in the hands and feet (brachydactyly).
What causes Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy? Albright's hereditary osteodystophy is caused by mutations in the GNAS gene.

How is progressive osseous heteroplasia inherited? This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

Pseudoxanthoma elasticum, PXE, is an inherited disorder that causes calcium and other minerals to accumulate in the elastic fibers of the skin, eyes, and blood vessels, and less frequently in other areas such as the digestive tract.
Myotonic dystrophy type 1, one of the two types of myotonic dystrophy, is an inherited type of muscular dystrophy that affects the muscles and other body systems (e.

How is myotonic dystrophy type 1 inherited? Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Chromosome 1p deletion is a chromosome abnormality that occurs when there is a missing copy of the genetic material located on the short arm (p) of chromosome 1.
Cylindromas are non-cancerous (benign) tumors that develop from the skin.
Geographic tongue is a condition that causes chronic and recurrent lesions on the tongue that resemble psoriasis of the skin.
What causes geographic tongue? Is it genetic? The exact cause of geographic tongue has not been identified.
Noonan syndrome is a genetic disorder that causes abnormal development of multiple parts of the body.
Spondylothoracic dysostosis is a rare condition that affects the bones of the spine and the ribs.
Is spondylothoracic dysostosis genetic? Yes.
Left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) is a rare heart condition.
Genoa syndrome is a rare condition that primarily affects the brain and skull.
Cold urticaria is a condition that affects the skin.
What causes cold urticaria? In most cases of cold urticaria, the underlying cause is poorly understood.
Is cold urticaria inherited? Cold urticaria is not thought to be inherited.
46,XX testicular disorder of sex development is a condition in which a person with two X chromosomes (which is normally found in females) has a male appearance.

Juvenile spondyloarthropathy refers to a group of rheumatic diseases that develop during childhood and are characterized by inflammation of the entheses (the regions where tendons or ligaments attach to bones) and joints.
Hairy cell leukemia is a rare, slow-growing cancer of the blood in which the bone marrow makes too many B cells (lymphocytes), a type of white blood cell that fights infection.
Majeed syndrome is characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and inflammation in the bones and skin.
What causes Majeed syndrome? Majeed syndrome is caused by mutations in the LPIN2 gene.
How is Majeed syndrome inherited? Majeed syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations.
Atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome (aHUS) is a disease that causes abnormal blood clots to form in small blood vessels in the kidneys.

Crusted scabies (also called Norwegian scabies) is a severe form of scabies that most often occurs in people who have a weakened immune system, neurological disease, the elderly, the disabled, or those who are mentally incapacitated.
Acromegaly is a hormonal disorder that results from the pituitary gland producing too much growth hormone (GH).
Oculodentodigital dysplasia is a condition that affects many parts of the body, particularly the eyes (oculo-), teeth (dento-), and fingers (digital).
Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve, the nerve that carries the visual signal from the eye to the brain.
The Glass-Chapman-Hockley syndrome is a very rare disease.

How is Glass-Chapman-Hockley syndrome inherited? Based on the only family that has been reported in the medical literature, to date, the syndrome is believed to be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Precocious puberty is when a person's sexual and physical traits develop and mature earlier than normal.
Progressive hemifacial atrophy, or Parry-Romberg syndrome, is a condition that causes the breakdown of the skin and soft tissues of half of the face.
Reticulohistiocytoma (RH) is a rare benign lesion of the soft tissue.

What causes reticulohistiocytoma? While it is known that reticulohistiocytoma (RH) develop due to a rapid production of immune cells (histiocytes) in the skin or soft tissues, the cause of this process is not currently known.

Hardikar syndrome is a very rare multiple congenital malformation syndrome characterized by obstructive liver and kidney disease, intestinal malrotation, genitourinary abnormalities, cleft lip and palate, pigmentary retinopathy (breakdown of the light-sensing tissue at the back of the eye), and congenital heart defects.
Doyne honeycomb retinal dystrophy (DHRD) is a condition that affects the eyes and causes vision loss.
How is Doyne honeycomb retinal dystrophy inherited? Doyne honeycomb retinal dystrophy (DHRD) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is a genetic condition that is characterized by the growth of cysts in the kidneys (which lead to kidney failure) and liver and problems in other organs, such as the blood vessels in the brain and heart.
How is autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease inherited? Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
Globozoospermia is a rare form of male infertility.
Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS) is a condition that affects the development of bones and other tissues of the face.
What causes Treacher Collins syndrome? Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS) is caused by changes (mutations) in any of several genes: TCOF1 (in over 80% of cases), POLR1C, or POLR1D.
Acquired hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder that interferes with the body's blood clotting process.
Coats disease is an eye disorder characterized by abnormal development of the blood vessels in the retina (retinal telangiectasia).
What causes Coats disease? The exact cause of Coats disease is not currently known.
How is Coats disease inherited? In most cases, Coats disease is not inherited.
Fatal familial insomnia (FFI) is an inherited prion disease that affects the brain and other parts of the nervous system.
What causes fatal familial insomnia? Fatal familial insomnia (FFI) is caused by a specific change (mutation) in the PRNP gene.
How is fatal familial insomnia inherited? Fatal familial insomnia (FFI) is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a rare neurological condition that is caused by an adverse reaction to neuroleptic (tranquilizer) or antipsychotic drugs.
Idiopathic acute eosinophilic pneumonia (IAEP) is characterized by the rapid accumulation of eosinophils in the lungs.
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common skin cancer.
Schwannomas are tumors of the tissue that covers the nerves (nerve sheath).
What causes schwannomas? The cause of schwannomas is unknown.
Are schwannomas inherited? Most schwannomas are not inherited.
